movie_review_blurb: If Chernick set out to portray the couple's movie project as a bit frivolous and self-absorbed, she succeeded. But I doubt that was the intention.
With its snappy, even hectic editing and great archival footage, Who Gets to Call It Art? is loads of fun to watch.
movie_title: Who Gets to Call It Art? (2006)

movie_review_blurb: It's art of the highest order.
The British Tourist Authority wouldn't like London much, but it's the most ambitious, provocative and engaging new British film to surface in a long while.
Widows' Peak is chiefly a comedy, and the main weakness is the choice of director -- John Irvin -- who is best known for action movies and, on this evidence, should stick with them.
An amount of telescoping is inevitable in a story which spans 32 years, but you are left with the feeling that the film has cunningly leapfrogged over key events you would have liked to see.

It is refreshing to find a heavy-hitting European auteur telling his story with such directness, and delightful to see a serious, artistically exacting film for children, even if you suspect it will soar over that audience.
This is a tough ride for a very small return: the cramped and narcissistic anguish of a middle-aged male as seen in Potter passim.
The film, school of Bob and Ted and Wayne and Garth, but inferior in all regards, illustrates the Theory of Reverse Evolution.
Alas, this is a scrappy little film, ill-scripted, photographed and, in particular, directed, and the weird, but very likeable cast is the only reason to see it.

The film courts your sympathy for a practice more common than you'd expect, but by the same token it's very bland, skirting round the reasons why Pasdar likes putting on the glitz, and round the subject's darker fringes.
An impressive debut feature from the young, independent American film-maker Tom Kalin.
It's a low-key affair, whose refusal to spell out its points too loudly is commendable but also a little unsatisfying -- too many details never quite come into focus.
movie_title: The Last Days of Chez Nous (1991)

movie_review_blurb: This is bull of a very high order.

A byzantine story (of star-crossed lovers) that proceeds fitfully through the fabulous logic of dreams; luscious colour-scope photography, and a febrile camera craning and tracking restlessly through fairytale locations and sets.
The Queen of Spades is a treasured relic of a time when the British cinema momentarily abandoned its good manners and revelled gloriously in visual and emotional excess.

There are some of the very finest character actors that Warner Brothers could muster and a rich, detailed screenplay studded with an indecent number of sparklingly quotable lines. It is a movie to play again, and again.
Grant, seeming to get better the further he's allowed to extend his range, delivers a terrific central performance, as acerbic but more complex than his sexy snake in Bridget Jones.
With its clashing Titans, gorgeous costumes and toned bodies, Immortals has something for all, though its main appeal may be to those who enjoy slo-mo exploding heads in 3D.
It's a pleasure to see the director back with his male muse, the star of his radical early films, for the first time in more than 20 years.
In his early forties, the star seems to be struggling for scripts to fit his mercurial bad-boy talent, and this very expensive space comedy won't do his seesaw career any favours.
The director, Endaf Emlyn, previously made One Full Moon, and brings the same visual brio to this small-scale piece. It's benign, hard to dislike. But a little predictable.
It feels like a slender short story spun out close to breaking point. An honourable debut, though.
The overall momentum flags at times and, even though the film runs for a crisp 87 minutes, it feels over-extended.
Abel Ferrara has never been exactly a mainstream film-maker, but with Dangerous Game he wanders too deep into the margins, even for die-hard Ferrara addicts.
The passing years have robbed it of none of its capacity to enchant and amuse.
movie_title: The Tale of the Fox (Le Roman de Renard) (1930)

movie_review_blurb: Mark Rydell directs, often with a leaden hand, but the film is intriguingly structured and has the kind of bittersweet, double-edged ending too rare in mainstream Hollywood these days.
Ryan gives a career redefining performance.
It is a decent, intelligent film that yet somehow fails to excite.
Saucereyed and hedgehog-haired, Brittany Murphy thinks, wrongly, that she is adorably kooky as the party girl.
Shot like a feature-length commercial, Torque is as bright and shiny and inconsequential as a chrome hubcap.
North London-Jewish stories can provide a rich mine of humour, but Suzie Gold is dross.

Often cast in high-energy, borderline manic roles, Bacon creates here a sad, lank-haired, introverted character who doesn't fish for sympathy and, for that very reason, and against all odds, ends up winning it.

With its fast editing and handheld camerawork, the film zips along lightly. Like a classic O Henry short story, it has a sting in the tail. But it's above all about conjuring a sense of atmosphere and place.

Stage Beauty... has a lot going for it. Richard Eyre's spritely direction helps hide the holes in the plot, creating a vivid, raucous, underworld London of transvestites, whores and pickpockets, some played by a terrific supporting cast.
Jean doesn't altogether disappoint with this second offering -- not as a director. Beyond Bedlam is handsomely mounted, with a flair for framing, camera movement and expressionist lighting.
I enjoyed seeing A-list actors in the sort of small supporting role they would never otherwise accept. And they got the film made.

It's rare to see in a British film: a dramatic point that doesn't hinge on dialogue. Four Weddings and a Funeral is a lightweight affair, but this is one of several fine touches that make it, on the whole, a cause for celebration rather than for mourning.

It's not hard to see what drew Richard Attenborough to the story. It is a character-driven piece with two potent leading roles, and he is a former actor known for teasing outstanding performances from his cast.
It's as manipulative as the corporate media it places under fire.

It has a dumb, trashy humour that I have to confess secretly to enjoying.
The four young actors, by whom it stands or falls, deliver impressively, in particular Robertson and Gainsbourg.
It's an excellent introduction to the neglected magic of the cameraman, bolstered by a revolving supporting feature chosen from the examples discussed in the film.
movie_title: Visions of Light: The Art of Cinematography (1993)

movie_title: The Vertical Ray of the Sun (Mua he chieu thang dung) (2000)

movie_review_blurb: A grim tale well told.
After two intense hours revisiting the elemental bond between parent and child, the grit of daily life washes away.
movie_title: Into The Arms Of Strangers: Stories Of The Kindertransport (2000)

movie_review_blurb: A concoction by director David Mirkin that never fails to sink to the lowest common denominator -- yet often hits a funny bone.
Quote not available.

Quote not available.
It would be so easy for an actress to overplay this role, to morph into high camp, but Christensen stays icy cool.
The movie is silly, silly, silly -- and proud of it. There's a good chance you will be giggling helplessly at some point in Johnny English, and 7- to 14-year-olds will be giddy throughout.
A delectable, frothy, often over-the-top 1950s murder mystery by director Francois Ozon.

The tension between the expectations that arise due to the familiar genre and what is actually happening onscreen makes "Copenhagen" special, and a bit strange.

Even if you allow for the the fact that the film is geared towards the 5-year-old set, it's still a pretty dreary experience, made even more so by screamingly vivid colors, uninspiring animation and grating songs.
The dark, surreal animation unearths the personal side of the story: its nightmarish aspect and traumas.
There are a couple of scenes that fall flat, losing the manic push of the rest of the story, but the mood is so screwball that the film hurtles past its own mistakes. It's good fun.
movie_title: Alexander and the Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Day (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The film lingers so lovingly over Zoe's many sexual exploits that one almost feels disappointed when it becomes clear that the film is about to turn into a lecture. Erotica is best when it doesn't take itself too seriously.
An extremely confident and promising debut.

The sheer amount of information that Belzberg had to organize, and fit into a seamless whole, is awe-inspiring. The pace feels like an unstoppable river, the current of history, the continuum of atrocity that Lemkin and others sensed.

The Heart Machine is stylish and effective, aided by Rob Leitzell's moody cinematography.

Brown's gift is in the interviews she gets, which include a grieving father whose son was killed in the explosion and two oil rig workers who now suffer from a variety of maladies, including PTSD and depression.

movie_title: Hector And The Search For Happiness (2014)

"A Coffee in Berlin" veers confidently from melancholy to absurdity and back, and then back again.
"Dolphin Tale 2" cares about the right things: the details of marine rescue, the dedication of the individuals involved, and the lives and personalities of the animals under their care.

A throwback to 1980s action films, with strong men at the center going up alone against an unambiguously evil foe, "Falcon Rising" is an entertaining film with a thrilling physical performance from Michael Jai White.
The music is so terrible and it is such a focal point of the film that it was difficult to get past it.
The set-up, reminiscent of some of Hitchcock's films, works like a well-oiled stopwatch: once the situation starts, it cannot be stopped.

At some points the film lags, loses focus, especially in the segues between vignettes where you can hear the gears creak. Thank goodness it's so pretty to look at, and it is fun to count the references to classic films.
movie_title: Frank Miller's Sin City: A Dame to Kill For (2014)

movie_review_blurb: "Love is Strange" is a patient film. The emotions it unleashes are enormous.

From the very first shot, we are clued in that there are depths of strangeness to be plumbed in even the smallest and most banal interactions.
Selena Gomez is adorable and manages to float away unscathed. But other than that, it's an unfunny comedy, populated by irredeemable sociopaths.
It is good. It is sincere, funny, thoughtful and spiritual, often poignant, and with a deep strain of existential worry running underneath the whole thing.
"Affluenza" thinks it is deep when it is merely trite. It illuminates nothing.

"The Homesman" doesn't play things safe, and that's a welcome change.
The film explores familiar territory, and it's trite in its particulars, but it has a strange emotional power that emerges almost despite itself.
Lowell shows great sensitivity in creating that collective mood, and expressing it through a large, diverse ensemble.

"Eden" is long, but Hansen-Love's style is so observant and specific that it is always a compelling watch and ends up being sneakily profound. It also features one of the best soundtracks in recent memory, a history lesson of club music.
The film launches itself into a dreamspace of its own that has a unique power and pull.
movie_title: A Girl Walks Home Alone at Night (2014)

movie_review_blurb: One needs only to watch his performance in "Samba" to see Sy's old-school natural star power in its purest form. He's the perfect leading man.
"The Amina Profile" is interested in every level of this complex emotionally-fraught story. This is not just the story of the "catfishing" of Sandra Bagaria. Everyone was catfished.
movie_title: A Gay Girl in Damascus: The Amina Profile (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The plot of "Mad Women" is ridiculous, unmotivated and "shocking," but that wouldn't be an issue at all if there had been some attempt at style, or mood, or a point of view.

"Faith of Our Fathers" doesn't work, and not because of its Christian message.
Watching all of these people listen, talk, behave, react, think, work stuff out...that's the genius of "Obvious Child," that's the strength and beauty of its unique wavelength.

What matters in a movie like this is the relationship. Cailley understands that, and keeps his approach simple and transparent.

movie_title: I Am Big Bird: The Caroll Spinney Story (2015)

It does what good documentaries should do: it shines a very focused light on a very specific problem, a problem that affects millions of people and their families.
A powerful and entertaining film about a gang of girls, and what friendship means, the protection it provides.

Takes this well-worn storyline and makes something unique out of it, something fresh and bizarre.
A gigantic spectacle, a virtual-reality experience that is both ridiculous and sublime, sometimes in the same moment.

The magic holds. It holds from beginning to end.

Chuck does nothing new, and it moves through boxing tropes like it's ticking off checkmarks, but there's an honesty to it, a fresh and messy one.
A bold and unique film that has 'personal' written all over it. No one else could have made it.

A potent blend of eroticism, pent-up feelings and good old-fashioned appreciation of beauty.
The presence of Huppert makes Souvenir well worth a look.
The film itself seems to be in denial about its own story.
What is most unexpected about Permission is its sense of poignancy and tenderness. In its own way, it's quite heartbreaking.

A sweet film with a purity of purpose and intent, elevating it above other films portraying similar struggles.

Very quickly devolves into a bland story about a nondescript khaki-wearing guy who learns to care about the less-fortunate.
An unabashed piece of pure entertainment, punctuated by 11 memorable songs.

[An] extraordinary documentary.
In a corporate-run franchise-driven industry, del Toro's movies are refreshingly personal. All of this is true of The Shape of Water, but still, something's off.

A nuanced and sensitive exploration of the many ways rape affects a person's life, even as she tries like hell to get back to normal.
The film has much to recommend it, in particular its lack of sentimentality about suicide, art, womanhood.
[A] gentle and emotionally stressful documentary.
There are some extremely dark moments in Dina, and these are even more powerful because of Santini and Sickles' humanistic approach. Their care for Dina and Scott is clear in every frame.
A sometimes-riveting 'take' on the unexpected uninvited guest plot-line, grounded to the earth by the phenomenal performances of Allison Tolman and Sophie Reid.
A genre film that has things to say about the world in which we live, its emptiness and the chasm between cause and effect.

A rambunctious collage of a self-contained self-sustaining world, with its own rules of play and concerns.

The premise of Mr. Roosevelt is pretty slight, but it's filled with funny performances and biting snippets of social commentary.

movie_title: Bright Lights: Starring Carrie Fisher and Debbie Reynolds (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Fifty Shades Darker may wear leather and chains, but it's still a retro bore.

What does all of this add up to? Damned if I know. But it's fun to see a film that plays by its own rules to such a degree that any comparison to anything else falls apart.

The most pleasurable aspect of 20th Century Women (and it's pleasurable throughout) is that it allows itself to be messy.

The film feels like a blazing catharsis for all involved.
There is a welcome (and surprising) layer of complexity running through the film that makes it a little bit more than your standard fare. The likable and funny ensemble helps too.

If someone had said to Marguerite early on, "Listen. You can't sing," would it have made a difference? Would she have been happy? But Marguerite is undeniably happy when she sings. It's an ethical quandary, one the film has a lot of fun exploring.

Blanchett is a naturally theatrical actress, unafraid of being "dramatic." Because of this, she sometimes seems out of place in a realistic context. But "Carol" plays to her strengths.

A film so purely entertaining that you almost forget how scary it is. With all its terror, "The Visit" is an extremely funny film.

movie_title: Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Road Chip (2015)

movie_review_blurb: "Dheepan" is finely-drawn, beautifully shot and acted, featuring complex characters doing their best in no-win situations.

Engaging and thought-provoking ...

None of this would be possible without the extraordinary performances of these two actresses.

movie_title: Southwest of Salem: The Story of the San Antonio Four (2016)

movie_title: Kandahar: Le soleil derrière la lune (2001)

movie_review_blurb: [Baahubali - The Beginning] boasts of an interesting storyline and sterling performances by the lead actors. The film surely catapults Indian cinema to international levels.

movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A cautionary fable, an unflinching look at the damages of drug culture, and a ray of hope to the end of that culture, Tigers Are Not Afraid is a work of immense beauty, pain, fear and joy.

Brie Larson's directorial debut Unicorn Store is a wonderful debut, a film full of great laughs, terrific performances, clever observations, and a huge, rainbow-coloured heart.
Marjorie Prime is a rare, conversation film that still demands to be seen on the big screen, to fully appreciate its performances and its subtle power

movie_review_blurb: Potash's closeness to it, and sense of healthy outrage, invigorate the film and make the saga's central participants impossible to forget.

movie_review_blurb: A damning look at Big Coal and its landscape-decimating practices, a litany of disheartening statistics and enraging testimony.

movie_review_blurb: Subscribing to the philosophy that creepy equals interesting, the film contains barely a moment that isn't flat-footed, ludicrous or both.

movie_review_blurb: Much of what passes for fresh in this Scarlet Letter update doesn't bear closer inspection, yet the movie is not without its pleasures, chief among them the potentially star-making lead performance by Emma Stone.

movie_review_blurb: Simon Pegg is likably smart and obnoxious as the fish-out-of-water Brit in high-gloss Manhattan, but he's swimming upstream in a feature that substitutes slapstick for scathing wit.
movie_title: How to Lose Friends & Alienate People (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The finely crafted Alice Neel is at once tribute, investigative journalism and messy family drama.

The movie doesn't take its broad, jokey premise terribly far, but it manages to sustain a goofy-sweet comic energy and offers sly observations about assimilation, sibling rivalry and the art of competitive maternal bragging.
Packed with facts, figures and the testimony of policy experts, the film is no wallow in wonkiness, but a surprisingly sprightly tough-love lesson in fiscal responsibility.

Alive with improvisational energy and rejecting the conventional biographical format, the film pursues ideas and feelings rather than chronology as it scats through an archival wealth of interviews with O'Day and some of her most inspired performances.
movie_title: Anita O'Day: The Life of a Jazz Singer (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Every triumph registers low on the emotion meter, and most of the supporting characters are two-dimensional at best.
Refreshingly sincere and full of wholesome can-do spirit.
It feels more like a small-screen distraction.
A genial, hit-and-miss return to the ridiculous for Adam Sandler.
movie_title: You Don't Mess With the Zohan (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Period tale of real-life heroism doesn't fully come to life.
by-the-numbers audience-pleaser.
With the collaboration of screenwriter Tonino Guerra, Khemir has created a fresh variation on the somewhat tired subgenre of the crisscross, in which the paths of strangers intersect and converge.
movie_title: Bab'Aziz: The Prince Who Contemplated His Own Soul (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Straight out of the slice-and-dice school of filmmaking, Vantage Point fractures chronology and perspective in a vain attempt to disguise its flimsiness.
A frenzied comedy promoting the family values of loud, obnoxious and mean.
A harebrained rom-com diversion offering few laughs and little romance.
A fresh, intelligent and thoroughly involving psychological thriller.
An engagingly angry black comedy from Norway.
For all its playful touches and neat-o nostalgia for nondigital entertainment, the whimsy feels forced.
Most viewers will be left to wonder whether the message is connecting.

Those who stick with Martian Child won't entirely avoid mush, but they will find terrific performances by John Cusack, as the parental unit, and 10-year-old Bobby Coleman, as the self-proclaimed extraterrestrial.
A mildly fractured fairy tale that's often too dopey for its own good.
Sharp, insightful look at the ups and downs of one of L.A.'s most influential alternative bands.
movie_title: Everyday Sunshine: The Story of Fishbone (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Like its central character, Henry Jaglom's 16th feature is gangly and graceful, awkward and tender, a jumble of astute observation and clunkily heightened reality.
A slight, if often riveting, behind-the-scenes documentary.
The collision of adolescent hormones and parental folly, hardly new cinematic territory, gets a bracing absurdist slant in Youth in Revolt.
Even with a terrific voice cast, this animated romantic adventure is hit-and-miss.
Patricia Clarkson's charismatic warmth elevates an awkward inspirational sports drama.
If not entirely satisfying, it stays with you nonetheless, capturing the oppressiveness of the criminal brotherhood and the cost of an extraordinary young woman's courage.
A dire warning and solid piece of advocacy journalism, complete with an action checklist at film's end.
Steeped in an authentic sense of place, this crime drama is less convincing on the storytelling front.
The story deepens through the clownish, heartbreaking exertions of Rockwell's gruff misfit, still working things out at the final buzzer.
The metaphors are so crystal-clear and the story unfolds at such a deliberate, often infuriatingly slow pace that the impact of the drama is muted.
movie_title: The Milk of Sorrow (La Teta Asustada) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Audiences will shrug at the mystery's solution but likely will be eager to see what Berger & Co. do next.
The body count is high and the personalities click in this old-school testosterone fest.
Williams draws upon countless earlier dramas without adding anything fresh or memorable to the discussion.
Schneider has fashioned a measured fable, witty and deeply felt, if at times tipping into melodrama.
Pulsing with incredulity and dread, it's less a fully developed argument than the seed of one.
Ambitious, if not always satisfying.
A well-made and entertaining descent into a black-comic hell.

What saves it from starry-eyed fuzziness and grounds it in sociopolitical reality is Brown's clear-sighted anger and the astute perceptions of talking heads including Cornel West, Ice-T and Norman Lear.
movie_title: GhettoPhysics: Will the Real Pimps and Hos Please Stand Up! (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A genial, low-impact collection of thoughtful sound bites on all the big stuff.
Posing big questions about love and sex and work, this cartoonish rom-com is far more conventional than it wants to be.
Brimming with affection and beautifully shot, but it builds a flimsy case for why it matters.
Furry Vengeance is a collection of feeble jokes in the service of green themes. Sustainability never looked so stupid.
Fans of Choe's work - stylized, vibrant, ornate and vulgar - will appreciate the inside look at the self-described man-child, but his struggles to grow up are more tiresome than compelling.
movie_title: Dirty Hands: The Art & Crimes of David Choe (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Hardwired as we are to respond to infants, it's difficult not to be drawn in to the innate cuteness. The filmmaker's emotional connection to his subjects is clear, and even when "Babies" loses steam, it casts the human story in a fresh light.
The immediacy of the filmmaking helps to fill the void, and Bones' unaffected performance has its moments.
At the heart of Prodigal Sons, a family drama in the form of a succinct, eloquent personal journal, is a sibling rivalry whose reverberations touch upon the very essence of human identity...
A dark vitality fuels this cold case in the cold north of Sweden.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The culture clash is muy muted in this alternately sweet and dumb comedy.
Sometimes stilted procedural cuts to the chase to deliver a haunting history lesson.
Like a lot of Valentine's Day gifts, showy and easily forgotten.
Although sometimes too sly for its own good, this great-looking carnivorous caper brings Wes Anderson's whimsical melancholy to a kids' classic.
The rhythm's off in this goofy tale of an air-drumming underdog.
From the catacombs to the city's heights, Paris turns an unblinking gaze on the beauty of melancholy and the daring leap toward joy.
A dynamic portrait of doctors without halos.
movie_title: Living in Emergency: Stories of Doctors Without Borders (2010)

movie_review_blurb: If theory ultimately outstrips drama in this semi-serious inquest into identity, gender and love, the filmmaking is often thrilling.
[It] feels padded even in its brief running time; it's a slight mood piece posing as a character study.

Whatever personal risks first-time director Hossein Keshavarz took to make the film, there's little sense of danger in the finished product, which offers snapshots of middle-class Iran but falls flat on the dramatic front.
The film uses the upper-middle-class setting effectively, even as it resorts to heavy-handed symbolism and melodrama in its dour, mostly unforgiving portrait of parental dysfunction.
A noodling indulgence that's alternately freewheeling and dead in the water.
movie_title: A Glimpse Inside the Mind of Charles Swan III (2013)

movie_review_blurb: How many directors does it take to screw in a star-studded piece of aggressive stupidity and call it a movie? An even dozen, and there is no punch line.
This character-driven genre meld could have used more edge and energy, and less obvious message-mongering, but it scores in terms of atmosphere, humor and charm.
Policy wonk Robert Reich's analysis of today's parallels to the Great Depression is both statistics-driven and impassioned.
There's a lovely naivete and straightforward sense of place to this modern-day folktale.
It's a wild and vivid ride and a spirited reminder of the kinship between Jewish and Arab cultural traditions.

The road to the inevitable slapsticky Seder is paved with more sweetness than bite, a good deal of frantic foolishness and progressively thinner laughs, all wrapped in a message of acceptance and inclusiveness.

Efficiently told and features solid performances, but without the juicy character detail, vise-grip suspense or black comic intensity of its memorable forerunners, it unwinds as a boilerplate genre item.
A beguiling set of variations on a theme, a gossamer-light étude composed for delight rather than dissection.
Thor Heyerdahl's legendary rafting expedition gets glossy treatment in this handsome but underwhelming action-adventure.
The attention it pays to every fluttered eyelash, flared nostril and furrowed brow makes for one long haul of an affair.
"Tchoupitoulas" is a jewel-bright whoosh of a ride through nighttime New Orleans.
The film ably captures the painful messiness of seemingly simple lives.
Lizzy Caplan and Alison Brie lend the lightweight rom-com "Save the Date" more than its fair share of watchability. But the film is never truly interesting.
A fascinating portrait of municipal and private interests trying to make headway in the charged atmosphere of devastating personal loss and wounded national pride.
Though its early sections feel repetitive and self-congratulatory, the doc's tension builds in the way director Mary Liz Thomson uses archival material, much of it from TV news.
Evidence that even at 94, and even in flat surroundings, the late actor possessed undeniable screen magnetism.
movie_title: The Man Who Shook The Hand of Vincente Fernandez (2012)

movie_review_blurb: With its stock characters and low-expectation high jinks, the German import "What a Man" could have been fabricated on the Hollywood rom-com assembly line.
A chaste young-adult romance that bites into supernatural melodrama, science fiction and political conspiracy theories.
Director Feng Xiaogang captures the epic scale of the exodus as well as the often-harrowing details, yet emotional connection proves more elusive.
The movie contains enough fresh insanity and inventive visuals to make it an amusing cyberpunk extravaganza for most of its protracted running time.

In "Holy Motors" Carax insists on our other selves. His daylong ride is a wary celebration, a joyful dirge that's served up in concentrated form by a roving band of accordion players. It's all in a day's work.

If the movie doesn't entirely get past its hard-to-buy premise, director Paolo Sorrentino does have the courage of his convictions, not just embracing every contradiction but spinning many of the story's contrivances into moments of strange, aching beauty.
Though it doesn't always hit the hilarity target, this tween-targeted romp strikes a sweet-but-not-sappy balance.
Blawut's fast-moving doc is a sharp rendering of a kind of tech-enabled time travel, and the way this online fraternity is rewriting history while very much in its grip.
[Portrays] a vibrant culture and its festive traditions, rarely evoked in depictions of a nation long devastated by war.
The actors give their characters a resonance beyond the symbolic, but the action doesn't quite transcend the stagy setup.
The reality-cable-style approach tends to overstay its welcome and lessen the impact of each portrait, especially when it comes to New Yorker Winnifred's teen dramatics.
Kiarostami embarks on a typically indirect but never rambling path in "Like Someone in Love," crafting an elegant mystery that resonates beyond its final, jolting moment.
It's too bad the filmmaker felt the need to lighten his unvarnished observations about aging with "cute" stuff.
It never discovers new worlds, but "Escape From Planet Earth" is, in its genial way, escape enough.
If the romantic fate of the central triangle never matters, the sumptuous wistfulness of the filmmaking does.
Taut and effective edge-of-the-seat horror, delivered with style and an especially haunting performance by Vera Farmiga.
The lack of opposing voices diminishes the film, even as Stone raises issues that shouldn't be discounted out of hand.
A twisted tribute to analog moviemaking and 1970s Italian Giallo horror flicks.
Barbara Sukowa's performance in the title role is the kind that reverberates long after the screen goes black.
The movie could have made its points - war is bad; music is the universal language - in half the time. But the harmonies are sweet, the acoustic picking impressive.
A lean, economically told indie that should please fans of the 1981 source novel.
Insights are few in this fan letter of a documentary.
movie_title: One Track Heart: The Story of Krishna Das (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Though his treatment of the subject is often superficial, Perlman makes a clear argument for the broader implications, especially for Western consumers.
movie_title: Free China: The Courage to Believe (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Zeroing in on the art of rehearsal, "Becoming Traviata" is an exquisitely observed look at performance and the creative process.
Innocence meets experience, unconvincingly, in the strained redemption drama "33 Postcards."
The farce is so light on its feet that it's buoyant.
movie_title: He's Way More Famous Than You (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The performers are up to the wacko task. But one of the movie's key problems is that it only pretends to let loose, its calculated absurdity firmly tethered to the life lessons that lie in wait.
Siphons off bits of "Play It Again, Sam," "Hannah and Her Sisters" and "Manhattan Murder Mystery" in its underwhelming tale of a thirtysomething Parisian's search for Mr. Right.
For a film that purports to go beyond the surface and uncover the "true essence" of adult film stars, "Aroused" spends a lot of time admiring the surface.
With its fine eye for detail, At Any Price is also a complicated and revelatory look at the intersection of country folk and corporate might.
Low-rent Wes Anderson, without the style or heart.
With its clarity and depth, Gavilan's singing is as good as her acting.
Admiring but hardly deifying, this portrait of an ecological warrior is compelling viewing -- as philosophical overview, character study and high-seas adventure.
As a portrait of female strength and a celebration of the artistic spirit, "Leonie" too seldom comes fully alive.
Even though the handsome black-and-white lensing is no substitute for a compelling story, it helps, infusing the skin-deep sketches of emotional enervation with aesthetic energy - for a while.
A winking portrait of visionaries, geeks and wackos that's diverting but too cheeky for its own good.
Without straining for big-picture significance, it provides a composed look into the revolutionary spirit.

A brisk, good-looking and never dull B movie.
The material has the mild impact of a special episode of a network crime series, with Eklund's villain a figure of mannered creepiness rather than profound chills.

A work whose elegant atmospherics ultimately overwhelm the story, even with the terrific Vincent Cassel in the title role.
Mungiu's quietly gripping film challenges expectations, refusing to merely lay forth an argument against benighted religion or to make Alina a simple victim.
A would-be thriller whose intended horror-tinged chills register as ho-hum hokum.
A film whose core is a haunting question: When parents are monstrous, where does filial love begin and end?

Director John Putch struggles to find balance or generate a single spark from the clunky mix of romance, political diatribe and thriller.
Though it's handled with little subtlety, the way the atmosphere of suspicion in Vichy France filters down to the kids is a smart slant on the material.

movie_review_blurb: There's an unflashy clarity to the documentary "Bill W." that suits its subject.
Amid the would-be and actual laughs, the screenplay tries to drum up drama, but every disagreement and tension is treated superficially and summarily resolved.
movie_title: What to Expect When You're Expecting (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The performances are uneven, but there's a grimy thrill to seeing scenes from the play in subway cars and on fire escapes.
Smart girls do stupid things, there's no doubt about it. But Ansiedad's bad behavior is supposed to be both faux and earnest, a premise that doesn't jell.
Gren Wells' screenplay throws around a few ideas about female independence and sexuality, but finally it's as shallow as it is mawkish.
The movie, a hit on its home turf of Turkey, is a straight-up shot of martyrdom and extravagance, honor and glory.
An up-close but superficial portrait of aspiring MMA stars as they fight their way through the Cajun Country regional circuit.

Amid the mythical allusions and the climate of decay, "Keyhole" overthinks its exploration of memory and forgiveness.

A gentle fable whose humanist heart beats in Michel Piccoli's nuanced performance.
A police procedural as existential inquiry, set in a remote dreamscape of mystery and foreboding.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in Anatolia (2012)

A lot of the film unrolls like wasted opportunities, placeholders between the cheesy musical interludes and ludicrous Peckinpah-esque violence.
Filmmakers Ola Simonsson and Johannes Stjärne Nilsson and their engaging cast pull off the feat with no strain and a surprising amount of heart.

Despite its wobbly tone and stumbles into implausible melodrama, the film succeeds as a study of realignments among friends and family, a gently cracked mirror held up to the insanity that would soon devastate the region.
Even as it zeros in on radical shifts in the mechanics and mores of parenthood, it sits quite comfortably in a well-worn romantic-comedy groove.
Reaches for thematic resonance and ends up only cliché-deep.
With its modest scale and sharp observations, writer-director Liza Johnson's first feature has the quiet impact of a short story.
A self-indulgent pilgrimage to the shrine of '70s fabulousness, "Ultrasuede: In Search of Halston" assembles a fine assortment of archival material but falls far short of its stated goal.

An ungainly mix of flat-footed gumshoeing and strained attempts at hilarity, all delivered with an unconvincing Joizy vibe.
Glossing over such inconvenient facts as out-of-wedlock fatherhood, this unabashed encomium skimps on complexity and insight in the name of veneration.
"Over Your Cities Grass Will Grow" is that rare art documentary - one that places the art front and center, not as an adjunct to its maker's biography.
movie_title: Over Your Cities Grass Will Grow (2011)

movie_review_blurb: "Flowers" abounds with well-worn movie archetypes and slathers on schmaltz.
Director Edmon Roch makes some smart conceptual choices that honor his subject's self-invention and mystery.
Alarming viewing for anyone who cares about the American justice system.
A disquieting, heartbreaking look at American crime and punishment.
Set among the hangdog hicks and arcade attractions of a fictional Southern beach town, the loosely autobiographical movie aims for roller-coaster passion but only flatlines.
Inspired by a documentary, the film is shot with vérité immediacy and beautifully acted by an outstanding ensemble.
The material is programmed to stimulate funny bones and tear ducts in a reassuring alternating pattern.
Performances are superb across the board, framed in elegant widescreen compositions that simmer with violence.
Winstead, who appears in nearly every scene, can be compelling but, like the material, often pushes too hard ...
It's a film as profoundly sad as it is enraging and potentially galvanizing, and it's one of the most important pieces of nonfiction to hit the screen in years.
Moving between a present-day mother-daughter clash of values and a personal history of life under Mao's regime, her docudrama is an awkward mix.
Given the talent assembled for this diversion, you can't believe it's not better.
Flirting with farce, the film never gets out of comic first gear.
The film suggests a state of grace between childhood and adulthood, but the narrative feels increasingly tentative, and the characters remain opaque - "local divas," in one teacher's estimation.
An exceptional portrait of a community in crisis and the focused fury of its response.
As raw as the material of "5 Broken Cameras" can be, it is also lyrical and elegiac.
The nonaggressive approach can be frustrating, but it nonetheless gets under the skin-deep promises of glamour and wealth that lure a seemingly endless stream of very young hopefuls.

With its vague organizing principle, the film fails to achieve an impact greater than the sum of its parts.

It's not entirely satisfying, but there's plenty to savor in "Chicken With Plums."
A documentary as gentle as its subject: the story of a boy who realized his dream and, on the film's evidence, received a lot of encouragement and support along the way.

A sort of kinder, gentler "Borat."
With its international collection of mostly two-dimensional characters and its barely developed ideas on adultery, capitalism, addiction and sex, "360" is an over-plotted and dreary farrago.
At its best, it's a sly dismantling of a familiar comedy template built on male cluelessness and female responsibility.
It's not likely that a big-screen alien invasion has ever felt less urgent.
[An] excellent and unexpectedly nuanced documentary...

As a portrait of a nation amid accelerated and profound change, "Trishna" is a vivid piece of cinema. As a melodrama, it's provocative without being emotionally involving, the central performance more distancing than engaging.
The overall impression is as fleeting as much of the imagery that flashes across the screen.

It's the killer pingpong action that ultimately keeps Balls afloat.

A compelling, beautifully acted drama.

There's a generic feel to the saga and, especially, the character of Allie.

A timely and provocative critique of the notion of journalistic objectivity.

A film of quiet depth and lyrical beauty.

movie_review_blurb: There are comic and poignant moments throughout.
A predictable comedy masquerading as the tale of an unlikely political nail-biter.

Cunningham's 1990 novel makes an assured, if not entirely satisfying, transition to the big screen in this terrifically acted exploration of the bonds that transcend traditional notions of family.

movie_review_blurb: If anyone was clamoring for a follow-up to 1999's Baby Geniuses, they'll be happy to know that the sequel retains not only the same gimmicky premise as the original but its preference for cliche-ridden dialogue and flat-footed comedy as well.
A small-scale but winning comedy.
Mitchell's nuanced intensity as the vulnerable Melinda, especially in her more high-strung incarnation, is key to the film's success.
Minimalist but not austere, brimming with compassion but devoid of schmaltz.

Irving, a longtime filmmaker and lifelong birdwatcher, captures her subjects with striking intimacy. She shapes a well-told story, capped by a few dramatic turns of event.

movie_review_blurb: The power of even the muddiest B&W images is remarkable, Nomi's delicate whiteface visage penetrating the murk, his falsetto pure and free of irony.

movie_review_blurb: The great achievement of Guerrilla: The Taking of Patty Hearst, besides its unearthing of gripping archival material and its groundbreaking new interviews, is its insistence on context rather than sensationalism.
movie_title: Guerrilla: The Taking of Patty Hearst (2004)

The terrific ensemble cast finds the right deadpan tone to deliver the dysfunction.
Fly's subtle observations about certain elements of the upper class come through with quiet force.

The director has fashioned a powerful argument that places the fight for legalized gay marriage firmly within the lineage of human-rights struggles.

An ambitious next-generation spin on the found-footage genre, Population Zero starts out like an indie version of a true-crime TV news magazine and turns into a horror-tinged drama with a topical slant.
As the story gives way to repetitious sightseeing sequences and melodrama, it proves less than fully satisfying. But there's plenty to admire along the way ...
Ljung's clear-eyed film finds hope within terrible circumstances, and strength within heartbreak.
movie_title: The Blood Is at the Doorstep (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The participants profiled in Lysa Heslov's documentary are the epitome of resilience, but they're also disarmingly honest and funny as hell. In a word, they're irresistible.
Sometimes freedom's just another romanticized word for a knot of tough realities - as documentarian Nanfu Wang discovers in her affecting new film.
Uneven but deeply felt.
A riveting group encounter.
It revolves around a bank heist, but the real crime in Going in Style is its waste of acting talent.
While the young-love melodrama isn't about to entice older viewers, the target audience will swoon.
The film is as vibrant as it is personal and urgent.

Though the engaging documentary treads through unavoidably familiar territory ... its chorus of testifiers often find sharp new angles of approach. Like the jokes they hone, many of their insights arrive with the impact of well-crafted punchlines.
For too much of its running time, Bronwen Hughes' feature feels more like a hyper-ebullient travelogue than a biographical portrait of an extraordinary young man.
A guns-and-sex comedy that fires blanks on all fronts.
movie_title: Is That a Gun in Your Pocket? (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A thoughtful lesson in history - and listening.
Though it sometimes loses its melodic flow, the doc (directed by Brad Allgood and Graham Townsley, with co-direction by Juliana Penaranda-Loftus) is a testament to spirited determination.
Amid all the hand-wringing about student debt, Mims offers a jolt of chilling clarity.
For Antonioni, beginnings and endings aren't plot points on a narrative graph; they resonate everywhere, entwined and inseparable.
The If Project's portrait of people-focused policing is not just inspiring but an urgent lesson in communication across a widening divide.
Wayne Roberts' powerfully low-key drama gets under the skin.
Hits every note of plucky positivity so squarely on the head that it leaves little room for audience involvement.
A lazily written and generically directed Fatal Attraction knockoff.
Consider it a matter of scientific certainty that the film will induce groans from its audience.
What might be engrossing in Liz Jensen's source novel is oddly opaque in this screen mishmash, and much of what's meant to be tense or suspenseful is merely awkward.
Until its letdown of a final stretch, Morgan is a gripping group portrait of menace and vulnerability, each punch to the solar plexus a burning question, timeless and of the moment.

The assured feature debut by Andrew Ahn is also the story of a young gay man's sexual awakening, and its sensitive lead performance affectingly expresses the tension between tradition and personal identity.
The central couple's ups and downs may grow tiresome, but the characters, powerfully realized by Emmanuelle Bercot and an especially riveting Vincent Cassel, never do.
It's a story of contained chaos, quietly observed - one that catches fire more in retrospect than in the viewing.
Caught as it is between mocking romance clichés and investing in them, the film is too up in the air to succeed on either front, as love story or sendup.
The events, evoked through news coverage, play out with little tension in a film whose chief concern is to laud a man already held in high esteem.
movie_title: Follow Me: The Yoni Netanyahu Story (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Curtis understands his son's need to test boundaries as much as his own responsibility to protect him. Robinson makes this single dad's loneliness plain. Morris isn't the only one on the cusp.
Enlightening but seldom riveting ...
Beautifully observed ...
Whatever nuance can be found in Front Cover, the story of an openly gay fashion stylist and a seemingly homophobic Chinese movie star, belongs chiefly to the performances of Jake Choi and James Chen.
Illuminating and often powerful, if not always satisfying ...

"Aftermath," that tossed-around cliché, comes into tender, harrowing focus. ... A crucial, profound strength of Newtown is its refusal to rush toward "closure" as necessary, or even to suggest that it's possible.
As a study of endurance and self-preservation in the face of persistent double standards, the movie clicks.
If this film portrait stirs deep emotions, they spring from a breathtakingly unsentimental embrace of life at its most challenging.

Some legs of the journey are detours, and the film can feel overlong and diffuse, but as a capsule history it offers revelatory insights, particularly in its emphasis on the role of distance running in the women's movement.
Cranston turns every moment of duplicity, which is to say nearly every scene of The Infiltrator, into an emotionally textured high-wire act.
Despite the overdone stylistics in the film's final third, Sen-Gupta's dark dreamscape distills notions of vulnerability with gritty power.
Stunning stylized visuals, girl power and a strong rooting interest fuel a wonderfully old-fashioned tale.
movie_title: Long Way North (Tout en haut du monde) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Leads Zach Galifianakis, Owen Wilson, Kristen Wiig and Jason Sudeikis bolster the hit-and-miss story with soulful goofiness.
With its old-fashioned gloss, the incident-packed story proves only mildly engaging and finally has little to say.
Holm assumes the audience requires ample evidence of Ove's goodness, and the film loses its footing in backstory melodrama.
movie_title: A Man Called Ove (En man som heter Ove) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Given the imaginative setup and the material's provocative questions about mortality - not to mention the future of humankind - the movie's neat lessons about the nature of happiness and a life well lived feel too easy, too obvious.
The story remains an academic argument, struggling to pierce the handsome surface.
However suspensefully the score groans and cries, the emotional stakes dwindle with each overemphatic narrative curve.
With all the sharp comic timing on hand, this party should feel lighter, swifter, more agile.
Uninvolving from start to finish, the would-be thriller Anonymous traffics in a certain bland slickness, placing it squarely in the international crime subset of generic action features.

As the fog closes in, so too does the foreboding, expertly tuned to fraught dissonance by director Sophia Takal, who blends art-house flourishes with such horror conventions as the spotty cellphone reception that signals trouble.
The filmmaker's questions are sensitive yet penetrating, the musician's responses thoughtful, eloquent and pained.
A sweet and clever spin on time travel and rock fandom.

Writer-director Lang explored the character with Richard in two shorts, and there's a lived-in feel to the portrait that emerges in the visually adventurous "Baden Baden," which weaves darkly luminous fantasy imagery into Ana's mostly aimless hours.
Like the heroic Bostonians it celebrates, civilians and law enforcement both, Peter Berg's Patriots Day gets the job done.
Winningly bittersweet despite its frustratingly slight lapses.

At its strongest, Dark Night taps into the emptiness, hurt and longing beneath the pings and swipes of our "connected" world. But for all its artfulness, the film doesn't shed light so much as push buttons.
Life may be on the line, but it's in short supply on the screen.

The cameras avoid the goriest angles of the mutilated animals, but the horror is amplified as the film moves from the savannas of Kenya and Tanzania to display windows in Hong Kong showcasing carved ivory curios.
Holmes' unfocused screenplay makes clear that his subject was an honorable thief (Hall never took a life), but the writer-director never makes any of it matter.
"Gimme Danger" is essentially a family album assembled by an enamored outsider.
Though the movie's well cast, its central story rarely shakes off the derivative cloak to become involving. But Ron Livingston's turn as a sorrowful Elvis Presley is a quiet revelation.

Schisgall's interviews with her enrich the portrait of Padnos, but it's the journo's open gaze and natural inquisitiveness, his refusal to merely demonize his abusers, that give the film its discomforting power.
It would be nice to applaud Lynne Alana Delaney's creativity, but the result is so ham-handed and unconvincing that it's far easier to wish she'd enlisted more help in realizing her vanity project.
Terrifically engaging.
Mistaking moody poses for storytelling, the Iceland-set "Autumn Lights" gathers an international assortment of insufferable ciphers in a remote coastal town.
As heartfelt and personal as the story is, much of it feels like standard teen angst.
[W]hat might have been a tantalizing whodunit about the less-than-gleaming gears of justice ... is instead a curiously uninvolving exercise in procedure.
Flirting with sitcommy high jinks, Clark instead gives us a bittersweet cocktail of soul-weary defeat and unassuming vigor.

If this adulatory "American Masters" production elides certain chapters of Angelou's biography, it nonetheless offers ample evidence of her commanding intensity and of her importance as an unwavering voice of the black experience.
movie_title: Maya Angelou: And Still I Rise (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The raw vigor and protest of punk get co-opted by the movie's coming-of-age story; it's not the heartfelt sweetness that's the chief problem, but how run-of-the-mill and derivative the plot is.

Tom Donahue's moving work of advocacy journalism draws on a range of experts on the military and its mental health crisis, but it's the first-person chronicles of the walking wounded that give the documentary its urgency and power.
As Grasten strains to connect the unhappy lot to the Genovese myth, convincing drama flickers out of reach.
Director Leyla Bouzid may struggle to shape her narrative in the final reels, but through most of its running time her first feature pulses with in-the-moment vitality.
movie_title: As I Open My Eyes (À peine j'ouvre les yeux) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The desultory finished product would be unwatchable if not for the grounding presence of the two leads and JoBeth Williams' supporting turn.
This resourceful low-budget picture could have gone deeper, but within its brief running time manages to send up materialism, groupthink, celebrity worship and political posturing.

Wan's expert deployment of genre jolts is no less in evidence this time around, but as he takes his time - perhaps even a bit too much of it - interweaving the Warrens' story with that of the Hodgsons... he crafts a deep dive into dread.
None of it is earth-shattering, but Goodman gives it muscle and makes it work.
Whatever Rosefeldt intended, "Manifesto" doesn't quite set forth a manifesto of its own. But it's a blast of fresh air.
More than the story of an individual, the film is a stirring tribute to endangered folk traditions.
There's an eloquent handmade quality to "Arthur Miller: Writer," filmmaker Rebecca Miller's engagingly intimate portrait of her famous father.
However nuanced and artful, the nightmarish unease is laid on so thick that, in combination with the cryptic narrative, it gradually turns to murk.
Director Markus Rupprecht and his cowriter, Donna Logan, never get beyond the handsome period surface to an involving emotional core.
The clunky organization and very basic production values give way to something inspiring.
In that discomfortingly close range between the unlikeliest of friends, and between rapture and repulsion, the film finds its compelling edge.
But it's the salt-of-the-earth Borregos, a trio of farmer brothers and their sister, who give the film its most involving through-line, and its heart.
A low-key comedy of errors whose leads' underplayed oomph bolsters the uneven scenario.
... a pleasing balance between sincerity and irreverence.
Soufra's lasting impression is one of empowerment and the energizing sense of purpose and community that the women derive from the enterprise along with their incomes.
A comic drama that's sometimes appealingly gentle but more often frustratingly amorphous.
Within the story's sometimes too-neat outline, Volpe lets most of her characters breathe.
A clear-eyed film that's clinical in its specifics.
While the movie never soars or burns especially bright, it delivers a modicum of magic without getting pious or gushy.
Its lessons in compassion and self-acceptance are treacle-free, and however movie-shiny the story's world of economic comfort and prep school, those lessons pack a universal punch.

We all like to imagine ourselves as brave resisters. Pomsel's unapologetic account of being "one of the cowards" is a haunting, ever-timely reminder of how easy it can be to cash the paycheck and look the other way.
Just as ambition eclipses the protagonist's judgment, the movie loses its way in an excess of generic story strands.
A haunting documentary that asks urgent questions in this age of extinction crisis.
What might have devolved into cutesy odd-couple territory instead moves in unexpected directions, bolstered by a fundamental idealism.
A movie that's by turns off-putting, bracingly incisive and insufferable.
As Zea's inspired and intimate portrait demonstrates, with an exuberant attention to detail that matches Murray's own, there's an epic sweep to the successful career she carved out.
Shining a light on hospice and palliative care, approaches that are still considered alternative, Defining Hope builds a persuasive case for the ways they empower patients and their loved ones.
The understated performances keep the proceedings involving even when the film draws ultra-obvious parallels between its protagonist's professional maneuvers and his achievement-focused parenting.
This taut drama exists in a timeless noir territory, a world of free-floating dread and dashed hopes where mood supersedes specifics of time and place.
My Friend Dahmer is one of the most disturbing coming-of-age features in memory. But it's also exceptionally moving.
One family's silences and lies unravel before our eyes in the gripping, intimate "Aida's Secrets."
Jewel-bright and heart-wrenching.
Meeting a chimpanzee's gaze, the pioneering researcher says she encountered "a thinking, reasoning personality." With "Jane," we see what she saw.
Covering an eventful artistic season, Jean-Stéphane Bron's "The Paris Opera" is a well-observed vérité portrait of a major cultural institution.
The starry chemistry of leads Ansel Elgort and Chloë Grace Moretz injects a modicum of energy into the coming-of-age drama, whose elements of romance, crime and smart-kid angst never coalesce.

The humor in Holy Air is inseparable from its poignancy, and every element of the film expresses that interconnection, from the performances to the spirited, melancholy-laced score by Habib Shehadeh Hanna.
Through eight years of filming ... the director discovers an everyday American story of extraordinary strength.
And though its dark riches can at moments feel like overload, and its narrative thrust occasionally grows diffuse, the story casts an undeniable spell.
movie_title: Birdboy: The Forgotten Children (Psiconautas, los niños olvidados) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The tonal shifts among mystery, folklore, melodrama and satire are neither smooth nor productively rough, and the narrative core remains unclear, lost amid the surfeit of disconnected moving parts.
A winningly sharp Millennial riff on the greens of summer.
Neither celebrating nor bemoaning its subject, it gazes head-on at the ways some people embrace the chance to live life as a nonstop popularity contest while others are hurt by it.
Gorgeously and at times frustratingly austere, "Hannah" has a simple, compelling premise. But more than that, it has the unparalleled Charlotte Rampling.
Honoring the primacy of language for his characters, Levine deftly reveals the ways they wield it to seduce, attack, manipulate, repress and, occasionally, to communicate.
A lesson in empathy, demonstrating how ground-shifting the simple act of listening can be.

It works mainly in fits and starts, though there's no question that the movie's depiction of the effects of Soviet rule on a nomadic population will be eye-opening for many Western viewers, and deeply resonant for Kazakhstanis.
movie_title: The Road to Mother (Anaga aparar jol) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Sarnet's earthbound fairy tale occupies a dreamscape somewhere between the teeming canvases of Brueghel and the existential agonies of Bela Tarr's films. And it's funny, with a sly salaciousness all its own.
The narrative doesn't quite coalesce, and except for a few late-in-the-proceedings moments, it doesn't deliver the grim, indelible shivers of the best noir.
There's charm and smarts to the healthy positivity, but without the balancing sting of the earlier sections, the intended abracadabra goes up in smoke.
[A] droll, knowing and tender romance - a story that brings a delicate touch to one of the thorniest of life's questions: How do you predict regret?
Though the filmmaker's confidence at times outstrips the execution, his decidedly non-formulaic approach is a refreshing break from the three-act conformity of too many first films.
movie_title: Being Black Enough or (How To Kill A Black Man) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: A day-old news flash of a drama, delivered in weepy headlines posing as dialogue.
[Jason] James' assured timing and visual knack almost mask how strained and half-baked the story is.
Artful and atmospheric to the max, "Never Here" is a study in personality disintegration dressed up as a whodunit.
With its likable characters, local color and cross-cultural sparks, "Signature Move" has unsentimental sweetness and pluck.
Builds a strong sense of emotional urgency as it unfolds against the edge-of-the-world setting of the Reykjanes Peninsula.
Through Tim Curtin's kinetic handheld camerawork, Carpignano immerses the viewer in Pio's experience.
Lewin can't quite transcend the inconsistencies and dwindling credibility of the concept or give the material a driving pulse, even with its race-to-the-deadline setup.

Montiel treats his story's happily unsung oddballs with sincere affection. He doesn't hold them up to ridicule, or insist that they snap out of their quirkiness and conform. But he doesn't quite know what to do with them.
An alluring mystery spun from the joys and perils of collaboration,
The woolly mammoth tusk is just the tip of the iceberg in this haunting excavation.

[Greene's] intense focus on individuals can feel limiting in terms of the overall truth-and-reconciliation dynamic, but it also leads to some powerful moments. And the story's contemporary resonance couldn't be clearer.
An engaging study in glamour and grit.
As stylized as Makridis' second feature is, it's grounded in recognizable behavior, and its sly, dry playfulness reverberates with fascinating questions about emotions and how we portray them.
Flaws notwithstanding, Un Traductor is a sensitive, eye-opening account that could travel widely.
Without pandering to audience sympathy, [Teles] creates an exceptionally sympathetic focal point for a story that embraces the messy tenderness of life as it's lived.
[A] sharp, wise and vibrant ode to female independence ...
A visual treat but a less-than-tantalizing mystery.
This quietly chilling wake-up call is sure to be one of the most vital documentaries to hit theaters in 2018.
Visually striking and memorably intimate.
In some ways the film is guilty of the kind of worship that made Garcia uneasy, but Bar-Lev's emotional connection to his subject is also an animating force.
movie_title: Long Strange Trip: The Untold Story of The Grateful Dead (2017)

movie_review_blurb: As it arrives poised for a megalithic box-office haul, it might be helpful to keep in mind the advice offered by one character: "You cannot stop Ragnarok. Why fight it?"
[An] electrifying cinematic essay that asks us to reconsider a lot more than a maligned species.
The star is up for the challenge, but the high concept quickly unravels.
Whatever its imbalances and flaws, the movie is sure to strike an emotional chord with the book's many fans as well as newcomers to the remarkable tale.
Garcia never gets a grasp on her protagonist's contradictions, or those of her story - certainly not enough to pull off the movie's jaw-dropper of a twist.
movie_title: From the Land of the Moon (Mal de pierres) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: At first the doc feels like a recap as argument, unlikely to galvanize anyone. But through its haunting firsthand accounts, it becomes a wake-up call for people on both sides of the argument.
New-relationship anxiety escalates to dark suspicion -- or is it unhinged paranoia? -- in Ingrid Jungermann's nimble horror-tinged comedy Women Who Kill.

Despite a few playful flourishes, filmmaker Luc Bondy's experiment in artifice never takes flight.
As clunky as the movie can feel, there's a winning toughness to its unsentimental view of childhood and its nostalgia for a pre-digital age.
A spirited testament to the power of creativity - not only as a source of strength and joy, but as a way to access buried emotions.
Though handsomely photographed and featuring a compelling cast, the Ireland-set memory piece ... will leave audiences wondering how much more satisfying the muted drama might be on the page.
An eye-opening look at one couple's response to the dearth of public services, therapies and programs for their son.
McKay demonstrates ... that his gifts as a filmmaker are as vital as ever.
With its sensory immersion in nature and its yearning characters, the gorgeously shot film is a memorable study of solitude and connection.
An eloquent coming-of-age drama set in 1930s Sweden that revolves around a spellbinding performance by young Lene Cecilia Sparrok.
Morrison balances her affection for all the characters with droll naturalism and an assured visual style.
Poignant and visually striking.
movie_title: Don't Come Back from the Moon (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Though the laughs are hit-and-miss, the synapses are always firing.
A vibrant dose of California dreamin'.
Even with the screenplay's sometimes screechy missteps, the Deutch duo hold the screen with charm and intelligence to spare.

With its astute capsule biography of DeMille and firsthand accounts from people who worked with him, the film pays tribute to one of Hollywood's most innovative and commercially successful founding fathers.
movie_title: The Lost City of Cecil B. DeMille (2016)

movie_review_blurb: An illuminating look at a black community's rural realities.

Heisler brings the required neediness to the role, but the key problem with this sometimes whip-smart, sometimes mushy feature is that Jo and her story are far less interesting than some of the people around her.
An intimate and engaging chronicle of her final months with the New York City Ballet.

There's enough dark sizzle between leads Rachel Weisz and Sam Claflin to keep the audience involved through the underpowered middle stretches before the film regains its footing, delivering a disquieting shiver of a conclusion.

A richly imagined tribute to a working-class hero.

Though "The Queen of Spain" looks terrific and features a warm, glamorous performance by Penélope Cruz, that promise is fulfilled only fitfully in this valentine to moviemaking.
movie_title: The Queen of Spain (La reina de España) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The writing and direction of Public Schooled put a bright spin on high-school antics, and the ace cast makes the grade, led by Judy Greer's long-proven down-to-earth magic and the deft physical comedy of Daniel Doheny.

Hardly earth-shattering, but illuminating nonetheless.

Kron calls out Hollywood on its double standard. Yet like many of her subjects, she sees that there's no fighting it; as standup comedian Julie Halston puts it, "Beauty's still the thing that people want most from women."
Insightful and surprisingly intimate.

Throughout Chavela, onscreen translations of lyrics accompany concert clips. A literal understanding of the songs is hardly necessary, though. The emotion in the performance says everything we need to know.
Beneath its quiet surface, the Austin, Texas-set drama "Barracuda" thrums with menace and mystery from first moment to last.
An underpowered, white-bread sermon on the importance of family and faith.

Working again in his native Baltimore, the writer-director maintains the documentary-style feel for place that has infused all his features.

Writer-director Josh Klausner set out to make "a film with a live soundtrack" rather than a conventional musical, and the results have an unforced, DIY charm.
The assured film, immersive and astutely observed, recalls the work of master chronicler Frederick Wiseman ...
The sad truth is that we've heard countless harrowing stories of the Holocaust, and this one, for the most part, isn't presented in a way that makes it indelible or urgent.

As frustrating as The Boy Who Made Shoes for Lizards can be ... it makes quite clear that the man behind a revered international brand is an artist first and foremost. For his ardent admirers, that will probably be a perfect fit.
movie_title: Manolo, The Boy Who Made Shoes For Lizards (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Built for action, like its title character, the movie packs a muscular, bloody punch, but mainly it's a well-oiled diversion.
A mostly satisfying, beautifully acted genre riff.
Following three former Hasidim over a fraught and eventful three-year period, Heidi Ewing and Rachel Grady have made their most powerful and complex film.

From first tentative rehearsals to road trip, you can see where the "let's put on a show" gumption is going. But the newly empowered teenage choreographer and her ragtag troupe ride their own giddy momentum.

An unforgettable collision of hope, faith and desperation.

Stubbornly uninvolving for long stretches, but it can also be stirringly cinematic.

Though the mix of poppy power anthems and Tchaikovsky isn't seamless and the familiar plot points are less than transporting, there's a beating heart to this tween story to match its exuberant dance sequences.

movie_title: RUMBLE: The Indians Who Rocked the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A meandering journey, too tepid to stir up the feelings of yearning and rebellion that it aims to evoke.

movie_review_blurb: Though it may hit a few predictable notes, its embrace of flawed and messy characters and refusal to repair every frayed emotional connection give it a dynamic, in-the-moment vigor.

A film that's admirably comprehensive but disappointingly short on emotional impact.
The period details are so lovingly burnished in this uneven, if heartfelt, feature that for a while they threaten to overpower the story, which delves gently into a rarely explored aspect of the war.
What might have been a snappy short is interminable at feature length, the mayhem-in-suburbia conceit generating few laughs as it stomps along.
Never as tense and gripping as it should be, the incidents and most of the performances too tamped-down to spark a much-needed sense of animating friction.

Colorful locales and exotic spices can't hide its essential blandness.

It's that rare musician's biography with a deep feel for the music. And in Chadwick Boseman, it has a galvanic core, a performance that transcends impersonation and reverberates long after the screen goes dark.

A film of subdued but mounting panic and grief - an unsentimental portrait of poverty in contemporary India and of a benighted man's efforts to understand the world beyond his workaday struggles.
[Director Ryan McGarry's] extraordinary access to life-and-death moments and his illuminating perspective on the medical system make for a powerful viewing experience.
A type of cinematic performance art, with all the self-consciousness that suggests - a sibling love story that's no less heartfelt for being in the form of a first-person poem.
