The Berlin-set tale of an aimless twentysomething is a delightfully unforced comedy with a sure grasp of character and setting.

A certain hirsute fellow in an engineer's cap, the one whose enigmatic kisser graces the Burt's Bees logo, is, it turns out, the real deal. And he's more of a character than any marketing guru could invent.
Remarkably intimate and astute.
Dunne creates a full-blooded character. The film around him, unfortunately, takes low-key to the realm of tepid.
If ever a movie earned the exclamation point in its title, it's Lukas Moodysson's "We Are the Best!"
A few bumpy patches notwithstanding, the new feature is an exquisitely designed, emotionally absorbing work of dark enchantment.
This "Punch" never truly connects.
The ground-level view of New York - high-energy, semi-farcical - avoids clichés while finding its own romantic pulse with Duris' charmer the compelling center of the buoyant and bittersweet storm.
The action is by turns insistently sunny and mawkish.
Audiences will find themselves face to face with their own prejudices, assumptions and, perhaps, squeamishness.
It pulls no punches in its informed outrage against the food industry, zeroing in on the rampant use of sugar and its many multisyllabic variations.
The film's restraint verges on blankness; a mood of desolation builds in this story of the West Memphis Three, but not an involving drama.
It's no polemic, but neither is it as character-driven as it aims to be.
It's a portrait of the artist as a charmingly uncompromising septuagenarian.
What's conspicuously missing is any grasp of the lovers themselves. They suffer and yearn, dance in the moonlight and act out prettily, without benefit of recognizable inner lives.
movie_title: The Disappearance of Eleanor Rigby: Them (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Gets the vision and the grit of the source material but finally feels more like a long trailer than an involving movie.
An exceptional chronicle, its mix of archival material and new interviews bristling with the energy and insight of one of the most important social movements of the 20th century.

Kelly's first narrative feature registers low on the cinematic-oomph scale, the production's low budget sometimes all too evident. Its aim is true, though, and Kathleen Chalfant infuses the lead role with an elegant ferocity.
[A] stuck-in-neutral feature, which combines a vague commentary on Italian politics with a vague portrayal of middle-aged awakening.
Hong Kong director and co-writer Pang Ho-Cheung sends up gender stereotypes and reinforces them in his contemporary yet not quite fresh confection, zeroing in on certain women's girlie wiles.
A film that honors memory without stooping to sentimentalism, tracing Austria's role in the Holocaust through one Jewish family's experience.
The drama that unfolds from that gambit is too tepid to make the perpetrator's redemption, let alone the fulfillment of his artistic vision, anything to root for.
It's an affectionate and admiring collection of moments, but the director's wobbly choreography never locates a dramatic core for this corps' story.
The visual style is plain, uninspired. But the closing chord is hopeful in its open-endedness, and the way it avoids perfect harmony.
Urgent investigative report and unforgettable drama, "Virunga" is a work of heart-wrenching tenderness and heart-stopping suspense.
Though the film's second half could be tighter, the details and atmosphere ring true throughout, especially in the walking-wounded chemistry between Seimetz and Roberts' tentative dreamers.
It's the rare documentary in which truly unpredictable events unfold and no assumption is safe.
The result is a travelogue with self-help bromides, or an Esalen workshop with blisters.
movie_title: Walking The Camino: Six Ways To Santiago (2014)

movie_review_blurb: "Showrunners" is a lively snapshot of the not-always-easy intersection of art and commerce.
movie_title: Showrunners: The Art of Running a TV Show (2014)

movie_review_blurb: With nary a word of narration and only one explanatory onscreen title, at the very end, the hybrid documentary Yakona tells a captivating story through a rich blend of sound and image.
Poppe crafts some powerful scenes that pose questions not easily answered.
As with many stories about children involved in a competitive activity, "Algorithms" is partly a portrait of grown-up hopes channeled through kids.
Though it hasn't the sweep to be greater than the sum of its parts, the movie offers an absorbing mix of melodrama and historical detail.

The way the women occupy Cohen and Plioplyte's spotlight is a lesson in aging well, a lesson that begins with the refusal to play by the rule that says to grow older, especially for women, is to fade into the shadows.

The earnest film's straightforwardness and down-to-earth characters have a gentle appeal, but its tendency to spell out every emotion and theme in on-the-nose dialogue undercuts its potential impact at nearly every turn.
A must for fans of the avant-garde pixie.
Every revelation registers in the gifted Amalric's gaze: infinitesimal physical mutations, emotional detonations.
Exploring economic migration from the point of view of children, "Waiting for August" is an impressive, if muted, debut documentary.
An eye-opening look behind Bali's profile as a tourist Shangri-la.
Polished and ambitious, this crime drama puts a fresh bicultural spin on a retro-style mystery but doesn't quite sustain the suspense.
Dance purists might dismiss Streb's work as circus gymnastics, but a bracing aesthetic is inseparable from the corporal shocks, as is an insistence on challenging accepted constraints.
Hayes hasn't integrated the two threads into a cohesive thesis.
movie_title: Smiling Through the Apocalypse: Esquire in the 60s (2014)

movie_review_blurb: An art-versus-commerce drama that consists of one beautifully aching performance surrounded by a whole lotta twee.
Juliette Lewis and newcomer Jonny Weston bring terrific sensitivity to their roles.
Carmine Gaeta and Luke Davies' screenplay is constructed from plot mechanics, and the emotional stakes grow less convincing with every twist of the screw.
Intimate and affectionate ...
"Next Goal Wins" is an irresistible underdog story - sports-fan credentials not required.
Richard Ray Perez's documentary concerns the myth more than the man.
Part of the unpredictable pleasure of "Bible Quiz" is its unanswered questions.
The actors' unforced chemistry defies the artifice. Olmos' delectable hamminess and Hamilton's unfussy performance convey volumes. Ross, guarded and resilient, is a revelation.

Alan Polsky and Gabriel Polsky propel the material in a way that can feel over-determined. But they grasp the eccentricities and desperation of fringe dwellers, and at its strongest their atmospheric film has the pull of a sad outlaw song.
"Billy and Buddy" manages to maintain the kind of brisk giddiness that many animated films struggle to achieve.
Like the ungainly avian creatures at the center of the herky-jerky adventure, this 'toon seldom gets off the ground.
This is the straightforward story of a family facing adversity head-on and making inroads against a rare disease.
Williams' alarm is balanced by his measured observation of a group of twentysomethings from the Kansas City-based International House of Prayer.
Cody has concocted a modern-day "Alice Through the Looking Glass," with none of the danger or wit.
Mam's camera work is exquisite in its immediacy and agility.
Even with Adam Scott, Richard Jenkins, Catherine O'Hara, Jane Lynch and Amy Poehler on board, the results are regrettably forgettable.
It is Weigert's performance that gives the film its mystery and charge. Playing seriously with identity, she draws the viewer ever closer. The way she never reveals everything is electrifying.
The film is a welcome exploration of practical and philosophical matters seldom broached across the partisan divide.
As engaging and unpretentious as its subjects, the Manhattan couple who became unlikely benefactors of Washington, D.C.'s National Gallery of Art.

An exhilarating vérité work by first-timer Manuel von Stürler, the documentary follows this seasonal migration, or transhumance, with a sense of quiet awe and intimacy, capturing the feel of cold rain, deep snow and the comforting heat of a campfire.
Centering on a desperate-to-wed flight attendant, this rom-com gets little mileage from its harebrained premise.
If the material lacks a distinctive flavor profile, its restraint is its strength. The focus on a woman's passionate hard work without need of marital-status back story is refreshing.
The film charts no new territory but is terrifically cast and, like its source novel, long on atmosphere.
A work that gestures toward depths without truly plumbing them.
At the film's heart is a fitful conversation that unfolds like a string of koans, epigrams, jokes and silences. And songs.
The movie's poems are unambiguous rants, delivered with theatrical ferocity. On-the-nose dialogue propels its lessons in self-respect.
Like many a biopic before it, "Winnie Mandela" shoehorns an exceptional life into the standard template of a highlights reel, lurching from one Important Moment to the next.
White's film is a love letter not just to Kelly and the Beatles, but also to postwar working-class Liverpool.
Glimpses of the relationship's dynamics can't overcome the missing sense of how these two first connected, an increasingly problematic void at the movie's core.
[An] erratic blend of not-quite satire and halfhearted soul searching.
[A] video game posing as a movie, a preposterously plotted kidnapping story starring a high-performance Mustang.
Barbeau-Lavalette builds a persuasive sensory immediacy in "Inch'Allah," even as her story grows increasingly contrived.
Miller's film is a work of emotional reserve, eschewing psychological explanation in favor of unadorned observation - of human behavior as well as nature and the still lifes of the domestic world.
Not just an affectionate portrait of a gifted athlete-turned-groundbreaking sportscaster, the film is also a fond remembrance of life in New York City from the 1930s through the '70s.
A timely snapshot of aspirational glitz in the big city. Oh, the youthful ambition. Oh, the designer outfits.
Inventively surreal virtues mark Maya Vitkova's ambitious debut feature as the arrival of a bracing cinematic talent.
The archival clips are eye-opening, and the animation, with its lovely subdued palette, is alive with the pains, joys and rascal spirit of childhood.
movie_title: Couleur de peau: Miel (Approved for Adoption) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: An awkward mix of B-movie crime saga and social-issue drama.
A compellingly unconventional, elliptical sports documentary that explores the mysterious realm of might-have-been.
A cheerfully unsettling exploration of mainstream representations of male homosexuality.

Even with such fine actors as Fionnula Flanagan and Stephen Rea in the ensemble, the Spanish-Irish co-production is a flavorless affair that has all the bite of a dining room-bound episode of "The Love Boat."
A documentary that doesn't force-feed its message of hope but genuinely earns it.
The film owes whatever persuasiveness it has to the teen leads' sharp performances - their sisterly chemistry and their filial friction with an alcohol-addled mother, well played by Mira Sorvino.
One of the strongest films yet from Jim Jarmusch.
Busts a few minor moves, but not as light on its feet as it wants to be.
The central characters' coupledom might bring them a safe haven, but audiences will be left out in the cold.
For all their obvious differences, the bond between affable Tom and laser-intense Matt reveals itself in ways both subtle and profound.
A bracingly romantic drama that's alive with a mature sense of passion and mystery.
There's nothing to be found in the forced, lifeless drama that unfolds ...
Emmanuelle Bercot's agreeably ambling feature celebrates the inimitable Deneuve-ness of her leading lady, whose character, Bettie, appears in every scene.
Brown achieves his desired retro aesthetic, and in the golden setting - the ranch country and oil fields of southern Montana - he finds a strong character in its own right.
As Wolf traces youth culture from 1904 through the atomic blasts ending World War II - from factory drudges to sacrificed soldiers - he gives form to a ghost in the machine of the modern nation.
Even with star Shailene Woodley delivering the requisite toughness and magnetism, the clunky result is almost unrelentingly grim.
The title character of "Honey" is a fascinating and complex figure, and Jasmine Trinca inhabits the role with a detached intensity that's thoroughly compelling.
Firth enters new territory with style and grace, anchoring a smart, high-energy movie that eventually runs out of steam.
A solid cinematic turn for the Nancy Drew of the new millennium, sure to delight crowdfunding backers and other fans of the source series.
Stephen Chow's dazzling comic fantasy about a gentle Buddhist demon hunter.
The movie has the taut efficiency of a well-constructed crime thriller, while its real-world underpinnings play out with a less convincing sense of urgency.
With the perseverance of a field anthropologist and the eye of a poet, documentarian Jessica Oreck traces a year of seasons in the stunning "Aatsinki: The Story of Arctic Cowboys."
movie_title: Aatsinki: The Story Of Arctic Cowboys (2014)

movie_review_blurb: In terms of character and plot, not one element of the intended wild ride escapes self-consciousness or becomes the least bit involving.
A film rich in atmosphere but emotionally as blunt as its title.
More of a foolish plod than a weightless rollick.
Adapting his TV series of the same name for this big-screen spinoff, Chen has an appealing visual style and deploys a sharp ensemble.
In smaller, sharper doses, the frenetic testosterone shtick of these baby-faced blusterers might have worked better.
Grounding may have healed Kroschel's aches and pains, but it didn't give him the clarity to make a coherent documentary on the subject.
Intended dramatic grit lands more squarely in the realm of after-school special.

Mordaunt doesn't always succeed at balancing the sentimental, the political and the ethnographic, but at its strongest the story is a seamless melding of history's dark undertow and a child's indefatigable optimism.
The central drama never fully engages, but the jolts that "Banshee" delivers are check-the-locks scary.

It's debatable whether the best love stories are also the "weirdest," as Emile Hirsch's character declares in "Twice Born." But they do require chemistry, the missing piece in his pairing with Penélope Cruz.
As it zigs and zags, its plot unravels rather than tightens, and its curveball of an ending is bound to leave audiences feeling as double-crossed as some of the characters.

Even as the directors stumble, including testimonial-type interviews that feel like an infomercial for Keating's Contemplative Outreach program, his deep affinity with nature comes through, as does his humor.
movie_title: Thomas Keating: A Rising Tide Of Silence (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It's a letdown that the film itself, written by Patrick Tobin and directed by Daniel Barnz, doesn't take half the chances its leading lady does and is content to paddle around the shallows rather than plunge into the deep end.

Nimbly avoiding the excesses of melodrama and the recessiveness of mumblecore, Chan and his likably low-key cast navigate hairpin turns from drama to comedy to outright farce with an impressive sense of proportion.
The fluency of Mann's direction and the slow-burn chemistry between Chris Hemsworth and Tang Wei counterbalance the more ordinary, and not always involving, procedural elements.
What begins as an intriguing psychological thriller devolves ... growing less interesting as it proceeds and giving costars Dakota Fanning and Theo James little to do.
Though it's not entirely satisfying, the loose-limbed feature exerts a genial pull in its offhand exuberance.
Though clearly a labor of love, the documentary is repetitive and preachy. The filmmakers' intermittent commentary, in particular, has the off-putting effect of mini lectures.
Despite a surfeit of talking-head commentary, the film has a strong feel for the emotion behind Frank Morgan's acclaimed bebop.
movie_title: Sound of Redemption: The Frank Morgan Story (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Through dynamic use of archival footage and intimate new interviews with Ellis' friends and family - all of them founts of down-home sincerity - Finlay unearths a fascinating biography filled with reversals, comebacks and false starts.
movie_title: Orion: The Man Who Would Be King (2015)

movie_review_blurb: An accessible look at an important topic: the medicine that ails us.

Chris Zylka and Riley Keough ignite a convincing spark as lovers who dream of wider horizons. Even so, their fateful course unwinds less than persuasively, the vivid sense of place not enough to bring the one-last-heist setup fully to life.
Filmmaker Su Rynard never loses sight of the winged tunesters' sheer beauty, or their emotional and symbolic pull.
Even as Vallot goes over the same ground, her compassionate and discerning eye for detail makes for engaging and often delightful viewing.
Distractingly lovely to look at, the film can't make Sangaile's struggles or triumphs matter.
Irreverent homespun Zen gives this doc zing.
movie_title: The Barkley Marathons: The Race That Eats Its Young (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A story that frames a familiar conflict - the collision of modernity and tradition - in intriguingly off-center ways, alive with piercing detail.

Whether you call it a hybrid, an origin story, a prequel, spinoff or "regeneration," the stitched-together monster mashup that is Victor Frankenstein is in one sense a perfect specimen: It exemplifies the more-is-less school of moviemaking.

It can be both as gripping and as lacking in nuance as its predecessor, and though it often feels more like a highly polished TV procedural than a transporting cinematic experience, it's a solid genre outing with unsettling topical resonance.

Trey Edward Shults is hardly the first filmmaker to use the all-American Thanksgiving get-together to expose family anxieties. But with Krisha, his extraordinary debut feature, he brings a bracing originality to a familiar setup.
In an age glutted with digital images, the documentary Frame by Frame is a bracing tribute to the power of photojournalism.
Her wit comes through, often entwined with a biting sadness.
This Isn't Funny is insightful and quick-witted, a romance that take chances while its lovers learn to do the same.
It ends on a note of fluidity and grace that makes you wish it had been told with fewer frenetic rampages and less forced whimsy.

Searching and earnest, Schenck rights the film when it stumbles. As someone who's fully present and in the moment, he's the antithesis of the shouting heads who dominate public debate and a fascinating film subject.
If the film's mix of factoids and poetic longing can sometimes feel clunky, Journey to Space finds a smart balance between idealism and pragmatism.
Director Patricia Riggen finds a rigorous and affecting visual language for The 33, but she and her international cast are hampered by a screenplay that too often gets in the way of a powerful story.
Leslee Udwin's documentary about the December 2012 crime is in many ways a hopeful portrait, focusing not just on the attack but on the ensuing protests and policy changes.
A movie that's constructed almost entirely of empty clichés about suburban ennui.
Using Bronx locations and a strong cast of Caribbean-Latino actors, director Henry Barrial constructs a convincing portrait of a neighborhood and its Nuyorican culture.

But Hanks wisely limits the celebrity talking heads in this rise-and-fall story. Instead, he focuses on the people who built the company from a Sacramento drugstore annex to a global brand, creating a ragtag family in the process.
movie_title: All Things Must Pass: The Rise and Fall of Tower Records (2015)

movie_review_blurb: [A] handsomely shot, sometimes harrowing doc.
It's an act of defiance that's also a sublime piece of cinema, and it ranks among the director's finest work.
A feet-on-the-ground fantasy with a nicely underplayed comic tone, Well Wishes is part road trip, part romance and part starting-over fable.

A strong sense of place emerges, if not a consuming narrative, as the filmmaker strains to connect a 1970s coming-of-age story to historical records and bigger thematic arcs - namely, bloodlines and bloodshed in a rural community.
Naz & Maalik unfolds with a youthful vitality, bolstered by the charm of its lead actors.

In subject and style, it's a departure from [Jude's] contemporary satires, but the period story is evidence of the same keen eye for class hierarchy, codified cruelty and the limits of self-deception.

Is marital fidelity possible when you're bohemian, French and a character in a Philippe Garrel movie? Offering further evidence to the contrary is the director's latest broody musing on life, art and l'amour.
An uneven but charmingly earnest fictionalized account of Assaf's rise through the ranks of hopefuls on the reality contest "Arab Idol."
Dramatically and technically, Warcraft gives the concept of "hybrid" new punch.
Far too much of this high-gloss tearjerker proceeds as a by-the-numbers romantic fantasy, nudging the viewer every step of the way.
Likable performers and novel storyline notwithstanding, the comic drama stumbles, leaving audiences with unsatisfying answers to its magic-tinged mystery.
A vibrant, affecting piece of filmmaking that's sure to widen Hesse's following.
"Sunset Song" ... falls short of the intended cumulative effect, its emotional power undercut by its studied, episodic unfolding.
A clunky composite of visual extravagance and Hollywood commonplaces about a life well lived.
In its genial, low-key way, the film ... is a chilling account of cyberbullying, perpetrated on a disturbingly wide scale over many years.
It's a compelling introduction for Akerman novitiates while offering fresh insights to devotees.
movie_title: I Don't Belong Anywhere - Le cinéma de Chantal Akerman (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The focus on the way individuals adapt to and defy custom is one of the smartest aspects of the film.
"Francofonia" is a love letter to France and the Louvre, but it's also a harrowing reminder that not all cultures have been held in such high esteem.
Two compelling performances anchor the Israeli drama Wedding Doll.

Call it "civil war" or call it brand extension; call it a "cinematic universe" or a corporate behemoth - the latest Marvel extravaganza furthers the studio's cross-pollination of action franchises in a way that's sure to satisfy devotees.
Applause offers no softening euphemisms -- but plenty of sharp humor -- in its depiction of a gifted artist struggling to reform herself as she rages against the vulnerabilities of middle age.
At first feels like a bizarre exercise in conjecture or a brainstorming session for fiction writers, but it turns into a provocative and moving philosophical inquiry.
movie_title: The Visit: An Alien Encounter (The Visit) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Its sentimentality is tempered by the elegant restraint of the fine lead performances.
With his coiled, jumpy intensity, Paradot - a carpentry student making his acting debut - is thoroughly convincing, provoking scorn as much as sympathy.
The lively MLB-produced doc's choice archival material and full roster of new interviews will delight fans, both as a warm-up to the 2016 season and beyond.
Like most of the indispensable Jia's work, this triptych film, which jumps from 1999 to 2014 and then to 2025, is intimately engaged in the push-pull between tradition and progress.
movie_title: Mountains May Depart (Shan he gu ren) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The harrowing medical crisis that drives the family story gives it the nonreligious urgency to preach beyond the choir. So too does Jennifer Garner's down-to-earth lead performance.
Hauck's first feature can be suffocating. This narrative puzzle should be more fun than it is.

It's a sinuous tale shaped by the writer-director's favorite motifs - animism and medicine - and by sideways glances at the myths, religious traditions and political convulsions of his native Thailand.
A fully involving drama about the new rules of engagement.
It's too bad that a movie so lovingly steeped in music hasn't more rhythm and flow.
movie_title: Una Vida: A Fable Of Music And The Mind (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Suitably low-key but sometimes under-realized, this drama is fueled by its working-class milieu and a heart-wrenching performance by Hill Harper.

The gentle drama A Country Called Home is in sync with its small-town Texas setting. Unfortunately, much of it is also as flat as the terrain, despite the efforts of an engaging cast led by Imogen Poots.
This road is lined with clichés and blunt dialogue, the emotional shifts all too neatly underlined by Death Cab for Cutie tracks.
What Maddin & Co. have invented here ranges from Freudian horror to childish naughtiness.
Director Jean-François Pouliot isn't afraid of stillness or silence or painful moments, even as he whips up plenty of goofy stuff too.
What begins intriguingly rests increasingly on manufactured suspense.
Beneath the well-worn dysfunctional-family setup are bracing observations of the human coping mechanism.
A documentary whose visual magnificence is more than matched by unforgettable characters and political urgency.
Gillespie isn't able to conjure a stirring cinematic experience. The pieces don't fuse so much as fit together, and much of the action feels instructive rather than immersive.
It's a film with a cause, but it's also brimming with drama in the midst of jaw-dropping landscapes.
Though the story is drawn in broad strokes and overloaded with melodrama, director Mat Whitecross' exuberant feature understands the communal joy and personal necessity of rock 'n' roll.
First-time director Daniel Duran, working from a screenplay by Oscar Torres that abounds in the maudlin and risible, isn't able to lift the ham-handed material to a place where it might ring true.
Chris Messina's "Alex of Venice" is as much a love letter to the Los Angeles neighborhood as it is a well-observed drama.

Despite its clumsiness, the film conveys the melding of modern and ancient, sensuous and sacred: On the one hand the foodie-fave Ramen Burger, on the other a chef's paean to the "rhythm" of a bowl of ramen.

Reece Ritchie brings heart to the lead role, particularly in the decisive solo performance that caps the film. But that sequence is as expressive and alive as the rest of the supposedly movement-loving drama is static.
At its exhilarating best, it's a gritty and lyrical portrait of lives that are too messy and tender to be summed up in consumer-centric notions of the Millennial generation.

Though the comic confection's clunky moments keep it from achieving soufflé delicacy, its bright zingers and seamless fantasy sequences amp the playfulness, and the mostly unforced performances complement the production's cartoonish exuberance.
Patino's flights of high-flown language are both tasty and distracting; Dern, in ultra-crusty mode, makes the most of a crucial tirade. If only anything felt at stake in this story's dark spiral.
The two young female leads, exceptionally well cast, deliver strong performances, and the drama benefits from Weber's interest in understanding rather than demonizing the bully.
The overwrought plot mechanics are exasperating, but the lead actresses' exquisitely modulated performances get under the skin.
A film that begins as a languorous study in grieving and shifts with screeching abruptness into a crime thriller.

Even with breathless chases, strong design components and dazzling effects, the story's organizing principle -- the faction system that divides society into five groups based on personality -- grows less compelling as Insurgent proceeds.

The wan drama is enlivened by bursts of black comedy, some bits more effective than others, and though it ultimately disappoints, there's promise in the understated creepiness of Riley Stearns' debut feature.

The setting is striking, the cast impressive. But "Two Men in Town," a drama that's built on dread and circles the question of redemption for a newly released prisoner, falls short of the mythic territory it aspires to.
None of it is quite satisfying, especially when old-age makeup takes center stage.
movie_title: In the Name of My Daughter (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Immersive in ways that not many movies can claim, Humpback Whales is a prime example of the power of large-format documentaries to educate, delight and inspire.
Its central pair of unlikely allies will engage young audiences' sympathy. They're smartly played by Mae Whitman and Robbie Amell, whose warmth and comic chops keep the movie buoyant.
Neither screenwriter Anthony Di Pietro or director Tim McCann ("Desolation Angels") has a sure grasp of this uneasy mix of nature and nurture.

Aiming to please, the filmmakers submit without hesitation to the bold yet hokey source material, with leads Jamie Dornan and Dakota Johnson breathing a crucial third dimension into cutout characters.
Though naggingly simplistic in its historical scope, the film offers a fascinating chronicle of the 1948 Arab-Israeli war through the eyes of a daring group of men.

Watching lifelong friends, clearly destined for each other, miss the romantic boat over and over is entertaining at first, but soon their tortuous and silly road to the inevitable provokes only impatience.
Though his dramatic performance is somewhat too mild, classical-pop violinist David Garrett brings an electrifying musical authenticity to the lead role in "The Devil's Violinist."
Chief among its pluses is the low-key warmth of leads Martin Starr and Dina Shihabi.
Anyone with the slightest allergy to emo-tinged millennial attitudinizing should steer clear.
Nothing if not a mood piece, but amid its atmospherics and winking asides, it's also a fascinating portrait of a relationship.
As torrid affairs-gone-wrong go, this one's not juicy enough and way too predictable.
A meandering, if pleasant, excursion.
Despite its clunkier elements, Matsueda's screenplay is alert to details that ground the film in the day-to-day lives of young people who are American in every way but technically.
An intriguing premise never finds a dramatic pulse in "The Keeping Room," a self-consciously artsy depiction of female grit during the final days of the Civil War.
The haves and the wanna-haves mingle, anxious and wary, in Paolo Virzi's sharply observed Human Capital.
A lucid and important work of advocacy journalism. It illuminates yet another way that mainstream medicine thrives on crisis rather than health.
Whether director Gianni Amelio is aiming for emotional effect or social commentary, his fuzzy detours into melodrama land well off the mark.

"An Honest Liar" isn't simply a career recap or a fond portrait; the movie takes exhilarating turns as directors Justin Weinstein and Tyler Measom follow present-day developments in Randi's personal life.
If Aloha's earthbound elements are uneven, its rocket-launch aspects are downright confounding.
Like the young social activists at its center, the documentary "Radicalized" is propelled by a ragged energy, a fuel that's equal parts outrage and idealism.
There's no denying the beauty of the film's imagery, violent and tender, or the emotional power of the final moment in the boy-and-his-dog love story.
Though the leads lend charm and comic timing to the unpersuasive material, it would take a ground-up rewrite to make the fate of their characters matter.
A Sinner in Mecca is a suitably messy mix of the gritty and the surreal, the wrenching and the transcendent, from the midst of the trek to Islam's holiest site.

With a gripping performance by Gaby Hoffmann... the first feature by its writer-director is a winningly unsettling genre exercise whose style and polish belie the constraints of its microbudgeted five-day shoot.
Low-key but overly schematic.
A plodding feature that makes ample use of the legal record as well as evocative Shreveport locations while leaving the well of affecting drama untapped.
Even with its well-observed moments, the movie's nonmusical interactions, whether reaching for laughs or poignancy, too often feel flat and forced.
For all his tormented free-thinking, the protagonist never comes into focus.
Sophie Deraspe's film is a compelling anatomy of an Internet hoax - one that grabbed headlines amid the revolutionary fervor of the Arab Spring.
movie_title: A Gay Girl in Damascus: The Amina Profile (2015)

movie_review_blurb: If their story feels more like a dramatized argument than an involving drama, that's no fault of the lovely, unforced performances by Cobie Smulders and newcomer Gail Bean.
Clunky elements aside, the film's distillation of firsthand testimony and archival material has haunting implications.
Williams delivers a performance of mannered, sometimes heart-wrenching restraint. But something closer to cautiousness tamps down the film.
The insights about tech-enabled disconnections are hardly earth-shattering, but the nuanced performances find the emotional truth in every pixelated gaze.
[A] charming but surprisingly soft-focus movie ...
Donald Margulies' screenplay distills Lipsky's material in a way that's both tender and incisive. It gets the quasi-friendship between journalist and subject in a way that few films do.
Filmmaker Hanna Polak, working over 14 years, has created a chronicle not easily forgotten.
A playful paean to a movie genre and a prolific career, Ernest Borgnine's valedictory feature is a spaghetti western with a heavy helping of cheese.
movie_title: The Man Who Shook the Hand of Vicente Fernandez (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The story comes to life only fitfully, even with - or perhaps because of - its court intrigue and supporting characters both hissable (Helen McCrory as André's wife) and flamboyant (Stanley Tucci as the king's bisexual brother).
Though the lead performance would do Lassie and Rin Tin Tin proud, the increasingly ludicrous, cliché-packed plot generates not an ounce of suspense.
The faux press conferences and perverse inventions (SurvivaBall, anyone?) that are included here highlight corporate greed and governmental shortsightedness as shrewdly as ever.
Though the film is choppily told and its episodic rhythm never gathers momentum, it contains well-observed moments and astute performances by Mark Ruffalo and Zoe Saldana.
Lindstrom draws effective, understated performances from his cast, letting insecurities and betrayals break through the surface of laid-back celebration.
movie_title: How We Got Away With It (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The film is an exploration of art as a way through immense and complex emotions.
A film whose subject transcends time and place. It's a lesson in Buddhism disguised as a romantic pas de deux - or maybe vice versa.
From its look to its episodic rhythm, the movie plays like a compressed Season 9 - a season that has its moments but wouldn't rank among the show's finest.
It's a performance that gets the writhing interplay of transparency and opacity in a character who has gone beyond the deep end of unhinged narcissism and self-dramatization.
At its most provocative, it suggests a tension between spirit and flesh in the nun's maternal feelings. Rather than examine that friction, Améris pushes the narrative in predictable directions.
The film will restore one's faith in humanity, at least during its running time.
Fans of "Madame Bovary" might enjoy the chance to nod knowingly at references to the novel, but that's not enough to sustain a feature ...
Gemma Bovery is a mashup of Flaubert and a tired, outdated sex farce.
Peter Cousens' mawkish Freedom is an apologia for the white Christian people who helped slaves escape, or at least wrote songs to make them feel better.
The picture is upfront about being a sequel, but it may play better for those who aren't attached to the original film.
While it has the trappings of a mainstream rom-com, it largely refuses to follow that template.

Lok, are we comfortable yet saying that Kristen Stewart has the potential to be one of the best actresses of her generation? Because she may well become one of the best actresses of her generation. And Bincohe still ain't a slouch, either.
Both the re-creations and the interviews themselves are filmed for maximum spookiness.
Queen of Earthsurrounds Elisabeth Moss's mesmerizing performance with an actual movie, a low-key homage to Euro-horror films - complete with an appropriately thrumming and discordant score.

Not to suggest that cigarette smoking or petty crime is cool, but is it possible to have a cooler entrance than that of Ah Tze and Ah Bing, first seen robbing a blue-lit phone booth on a rainy night in Taipei, cigarettes dangling from their lips?
This is a revenge picture unlike any other, less a straightforward narrative than a meditation on retaining agency in a world determined to take it away. The feelings in Felt run deep.
Shot in chilly, wintry tones, Closer to God can be seen as a cautionary tale about the dangers of unfettered progress.

Aside from that dumb, dumb name, Terminator: Gensisys is far less offensive than it could be, and Taylor keeps the action brisk and linear, maintaining a clear sense of geography often lacking from modern blow-'em-up films.
Rickman keeps the tone fluffy and occasionally self-aware, and even more so than most costume dramas, you always get the feeling that everyone's playing dress-up.
[Marieme] has a long road into the seemingly inescapable marginalization of poor young black women ahead of her. But Girlhood offers some hope that the fleeting moments remain.
Hopefully Dying to Know will help to rehabilitate the image of hallucinogens from being just the domain of hippies and Burners.
movie_title: Dying To Know: Ram Dass & Timothy Leary (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Effie Gray is powerful enough on its own merits.

A largely faithful adaptation of a 1958 Robert A. Heinlein short story, Michael and Peter Spierig's Predestination is a time-travel yarn that worked fine as a 13-page read, but as a film the time-bendy elements come across as sub-Primer at best.
Though it's not just for Who fans, those well-versed in the band will enjoy picking out some of the more obscure, copyright-friendly songs used in the appropriately loud soundtrack.
Spike Lee's Da Sweet Blood of Jesus is a loving adaptation of Bill Gunn's 1973 Ganja & Hess.
A classic story told in a very brutal and beautiful way.
The 100 Year-Old Man Who Climbed Out the Window and Disappeared is gleefully amoral, never more so than when ruminating on how families are formed.
movie_title: The 100-Year-Old Man Who Climbed Out the Window and Disappeared (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A mostly engrossing meditation on the bravery of being out of range.
The terrific film captures, among other things, the terror of trying to get back into the dating scene when you don't really fit into any scene.

It all boils down to Kikuchi's mesmerizing performance as the wounded, desperate Kumiko. Deep down, she may know the treasure is not real, but she can't face a world in which it isn't. And that's life, pretty much.
The Sisterhood of Night actually holds enough interesting ideas for several movies, but they aren't always well served by Waechter's flashy, hyperkinetic style.
The accompanying visuals are largely archival footage, but more effective are the contemporaneous, patriotic war songs juxtaposed with the men's descriptions of the atrocities they witnessed.

He's a passive hero, mostly getting buffeted along by events and people beyond his control. But '71 is no less of a deadly game of cat and mouse for that, focusing more on the other players in this very bad night.
There's no way to make material like this light or funny, but Lost and Love is particularly bleak.

Thankfully, the more interesting drama of the aftermath is intact, including Jacqueline Bisset's performance as Devereaux's wife, Simone, channeling a righteous anger not seen since Beatrice Straight in Network.
Danny Tedesco's joyous documentary The Wrecking Crew is a personal, heartfelt tribute to those unsung heroes.
Not only is the hero a smart, brave 7th-grade girl but she's also an immigrant from Barbados, and a self-described nerd who got an A in geometry. She's even a cat owner. Well done, DreamWorks.
Prediger and Weixler are clearly talented, and hopefully have much more cohesive (and funny) work ahead of them.
There's an inevitability to the proceedings which turns out to be not so inevitable after all, particularly in the final act, when the seemingly one-note Shulem is given unexpected depth.

Though it's very funny at times, the satire isn't quite as sharp as it wants to be, occasionally feeling more like an improv sketch expanded to feature-length. But for that, it's still more entertaining than most extended-sketch movies.
movie_title: What We Do In The Shadows (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Trumbo works as a history lesson about the Hollywood Blacklist, but less so as a satisfying movie, falling prey to the standard trap of trying to fit too many decades into one feature film.
Fascinating documentary about the feminist movement of the late 1960s and early 1970s.
Steve Martino's wonderful The Peanuts Movie is a loving tribute not only to the original comic strips and cartoons, but to the man who created the franchise, Charles "Sparky" Schulz.
László Nemes's Son of Saul is the stuff of nightmares. (That's a compliment.)
The Nightingale doesn't aspire to be much more than a heartwarming road movie through rural China, and at that, it succeeds admirably.
movie_title: The Nightingale (Ye Ying - Le promeneur d'oiseau) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: One of the joys of Japanese cinema is how it not only wholeheartedly embraces genres, but also happily mixes them up.
Most troublingly, images of Nazis in modern Ukraine in What Our Fathers Did: A Nazi Legacy suggests that not being able to acknowledge that history paves the way for it to happen again.
movie_title: What Our Fathers Did: A Nazi Legacy (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Anderson's dreamy documentary Heart of a Dog is one of her more outwardly accessible works, and also one of the best movies of the year.
Peggy Guggenheim: Art Addictis a portrait of a woman who just hung in there and did her thing... though it doesn't shy away from her less positive tendencies.
Although set in an insular culture,Very Semi-Serious makes the experiences of the struggling cartoonists universal to anyone who tries to do anything creative.
If elements of it seem overly familiar now, that's only because they were done first here, and picked up by every heist film that followed.
The Wonders is a slice of a particular kind of sedentary life, and a consideration of the universal desire to find out what one's purpose is in the world. Especially if it doesn't involve bees.
The meaning of what's happening on screen at any given moment is less important than the texture and the joy of experiencing it.
A mostly satisfying two-hander that never quite lives up to its full potential.

Patricio Guzmán's gorgeous documentary The Pearl Button is in a class with the other beauty-of-nature reveries like Koyannisqatsi and Baraka, but with its political overtones delivered via somber narration.
movie_title: The Pearl Button (El botón de nácar) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Its subject had such a short life and career. This allows for tighter storytelling 45 years on, and tragic as her death at 27 was, it ultimately feels appropriate that Janis burned out before she could fade away.
Some of the ideas of Bikes vs. Cars have merit, but many... have a noticeable whiff of able-ism, and the film pays only minor lip service to people for whom biking everywhere always is not an option.
A fascinating character study.

Tension between the city and the country has been a fertile topic for as long as there've been cities, and Alê Abreu's phantasmagoric The Boy and the World explores the eternal conflict in a familiar yet wholly original way.
movie_title: Boy and the World (O Menino e o Mundo) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The second feature film based on the long-running animated series, Paul Tibbitt's The SpongeBob Movie: Sponge Out of Water is actually much better than it looks.
movie_title: The SpongeBob Movie: Sponge Out of Water (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Black Sea is an expertly crafted genre exercise.
Xavier Dolan's Mommy is an endurance test even by the standards of miserablist drama.
Paul King's Paddington is a very British movie, and that's mostly good, though it briefly succumbs to the sort of lazy humor that derailed the equally Anglo Boxtrolls.
Thomas Cailley's Love at First Fight is a French romantic comedy that's a good thing for a change, instead feeling more like a charming YA novel.
Loud, fluffy, and rather unsatisfying.
Red Army keeps a light tone even when dealing with serious issues, and is chock-full of great stock footage.
It's both an important part of Ghibli's history and a gem in its own right.
In Jackson Heights is a work by that rarest of creatures: someone with an unbridled love for humanity.

There are some lovely compositions both indoors and outdoors (including a use of split-screen), but Every Thing Will Be Fine still lacks the poetry or even fundamental interest of the film of his it most closely resembles, Paris, Texas.
Of the canonical films, it's the first in which the humans actually behave and talk like recognizable people.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Everything in the existing version ofHitchcock/Truffautis gold, to be sure, but there are still riches left in the vein.
Sorrentino still has a knack for framing his constantly lovely images like he's shooting a Cinerama travelogue, and they demand to be seen on as big a screen as possible.
There's a core of a good idea here, but the film itself is pale and anemic.
Deniz Gamze Ergüven's debut film Mustang is an often-harrowing look at the subjugation of girls in present-day Turkey as they're groomed to become "proper" women.

Band of Robbers is full of deep references to the books, but also stands on its own as a fresh and occasionally touching take on the "overambitious young schmucks decide to do some crimes and get in over their heads."
The timing of Josh Kriegman and Elyse Steinberg's you-are-there documentary Weiner couldn't be better.
A lovely portrait of three disparate women learning to work through grief and disappointment, and how sometimes it's healthier for wounds to stay open.
It's clearly artificial, but it generates an emotional response. Sergei Eisenstein himself would have approved.
I Saw the Light is pretty, slick, and empty -- three words that don't describe its subject.
Xavier Giannoli's 127-minute comedy Marguerite would have worked like gangbusters at a zippy 90 minutes, but it's a pleasant enough comedy-of-manners for most of its running time.

Take Me to the River is Picnic at Hanging Rock-level cagey about its central mysteries, and while many of its characters know what happened off-screen in both the recent and distant past, they ain't sharing the details with us, just their pain.
The film's tone is all over the map, with weird bursts of casual racism toward its ethnic supporting cast and unnecessarily explicit sex scenes that approach a The Room level of ickiness.
Cheadle is a delight to watch, and by and large, Miles Ahead can be described as his Miles Davis fan fiction.

The meditative Sweet Bean is veteran director Kawase's first film to receive domestic theatrical distribution -- probably because arthouse audiences love them some food porn -- and the real eye candy is the many close-ups of simmering beans.
Ye gods, do French directors love filming nude and nubile young women, even if their characters don't care about what's under the flesh.
movie_title: My Golden Days (Trois Souvenirs De Ma Jeunesse) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Call it superficial, but I call it irrefutable: Life is a runway, and Andrew Rossi's documentary The FirstMonday in Maymakes a strong case for fashion - that oft-demonized form of expression - as an art form.
Gotta hand it to Asghar Farhadi: When he promises fireworks in the title of Fireworks Wednesday, he delivers, both literally and figuratively.

As French-language films about efforts to rehabilitate violent yet hunky blonde juvenile delinquents go, Emmanuelle Bercot's muddled Standing Tall is at least less irritating and fetishistic than Xavier Dolan's Mommy.

The picture follows both the development of the project as well as the audience as they were guided through it, and it's significant it was an event meant to be enjoyed by the general public, and not just wasted on Burners.
Brown makes it clear that what happened to Lakshmi is not her fault - and more importantly, she's never passive, taking her fate into her own hands.

Beth Harrington's lovely documentary The Winding Stream traces the history of the original Carter Family singers -- Maybelle Carter, her cousin Sara, and Sara's husband A.P.-- and their influence on American music.

Many references in My Big Night will likely fly over the heads of those not conversant in Spanish pop culture, such as the unknown-to-Americans superstar Raphael riffing on his own image, but it's goofy fun regardless.
Much like its underserved title characters, the picture never fulfills its potential.
A moody and riveting study of loss.

As studies in female depression go, I Smile Back is less satisfying as a cohesive film than the recent Kumiko, The Treasure Hunter, but Silverman's vanity-free performance is a treasure in its own right.

The three main female characters are little more than caricatures (sexy girlfriend, shrewish authority figure, and flouncy eye candy) who only relate to the men, and the film's final 20 seconds are undeserved at best.
The unquestionably uplifting Dark Horse is halfway to being a narrative film as it is, re-creating many scenes both profoundly emotional and deeply silly.
Unlike certain recent Hong Kong movies that got bogged down in moralizing... Kill Zone 2 delivers the goods in this post-Raid environment.
One of the two very smart things that the film does is to keep the original 1975 setting, as the story would have been altered far too much to be set in the digital age.
Viva doesn't say anything new, but what it says isn't bad, either.
City of Gold isn't quite as mouth-watering as other recent foodie documentaries such as The Search for General Tso or Deli Man, which may speak more to this writer's own palate than anything else.
Phantom of the Theatre is still a fast-paced and agreeably silly horror movie and showbiz satire for the most part, even if it pulls its punches at the end.
If the story is familiar, it's only because it's been used in centuries of Chinese fiction beforehand and countless movies since.
The woo about Gaia and such makes even the occasional hard science sound suspect, and questionable statements like people going to parks after 9/11 as proof of the healing power of nature don't help.
Jonathan Pryce is always great, but Jerome Holder is a real find, displaying a charisma reminiscent of the similarly unknown John Boyega in Attack the Block.
What's most impressive is the access Sokurov and his camera got to the great works of the Louvre, thus allowing a closer look than we're ever likely to get in person.
Exactly what Valley of Love is setting out to accomplish is unclear, but anything that gets Isabelle Huppert back on American screens is a good thing.
Damn if Jonathan Hua Lang Lim's Pali Road isn't hardcore Lifetime material. That's a compliment, because those can be good, pulpy fun.

Bull is David Cronenberg's Crash set in the world of Brazilian rodeo - not just in the way that both the bipeds and the cattle live in cramped conditions, but also the sheer amount of sex and nudity that occur in very close proximity to the animals.

It's a beautifully shot film, and Oona Laurence evokes 1970s Jodie Foster, which is appropriate considering that it's exactly the kind of role Foster would have crushed back in the day. Hopefully, Laurence will turn out as well.

Shults does indeed display some giftedness on a visual level, keeping his limited locations interesting with numerous camera tricks and movements. But as calling cards go, Krisha should have remained a short.

Creative Control is shot in glorious black-and-white, which always makes New York look better and also complements the vector-graphic aesthetic of the glasses nicely. But the film's most important innovation is the use of Reggie Watts.
Raman Hui's Monster Hunt is a kid-friendly adventure fantasy that may be too slowly paced for its target demographic.
Combines two popular indie genres (Sad Bastard and Low-Budget Crime) without ever quite becoming its own thing.
A less artful version of A Pigeon Sat on a Branch Reflecting on Existence - though it may help to be Romanian.
Yen is appropriately soulful as the aging Ip - while Tyson is just terrible, and thus fascinating to watch.
Violent, profane, and frequently hilarious.
Both a charming British comedy and a remarkably insightful examination of what it means to be a nonfiction writer.
I was prepared to be let down, but it's damn good, continuing to fulfill the promise first shown by [My Little Pony: Equestria Girls - Rainbow Rocks].
movie_title: My Little Pony Equestria Girls: Friendship Games (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Because it's made by people who understand the importance of a clever script and want their audience to have fun, Lazer Team may just prove to be 2016's most entertaining superhero movie.
Rampling has racked up award nominations and wins for her performance, and rightfully so.
The Golden Dream is by no means an action film, but it has plenty of impressive stuntwork.
movie_title: The Golden Dream (La Jaula De Oro) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Buoyed by the performances of Pine and Affleck as working-class schlubs who aren't heroes, just men doing their very difficult job.
A charming and very mid-2010s coming-out comedy.
Many filmmakers have tried in recent years, but few have nailed the elusive formula of the two-hander romantic comedy quite like Emily Ting with Already Tomorrow in Hong Kong.
Where to Invade Next is everything right-wingers (as well as some leftists) hate about Moore, though as always, the truth is probably somewhere in between. Or a little left of the center, anyway.
Southbound is that rarest of creatures: a satisfying horror anthology film.
It's in the little moments that Bergman shines, a woman unafraid to follow her own path in both word and deed.
movie_title: Ingrid Bergman in Her Own Words (Jag är Ingrid) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Alternately witty and moody.
A touching remembrance of people using technology to do the right thing.
Dawn Porter's Trapped is a sobering look at the impact of anti-abortion legislation in the South.
Knight of Cups is Malick at his most Malick-y, and it's OK if that's not your thing.
Jia Zhangke's Mountains May Depart is one of those bighearted melodramas that mainland China does so well.
movie_title: Mountains May Depart (Shan he gu ren) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: There's potential for a fun horror movie with Phil Wurtzel's A Haunting in Cawdor, but the end result is as uninspired as its title.
Arturo Ripstein's Bleak Street lives up to its name, being a beautifully shot but ultimately unsatisfying exercise in miserablism.
movie_title: Bleak Street (La calle de la amargura) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: An all-too-rare example of steampunk done right - which also acknowledges that, however pretty such industrial imagery might seem from afar, actually living in such a world would be kind of horrible.
movie_title: April and the Extraordinary World (Avril et le monde truqué) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Requiem for the American Dream is valuable as a document of Chomsky while we still have him, but the people he's inspired may be his true legacy.
In addition to being a crowd-pleasing Disney cartoon, Byron Howard and Rich Moore's Zootopia works as both a nifty detective story and a parable on institutionalized racism.
The Boy and the Beast works with many common anime tropes but doesn't find anything new to say about them.
movie_title: The Boy And The Beast (Bakemono No Ko) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The journey is, of course, more important than the destination, and both of Embrace of the Serpent's trips are worth taking.
movie_title: Embrace Of The Serpent (El Abrazo De La Serpiente) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The Last Man on the Moon is a reminder that while there were no bigger heroes in the 1960s than the Apollo astronauts, they were still flawed men who had to come back down to earth.
movie_title: The Last Man On The Moon (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Larraín gives the film a hazy, somewhat overexposed look, and makes generous use of both Passion of Joan of Arc-style close-ups and Arvo Pärt's Fratres, which provides the sole comfort in a film in which solace is a myth.
A pattern seems to be emerging as Tobias Lindholm follows up A Hijacking with the equally direct and unsentimental A War, another examination of men under heavy stress.
The Wave wants only to be big, dumb, Hollywood-style entertainment. On that level, it succeeds - even if a disaster movie cliché drinking game would lead to alcohol poisoning. (You have been warned.)

Novice actor Hwietat is terrific in the lead role, and even if we go in knowing the historical backstory, we still discover it all from his point of view - and never stop wondering how the wolf will survive.
While New Jerusalem's rigid formalism will surely be off-putting to some, there's beauty to be found in the film's sheen of placid grime.

While we're still pretending that True Detective season 2 didn't happen, we have Alberto Rodríguez's thriller Marshland to satisfy our yearning for moody detectives investigating a disturbing case that shakes their faith in humanity.
It's ultimately yet another movie about fathers and sons who need to learn how to hug. That's a theme which could stand to go extinct for a few years.

Not that May-December romances can't be compelling, but it's hard to root for a guy in his forties to find the courage to make time with a barely legal girl, no matter how dissatisfied he is with his life.
We're free to imagine what might have been, and in doing so, Jodorowsky's Dune is fun, occasionally mind-blowing hooey.
It's no Melancholia, but Lars is still playing with his toys.
Frankie & Alice is lurid - again, she's a stripper - and occasionally silly in the way that so many multiple-personality stories wind up being.
Goodbye World's two story tones never quite mesh.
The fact that Mark Levinson's engrossing Particle Fever was edited by the great Walter Murch gives it a better pedigree than most documentaries.
Though he's not for all tastes, there's something admirable about Wayans's willingness to do anything for a laugh, often reminiscent of Jerry Lewis at his most frantic.
Bad Johnson is probably the most thoughtful movie possible about a penis that takes human form.
Legends of Oz: Dorothy's Return fails to make us care about the characters or their journeys, and the animation is shoddy and occasionally creepy ...
The moving I Am I presents a refreshing spin on both the amnesia and daddy issues genres.
Snowpiercer is one of those rare modern action movies that keeps the audience guessing...it's packed with fascinating ideas and presents a fully fleshed-out universe.
One of the best family films to come down the pike this year, and not just because this year has also brought us The Nut Job and Legends of Oz: Dorothy's Return.
Yves Saint Laurent is at its best when Yves indulges in all the hedonism the 60s and 70s have to offer. Just like real life, movies these days could use more hedonism.
A beautiful, subtle horror movie about the rigors of old age, made all the more horrifying because it will happen to all of us fortunate enough to live a long life.
The tone is generally light, the bickering goblins make a boffo comedy team, and while there's a recurring fart joke, it borders on classy. That's the power of good anime.
The story is fairly straightforward, and, more importantly, so is much of the action.
Notably, the original story was called "The Tale of the Bamboo Cutter," but Takahata's title puts the focus where it belongs.
movie_title: The Tale of the Princess Kaguya (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Everything that can go wrong does, and while it has its moments, Miguel Arteta's comedy relies too much on gender-shaming and emasculation jokes.
movie_title: Alexander and the Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Day (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A perfectly pleasant pastiche of other movies, the most obvious antecedent being the Toy Story films.
For the faithful, Rainbow Rocks does, in fact, rock.
movie_title: My Little Pony: Equestria Girls - Rainbow Rocks (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Ultimately, Advanced Style presents these women not as objects of curiosity, but as what they truly are: role models.
God Help the Girl's second-act showstopper "Musician, Please Take Heed" probably won't become a "Let It Go"-level cultural phenomenon, but it very much deserves to be.
Like burlesque itself, Exposed is at its best when it shows rather than tells.
Thunder and the House of Magic is That Touching Cat Chase Cartoon You've Been Looking For
movie_title: Thunder and the House of Magic (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Viewers looking for a shoot-em-up will be disappointed, but those hankering for an old-school Italian broodfest will find plenty to soak in.
If witnessing Takei and Brad exchanging vows doesn't bring a tear to your eye, you're either heartless, or you're William Shatner.
Moebius is almost weird enough to be a creation myth, and that's no small accomplishment.
A frequently absorbing miserablist family drama shot in appropriately chilly winter tones ...
Daniel Kraus' absorbing documentary The Kill Team demonstrates how badly trying to do the right thing can backfire.
There's little in Slugterra: Return of the Elementals to interest nonfans of the show, and the sheer laziness would be more forgivable if not for the equally lazy use of broad ethnic stereotypes.
Yoshiura keeps the story fairly linear, while playing with perspective and composing many stunning, vertiginous images that consider the different possibilities of being at war with gravity.
If Citizenfour ends abruptly, that's only because the real-life story is still far from over.
The Face of Love becomes a study of a woman gradually losing her grip on reality, thanks to the universe playing a seriously dirty trick on her.
Billy Kent's charming HairBrained comes from a long legacy of collegiate comedies but still finds its own identity.
Unfortunately, Agyness Deyn's acting chops aren't quite up to the task of carrying Sunset Song.
A celebration of (and cautionary tale about) personal and political freedom.
It's the latest from Teletubbies distributor Kenn Viselman, described in the film's promo material as a "marketing maverick." Sure, why not?
movie_title: The Oogieloves in The Big Balloon Adventure (2012)

movie_review_blurb: There's no consistent theme to the seven segments other than "starring famous people," hence the wink-wink title.
The film succeeds thanks to Lillard's clear affection for the material and on the strength of its performances, especially Billy Campbell as Troy's conflicted father.
Looks at the marriage battle waged by Maine voters.
The Mystical Laws is an (un)holy mess, a religious tract masquerading as a paint-by-numbers hero's journey.
Although its message is never subtle, Delhi Safari is fun enough to earn the right to preach.
[A] lively, challenging documentary ...
The film packs in more characters, subplots, and moments of nostalgic detail than it can gracefully accommodate, and the pacing often feels rushed.
Does it even qualify as a movie? Why did it take two people to write and cost $2.5 million to make?
The Bitter Buddha is very funny, and for all its bitterness, Eddie Pepitone's comedy is a taste that's easy to acquire.
A sometimes uncomfortably intimate portrait of a man who seems unsure if he has a place left in the culture he helped to shape.
[Feels] like a Bergman homage without earning the clunky label "Bergmanesque."

A story that probably could have been told better as a miniseries, the film's main strength is its performances.
What was very funny in print becomes serious and occasionally dour onscreen, with fewer laughs than you would expect from a Sedaris project.
While you may not walk away fully grokking the subprime market or securitization, you'll get a sense that Paulson probably was the best person to deal with a very bad situation.

The Pretty One has a more gruesome premise than most body-switching comedies, but also more heart, mostly due to Zoe Kazan's expressive, vulnerable performance.
The Lego Movie is exactly what its title promises, a kid-pleasing movie comprised of CGI renditions of the titular interlocking plastic bricks.
Hints of the opposing forces at work include a curious subplot about the need for the rule of law (take that, Kim Jong-Un!) nestling uncomfortably against the fart jokes.
A shaggy dog story but an intriguing and frequently beautiful one.
One of the best science fiction movies in years.
It's either much smarter and more profound than it's letting on, or it doesn't add up to anything at all. Or maybe both - it's all relative.
The young cast holds their own, though Megan Mullally as Tanner's best friend's mother steals all her scenes.
Even if the story is faithful to the way the events played out in real life - and the official description is that the picture is a "dramatic retelling" - Life of a King couldn't feel more formulaic.
Dumbbells manages to be pleasant and largely inoffensive despite early indications that it might turn into a T&A-fest.

Not without interest, and ... a pleasant enough way to spend two hours if you're not looking to be surprised.

movie_review_blurb: While it helps to already be a fan, it's imaginative and energetic enough to be entertaining for the uninitiated.
[A] very funny and thoughtful take on how straights often objectify queers - and how increased visibility in the media can result in an expectation to conform to stereotypes.
Is there any small town in America with its name printed on the side of its water tower that isn't going through tough times right now?
The movie eventually goes into Woody Allen territory in the best way possible.
Any film justifies its existence when it gives Katey Sagal a chance to sing.

In his first feature-length picture since 2003, director Ringo Lam he seems more concerned with philosophizing about the damaging effects of money and greed than he is in delivering an entertaining action picture.
The introduction of British agent Ilsa Faust (Rebecca Ferguson) to the mix suggests that this may be one of the only ongoing spy concerns that actually know how to use female characters.
In case you thought that bad people weren't still doing bad things in Africa, Hubert Sauper's disturbing documentary We Come as Friends will disabuse you of that notion tout de suite.
Park Heung-sik's Memories of the Sword is a historical Korean action film that delivers plenty of what its title promises.
The picture really belongs to the fantastic Regina Casé, who finds the humanity in her put-upon character even as she's giving terrible advice to her daughter.
movie_title: The Second Mother (Que Horas Ela Volta?) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The picture never rises above being a polemic.

Rosenwald does veer into hagiography, and there's a sense his darker moments are glossed over, but the good works he did should be celebrated, and they're all the more meaningful now that the Voting Rights Act is under attack.
Leave it to the French to get transgender representation (mostly) right.
For all its big emotions, the low-key Coming Home is a less a melodrama than a mellow drama.
Anthony Lucero's terrific East Side Sushi is hardcore sushi porn, but it's also funny and uplifting.
Green has deeper ambitions, eschewing procedural survival-in-the-wilderness material for a strong focus on character.
Depressing, grim, dark, and compulsively watchable.
movie_title: A Pigeon Sat on a Branch Reflecting on Existence (2015)

movie_review_blurb: [It] succeeds where so many other horror-comedies fail by remembering to be funny first and shocking second. Having a tasty script helps, too.
It's a buddy comedy in which women get to behave as badly as men usually get to. That right there - that's progress.
The Black Panthers: Vanguard of the Revolution covers all the important bases, while also suggesting other places for future documentarians to go.
movie_title: The Black Panthers: Vanguard Of The Revolution (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Carberry and Tweel never condescend to their hella-Southern subjects. And that's why Finders Keepers gives them a leg to stand on.
The Keeping Room is dark and violent and ends on an ambiguous note, but so did the Civil War and, arguably, the era of Westerns.
Sebastián Silva's Nasty Baby declares its button-pushing intentions right on its in-your-face title screen, but it actually ends up having a surprising amount of heart.
Kvetch if you must about how everyone's recording everything all the time now, but in Jafar Panahi's Taxi, that technology becomes a new definition of freedom.
Though there are some light sci-fi elements, the story remains largely grounded and based in the real world, focusing on the characters rather than the spectacle.
It's a beautifully directed film, no question, but also a glacially paced one, with performances that often give the impression that the cast chugged Robitussin before the cameras rolled.
Indeed,Experimenter often feels like an Errol Morris documentary, and though it never quite answers why humans are capable of such inhumanity to one another, neither could Milgram.

The picture belongs to Cate Blanchett's Mary Mapes, as she endures a very public scrutiny of both her gender and her politics, particularly at a time when "liberal" and "feminist" were treated as four-letter words.
A Borrowed Identity borrows from various genres without finding one of its own.
By the end, it's hard not to look forward to the sequel it promises.

For all its brutality, darkness, and ruminations about how a higher power can allow such things to happen, Beasts of No Nation is also leavened with intentional humor, and a stunning central performance by newcomer Attah.
3 Still Standing does a good job of surveying how the comedy scene has changed over the decades.
Labyrinth of Lies is fascinating enough in its procedural aspect -- including many scenes in the American-run SS records rooms -- even as it meanders in its third act.
Robert Zemeckis's The Walk is as breathtaking as you'd hope a film about a man walking on a wire between the World Trade Center Towers to be.
The Final Girls plays with the tropes of the slasher genre as much as its PG-13 rating will allow, and the final showdown is a thing of beauty, but it never attempts to be scary or menacing.
Carberry and Tweel never condescend to their hella-Southern subjects. And that's why Finders Keepers gives them a leg to stand on.
From a technical point of view, there's no question that Sebastian Schipper's Victoria is an astonishing achievement.
It's a matter of public record that Dunn was convicted of first-degree murder in October 2014, but that makes 3 1/2 Minutes, 10 Bullets no less suspenseful, and certainly no less heartbreaking.
Sophie Deraspe's fascinating, frequently infuriating documentary A Gay Girl in Damascus: The Amina Profile is a prime example of Why We Can't Have Nice Things.
movie_title: A Gay Girl in Damascus: The Amina Profile (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Shot in glorious black-and-white, Alonso Ruiz Palacios' Güeros follows the indie-slacker template to the letter, but it ultimately meanders too much for its own good.
Amy S. Weber's heart-wrenching A Girl Like Her begins by solving one mystery while posing another.
Blethyn is wonderful as an all-too-rare character, a middle-aged woman who holds her own in a position of authority over violent men.
Nobody gets away clean, as the saying goes, but having money sure helps, especially if you know how much a human life is worth.
A violent yet agreeably goofy throwback to the survival-in-the-woods genre, with shades of Southern Comfort, Deliverance, and even The Blair Witch Project.
The important thing is that San Fransokyo is everything San Francisco should be.
Even if hits like 'Wichita Lineman' or 'Rhinestone Cowboy' are not among your jams, it's impossible to not get swept up by the emotions on display.
O'Hara and Attie never judge the players, letting their words and actions speak, though those actions are often intercut with footage from the real war.
A throwback to the character-driven New York crime films of the 1970s, aided in no small part by being filmed in areas of Brooklyn that don't look like they've changed much in the past 40 years.
Elegiac, beautifully shot ...
The most interesting parts of The Battle of the Five Armies wind up being table-setting for The Lord of the Rings (hi, Galadriel!).
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The picture is beautifully rendered in pencils and watercolors, with some CG, giving it an appropriately timeless storybook look, even though it's set in a mostly modern world of buses and 3-D glasses.
This teen comedy manages to be worthwhile on its own merits.
Blancanieves is fun, funny, and beautiful to look at, with a genuinely surprising and moving ending.
As compelling as an individual thread or scene might be, the picture as a whole lacks forward momentum, as is often the case with films with asynchronous timelines.

The leading man of Jeremy Saulnier's mesmerizing Blue Ruin is not the kind of actor who usually gets to anchor a motion picture, let alone a violent revenge picture, and that's part of what makes the movie work.
Michael Beach Nichols and Christopher K. Walker's often chilling documentary Welcome to Leith tells how a particularly low-IQ group of neo-Nazis attempted to take over the tiny hamlet of Leith, N.D.
With the retirement of producer Hayao Miyazaki, Studio Ghibli has put production on hold; When Marnie Was There may well be its last feature film. If so, it's a strong note to leave on.
Jackie & Ryan is a sort of low-rent Nicholas Sparks romance that, for want of a better way to put it, never generates any sparks of its own.
Ardor is essentially George Stevens' Shane set in wettest Argentina, with the distractingly handsome Gael García Bernal in the Alan Ladd role.

While it's tempting to read a deeper subtext into this story of a desperately unhappy man trying to claw his way out of his stifling life, the undercurrent of melancholy always informed [Williams'] performances.
Every aspect of the intensely private man's life is laid bare in a way that straddles the line between celebratory and mercenary.
The 74-minutePlastic Manbecomes that rarest of works: a documentary that could stand to be longer.
movie_title: Plastic Man, The Artful Life Of Jerry Ross Barrish (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The photography is of course lovely (if you make an un-lovely documentary about climbing, you're doing it wrong).
People Places Thingsdoes leave some threads unresolved at the end, but then again, so does life.
It's ultimately less a Hitchcockian and more a Malickian mash-up, which is a genre that should totally exist.
One of the best films of the year.
movie_title: The Diary Of A Teenage Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: While the score goes out of its way to make his every action feel sinister, the picture doesn't fulfill its horrific potential until the third act.

The Seventh Dwarf's female characters are deplorably retrograde on both the script and design levels; they have little to do except be rescued, and Snow White is a vain, buxom sexpot whom the dwarfs leer at.
Twinsters is a heartwarming true story that might not have happened without social media, so score one for modern technology.

Jones and Connolly have terrific chemistry, particularly as Lottie works through the fact that adults encourage dishonesty and lying when it suits their own needs, and that secrets are more pervasive than openness.
movie_title: What We Did on Our Holiday (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Since there are giraffes in Parisian zoos, there necessarily had to be a first one, and Rémi Bezançon and Jean-Christophe Lie's Zarafa is a beautifully animated and often moving telling of how it arrived there in the early 1800s.

In Stereo is not without its merits, but it doesn't really get going until the last ten minutes, which play like the opening of a movie that would be much more interesting than the one that preceded them.
Dolan is capable of making not only a genre film, but one that clocks in under two hours, even with his usual languid pace.
Steve Hoover's documentary Almost Holy is a chilling look at just how not-good things got (and remained) in Ukraine after the Soviet Union collapsed.
The Incident commits to its premise, stranding its characters in their personal hells for 35 years, going deep into the minutiae of how they survive and what it does to their bodies and their brains.

Assaf's 2013 Arab Idol victory occurred around the time the campaign in this week's Weiner began, and both are recent period pieces about how the media can influence politics, for good and ill. The Idol ends on a far more hopeful note, to put it mildly.
While it's all gloriously bats--- in that uniquely Jodorowskian way, the picture ends with quite possibly the most unapologetically heart-on-sleeve climax in the old coot's canon.
It's as handsomely mounted as any of its more beloved brethren, especially in a shiny new 4k restoration, but it's no mystery why it was largely ignored back in the day.
Chances are, we'll being seeing more indie films like Gillian Robespierre's Landline set in the pre-smartphone-and-social-media era.
Stubbornly refusing to choose a hero or even a single point of view, Vida de Familia contemplates which side is indeed greener -- and if happiness is truly a thing.
A serious contender for the best film of 2017, the only way to watch Dave McCary's Brigsby Bear is the way it was made: with a completely open heart.
The triangle of Alejandra, Ángel, and Fabián would be enough for most films... but in The Untamed, as in life, an alien tentacle-monster makes everything better.
Person to Person's performances are engaging throughout. It even earns its end-titles dance party, which is something else you don't see every day.
Kogonada shoots it all lovingly, mostly in locked-down medium and wide two-shots; the camera seldom moves, closeups are used sparingly but effectively, and it's all set to a shimmery, ambient score.
The resulting film is what The Kid Stays in the Picture might have been like if Robert Evans had lacked his driving ambition and peaked with Rosemary's Baby.
It's still worth the trip, but only just.
Marjorie Prime is ultimately more about its ideas than its characters, but that's OK, because they're fascinating ideas.
