Gook is a movie that's very aware of its history, both good and bad.
It finds the emotional truth of its cartoony premise. Also, cats rule and dogs drool.
There are now fewer than 200 left n North America. Sure, it's not exactly at the top of the list of what's wrong with the world, but Deli Man makes a strong case that they're worth preserving.

Klaus Härö's The Fencer straddles the line between the inspirational sports coach and postwar intrigue genres, and while it isn't a tournament-winning example of either form, it has a steady stance and hits most of the expected targets.
The Salvation is a gorgeous-looking western with no other aims than being a gorgeous-looking western.
In the end, Jean Boenish is the real hero of Sunshine Superman.
But if you can't find happiness either on a beautiful but frequently lethal beach or a bustling but grim Berlin, where can you? Futuro Beach doesn't know, either.
Director Chan doesn't skimp on the hand-to-hand, foot-to-face, and occasional sword-to-shoulder action.
Heaven Adores You means to celebrate Smith's life, not his death.
Don't Think I've Forgotten: Cambodia's Lost Rock and Roll takes a broader look at the country's music culture before the encroachment of the Vietnam War, and the subsequent genocide under Pol Pot.
movie_title: Don't Think I've Forgotten: Cambodia's Lost Rock And Roll (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Nguyen's film does deserve credit for not only not shying away from its subject's darker moments, but addressing them head-on in the first act.
Among other things, Noah Baumbach's very funny While We're Young is a rumination on the Long Tail, the theory that pop culture remains accessible long after it's originally created.
Storywise, MC: TCOK is mostly underwhelming.
movie_title: Marie Curie: The Courage of Knowledge (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The question of whether Dominic Graf's costume drama romance Beloved Sisters needs to be three hours long is an academic one on many levels.
The focus is ultimately on Sasha and Paige's friendship, and how Paige's successes cause Sasha to reflect on her own failures, though being queer is not among them; it's just who she is.
Moore's performance as a well-to-do woman stricken with Alzheimer's before her time redeems Richard Glatzer and Wash Westmoreland's cringe-drama Still Alice.
The Search for General Tso is also a history of the Chinese immigrant experience in America, as the way into the hearts of xenophobic white Americans was through their stomachs.
Marc Brener's The Rumperbutts is a well-meaning musical-fantasy that never quite comes to life.
Jauja will be off-putting to some, but for those willing to get on its challenging wavelength, it's worth the ride.
Few things are more entertaining than Stewart playing to the cheap seats, and since most of us will probably never get to see him in a live performance, Match may be the next best thing.
5 Flights Up pairs up Diane Keaton and Morgan Freeman at long last, though it's not quite the revelation it should be.
Magician is a good primer for those who are unfamiliar with Welles, while functioning as a greatest-hits reel for students of the man.
movie_title: Magician: The Astonishing Life and Work of Orson Welles (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The town's history would be interesting even if not for the films that were buried there, but that particular motherlode of frozen motion pictures makes it all the more so.
Like formalistic whimsy, self-indulgence is tricky to get right, and Abel and Gordon do.
The film suffers from pacing problems and an unfortunate usage of its female lead.
"Happy" may not be the word for Finding Oscar's ending, but "tearful" certainly is.
In the end, everyone involved in I Called Him Morgan seems sad but not surprised by the tragic turn of events. Which is life, pretty much.

The Happiest Day in the Life of Olli Mäki is a portrait of a man who is ultimately a nurturer rather than a destroyer - in spite of punching people for a living - and it's one of the best films of the year.
movie_title: The Happiest Day in the Life of Olli Mäki (Hymyilevä mies) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Nobody plays barely maintained sanity like Malek, it's fun to spot all the unintentional Mr. Robot parallels, and those unfamiliar with the show might be inspired to check it out.
A Quiet Passion ... contains one of the best scenes of 2017, as Dickinson chews out her newspaper's publisher for altering the punctuation of her highly stylized words.
The film suffers from pacing problems and an unfortunate usage of its female lead.

Obit's stealth hero is Jeff Roth, keeper of the Times' archive of clippings and photographs. It's appropriately called "the morgue," and a movie consisting only of Roth going through the drawers would be no less fascinating.

One Week and a Day juggles tones deftly, finding the humor in the fact that no matter your pain, the world keeps turning, birds keep pooping on your windshield, and burial plots go to whoever fills out the paperwork first.
movie_title: One Week and a Day (Shavua ve Yom) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Bang! The Bert Berns Story isn't one of the more essential boomer-nostalgia docs, but it hits the target more often than not.

Lieberman looks at the broader picture of how it happened and how the current generation of Cambodians move past their parents' lingering trauma - clinically diagnosed as baksbat, or "broken courage" - and make a better world for themselves.
movie_title: Angkor Awakens: A Portrait of Cambodia (2017)

movie_review_blurb: There are worse places to be not entirely sane.
It still has the spirit of a Wright production, and that's a standard to which all violent comedies should aspire.
One of the more touching of [the] stories finds poetry in the fact that you're never more than 20 minutes from water in this town. (Hunh.)

The Commune may look like a Danish take on The Ice Storm, and while it does share themes of upper-middle-class types experimenting with the loosened sexual mores of the 1970s, it zigs just when you'd expect it to zag.
If Wakefield is a bit overlong, it also ends at exactly the right moment.

In its study of a famously tubby alpha male and how his wife helped him through one of the most difficult parts of his career, Churchill has echoes of Hitchcock - the movie, not the movie director's style - though it's a much better picture.
Don't even think about laughing, you bad person.
The Ornithologist undercuts its carefully constructed world in its final minutes, but up through the moment when the moon turns red as blood, it's a mesmerizing journey.
As grief-porn goes, The Sea washes up closer to Every Thing Will Be Fine than Louder Than Bombs.
When he passes, we shall not look upon his like again.
For viewing pleasure, it's hard to beat the verbal sparring between the avuncular Meaney and a more-Wormtail-than-Wormtail Spall.
Zaradasht Ahmed's documentary Nowhere to Hide is a you-are-there gut-punch about Iraq after the American military's 2011 withdrawal.
The picture resembles the recent 100 Streets, though it could have used some of that film's unabashed soapiness.
Frédéric Mermoud's Moka is a revenge potboiler that never quite boils while you're watching it.

Cate Blanchett plays 13 unconnected characters in wildly disparate situations who shout, whisper, and otherwise recite both famous and not-so-famous manifestos, including those by Fluxus, Dogme 9 -- yay! -- and the Dadaists.

Although Ana Lily Amirpour's new The Bad Batch has much higher production values, her A Girl Walks Home Alone at Night is a tough act to follow, and Batch is a bit of a letdown even if you haven't seen Amirpour's stellar debut.
The Women's Balcony is an equally hilarious and infuriating look at how patriarchies attempt to assert themselves and how terrified men often get when women stand up for themselves.
The well-worn plot is ultimately not as important as the simpler, moment-to-moment pleasures of hanging out with Elliott.
Abacus: Small Enough to Jail works as both a true-life legal thriller and a portrait of a tight-knit community under a tone-deaf siege.

Corbett Redford's Turn It Around: The Story of East Bay Punk takes 153 minutes to tell the story of a music scene famous for jamming econo, it's also reasonable - because it's a story that might go untold otherwise.
movie_title: Turn It Around: The Story of East Bay Punk (2017)

movie_review_blurb: While there there's a lot of hugging along the way, damn if every hug isn't earned.
Though it will mostly appeal to fans of Lynch and/or modern art, everyone can appreciate a harrowing story involving his college roommate Peter Wolf - later of the J. Geils Band.
Lacking a third act, Buzzard is less of a complete story than a slow-motion car crash, but then again, there are few things more fascinating than car crashes.
Wray and his signature song are the launching pad for Catherine Bainbridge and Alfonso Maiorana's essential documentary Rumble: The Indians Who Rocked the World.
movie_title: RUMBLE: The Indians Who Rocked the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: James Franco's very funny The Disaster Artist is possibly the best narrative film about an outsider filmmaker since Tim Burton's Ed Wood, and it's anchored by three wise choices.
Aside from the roving Nazi gangs and officious bureaucrats, Helsinki is an otherwise pleasant place where rockabilly music is never too far off, and the director's humanism shines through.
movie_title: The Other Side of Hope (Toivon tuolla puolen) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Shadowman's attempts to deify him as being a brave hero who colored outside the lines or whatever in the denouement rings false.
Birdboy: The Forgotten Children is its own unique, damaged creature.
movie_title: Birdboy: The Forgotten Children (Psiconautas, los niños olvidados) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: [The] official synopsis assures us that "Elio's sophistication and intellectual gifts suggest he is already a fully-fledged adult," which neither jibes with the on-screen character nor makes up for the fact that Oliver is clearly a solid decade older.
Held together by a deliciously ominous score by Gemma Thompson and striking b&w cinematography, Along for the Ride isn't the final word on Dennis Hopper, but it's a fun trip.
Whew! ... The Last Jedi thankfully returns to the tone of fun, adventure, and especially camaraderie that J.J. Abrams established so well in The Force Awakens.
Director Sono is too strong a visual stylist to let unfamiliarity with the deeper cultural meanings prevent any enjoyment of his frequently eye-popping audacity.
The Greatest Showman is an entertaining trifle.
There are many meaningful lines in Craig Gillespie's self-aware and very funny biopic.
At a lean 90 minutes, Quest never drags, but it's also begging to be extended into that update of An American Family which, for some reason, has never materialized.
Happy End flirts with using Eve as a point-of-view character but never really commits to it, mostly because it never quite commits to any perspective or rhythm.
Intent to Destroy may not inspire many people to watch The Promise - which is currently streamable on Amazon - but at least The Promise allowed Intent to Destroy to be made.
In the Fade lives and dies by Kruger's ferocious, fearless performance of a woman driven out of the light by the darkness of others. And her descent could happen to any of us.

In a speech toward the end of The Final Year, Obama muses that while history zigs and zags, "the trendlines, ultimately, will be in the direction of a less violent, more empathetic, more generous world." If only it were so.

The ... roteness can perhaps be chalked up to Small Town Crime's fancying itself a throwback to gritty 1970s detective movies, including a score that's an homage to Lalo Schifrin. But it's set in the present, and there are off-putting moments throughout.
What it lacks in narrative structure, it makes up for with a brisk 67-minute running time and the knowledge it's all authentic.
Leaning does not require familiarity with the previous film or Goldsworthy's ephemeral work to be enjoyed.
It doesn't quite work, and that Submission fails the Bechdel Test hard probably goes without saying.
With a few tweaks here and there, it could easily be taken for an entirely made-up documentary about a made-up person. It's not, but both his Beuys and Beuys hit many archetypal beats.
When you're the best at having an aesthetically pleasing face, it can make it all the more difficult to be taken seriously in other departments.
Unfortunately, the very talky Have a Nice Day is never as compelling as it could be due to the limited animation.
movie_title: Have a Nice Day (Hao Ji Le) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: There's untapped potential ... which feels like it was reverse-engineered from the disturbing imagery of a scene that takes the ingestion of indigestible hair to its logical conclusion, and the movie ends when its third act should be starting.

[Thelma] features one of the best horror-movie tropes: the second-act research scene in which the protagonist tries to figure out what's going on. No movie can be all bad with one of those scenes, and Thelma's already pretty good.
The Party never drags, instead reveling in a strong cast that's well-directed. Sometimes the greatest pleasures are the simplest.
Ozon is fascinated with themes of gender roles and sexual dynamics - much like Hitchcock and De Palma - but without their underlying misogyny and/or homophobia, so it's a perfect match.
Hamoud's entirely live-action picture shows a society that allows women more freedom, but which only makes the pitfalls and hypocrisies stand out more.
Despite the extensive digital work in the environments, Early Man's character animation still retains Park's signature handmade feel.
Vega gives a stunning, at times emotionally raw performance in A Fantastic Woman, and Lelio tells the story with an uncommon amount of compassion.
As befits a director whose IMDB picture looks like he wants to beat you up, Mom and Dad indulges in some truly tired stereotypes of Black and Chinese people.
At two hours, Vazante has an unfortunate tendency to drag.
Half Magic is very funny, and fully woke.

Tokyo Idols also gives a necessary platform to journalist Minori Kitahara, a vocal critic of how the idol movement protects male fantasies and the objectification of women, for which she's received major backlash.
As zero-budget films about disaffected youth go, Juan Sebastian Mesa's Los Nadie (The Nobodies) is one of the more engaging.
On the heels of Ann Marie Fleming's joyful animated indie Window Horses comes Nora Twomey's thematically similar but far darker The Breadwinner.
The Teacher is a sly goof on the inspirational-teacher genre.
Director de la Riva shoots much of Ladronas de Almas by firelight in long takes with fluid camera movements, still finding plenty of dread in crisp HD.
Dolores is an important step toward reclaiming Huerta's place in history.
The most interesting sequence is Polina's descent into Antwerp's nightlife.
When Mayor Libby Schaaf pledges to root out the department's "toxic macho culture," it's hard not to wonder if maybe, just maybe, that was the problem all along.
In addition to being a sweet portrait of a local legend, Untold Tales demonstrates that it's possible for privileged white males to rise above poisonous upbringings of racism, sexism, and homophobia.
movie_title: The Untold Tales of Armistead Maupin (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The brightest point of The Tiger Hunter is Pudi, often the best thing in good television shows that either burned out (Community) or never quite caught fire (Powerless), finally getting a chance to shine as a leading man. He's always worth hunting down.

The picture ... addresses a question not often examined in movies, and an eternal source of debate among those who are noticeably different: Is it dehumanizing when someone is specifically attracted to the elements that set you apart?

Brea shot much of the film on her iPhone, which often gives it the tone of a found-footage horror film. Making it all the more horrifying is the fact that not only is it real, but it's while Brea is unable to stand up or often even move beyond crawling.
It's not surprising that his new Napping Princess has some spectacular visuals but that it's otherwise flat.
movie_title: Napping Princess (Hirune-hime: Shiranai watashi no monogatari) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: John Carroll Lynch's lovely Lucky has exactly as much story as it needs, and it doesn't need much considering that it's the final leading role for Harry Dean Stanton, who recently passed away at 91.
Catherine Gund and Daresha Kyi's documentary Chavela is both a celebration of the rough but ultimately triumphant life of Mexican ranchera singer Chavela Vargas.

In the end, Loving Vincent feels more impersonal than other recent (and arguably more truly handmade) animated films, such as The Girl Without Hands or especially My Entire High School Sinking into the Sea.
My Little Pony: The Movie has plenty to offer viewers of all ages, it does not require prior familiarity with Friendship Is Magic, and it's quite smart.
Books are ... present throughout, including lots of tasty archiving porn in the Picture Collection and especially the Berg Collection. Like libraries themselves, Ex Libris has something for everyone.
movie_title: Ex Libris: New York Public Library (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It has some interesting visuals, but A Silent Voice demands investment in the redemption of someone who's impossible to root for.

Though not explicit per se, Tom of Finland is quite visceral; you can practically smell this movie, with many scenes reeking of cigarettes, sweat, and ... And you know whether that's high praise or not.

The way The Divine Order ties suffrage and the right to choose one's own destiny with Annie Sprinkle-style sexual liberation is almost a little too pat, but also results in an ending which qualifies as "happy" in more ways than one.
Being Pixar, the picture looks wonderful - lighting cinematographer Danielle Fienberg has outshone herself - but in the end, the derivative Coco lacks the spark of life found in The Book of Life.
In addition to being composed of horrifying found footage, LA 92 consciously evokes a found-footage horror film.

It's admirable that the film avoids full-on exploitation by ending just before Dahmer's first human kill, but the two-act structure also results in the film never quite making it to the fireworks factory.
The shame of it is, Nails could also function as an all-too-timely parable about women not being listened to when reporting assault, but it's buried within a deeply stooopid movie.
Gilbert creates something of a triptych with two past documentaries.
If you thought card tricks by sighted people were neat, you ain't seen nothin' yet.
With Rose Marie, you never had to wait long to laugh.
The 67-minute Brimstone & Glory is many things: ruthlessly economical, mesmerizing to look at, and downright vertiginous when scaling a castle while wearing a helmet-cam.
When you're faced with constant horror and sadness, sometimes all you can do is face the music and dance.

There's little that countless past books and documentaries haven't covered already, but it's fun to listen to the picture discussed by filmmakers young and old including Guillermo del Toro, Elijah Wood, and Peter Bogdanovich.
By necessity, Morgen added in the ambient nature sounds and an appropriately lush score by Philip Glass in full-tilt doodle-deedle-doodle-deedle mode accompanies the picture.
Wild is a top-notch portrait of alienation that doesn't skimp on carrying its bestial themes to their logical and often moist conclusions

The off-center romance of Dina is enough to make you think that maybe there really is someone for everyone. There isn't, of course - it's among the biggest of the Big Lies - but it's reassuring to see that these nice folks are among the exceptions.

Many independent animated films in recent years have adopted a hand-drawn and/or collage-heavy aesthetic, but few are quite as heartfelt and charming as Ann Marie Fleming's Window Horses: The Poetic Persian Epiphany of Rosie Ming.
There's a hint of a compelling movie in Danièle Thompson's Cézanne et Moi, but it's overshadowed by some unfortunate storytelling choices and a whole lot of Frenchiness.
Bell keeps I Do...Until I Don't sweet and light, not judging any of her characters other than Vivian, and if the ending is a bit pat, it's still a pleasant ride to get there.
Sinking Into the Sea is fun, but an hour of just Rudolph and Watts in the recording studio would be no less buoyant.
movie_title: My Entire High School Sinking Into the Sea (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A lovely meditation on identity and the difficulties of personal connection, Embers is a descendent of Andrei Tarkovsky's Stalker in both tone and mise en scène.
The muddled tone and obvious post-production tinkering makes it feel more like DC's version of Fantastic Four.
Such heartbreaking humanity in All of Me proves reality runs deeper than any shallow political rhetoric.
Little Men sticks its landing, implying something new about a major character without invalidating what came before. And that's no small feat.

Vita Activa: The Spirit of Hannah Arendt covers the whole of her life, and it is not a hagiography, giving plenty of time to those who disagree with her. But many of her ideas are no less relevant today.
movie_title: Vita Activa: The Spirit of Hannah Arendt (2016)

movie_review_blurb: With all due respect to Nuts! and Aferim!, no film this year has earned its exclamation point quite like famed documentarian Barbara Kopple's Miss Sharon Jones!
Ovarian Psycos is both a portrait of sisters doing it for themselves, and another example of how bitchy men can get when they're not included in everything.
Aside from her laudable work ethos, Hesse never comes across as an interesting documentary subject.
If A Monster with a Thousand Heads never quite finds a release for the tension and anger it builds up, that may also be the point.
movie_title: A Monster With A Thousand Heads (Un Monstruo de Mil Cabezas) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Herzog being Herzog, he still Herzogs up the joint, such as wondering whether the internet dreams of itself. (The answer may surprise you.)
movie_title: Lo and Behold, Reveries of the Connected World (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The Intervention pulls off the 'group of friends hash out their problems over a long weekend' story in a way that many other movies fail to do.
The hell of it is, Ghost Team nearly redeems itself with a third-act twist that arrives well after the viewer has stopped caring.
Yoga Hosers takes some potshots at critics, but that's fair: Critics really are the worst.
No new storytelling ground is broken in the charming The Hollars, but it doesn't need to be. The core cast always feels credible as a family.

Roger Ebert often said that what matters is not what a movie is about, but how it's about it. Viewed from that angle, Joshua Marston's Complete Unknown largely fails to find a compelling way to be about its subject.

It's difficult for an expressionistic Italian film about a director experiencing an existential crisis to not evoke 8 1/2 to some extent, but Nanni Moretti's Mia Madre is its own lovely meditation on art and life.
In Order of Disappearance is a clever piss-take on the modern revenge genre, and hopefully it won't be dumbed down too much for mainstream American audiences.
Ross Adam and Robert Cannan's fascinating documentary The Lovers and the Despot recounts a political story that would be unbelievable if weren't true.
The challenging, deeply artistic Cameraperson is also exactly that kind of documentary that would be appropriate for a festival celebrating arthouse theaters.
Lacks the visceral tastiness often found in other foodie documentaries.
movie_title: Kampai! For the Love of Sake (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Andrew Neel's Goat wants to be a shocking exposé of fraternity hazing, but it undercuts itself at every step.

A Good Day to Die Hard and Max Payne director John Moore has updated the notorious 2006 flop Firewall for the smartphone era with I.T. , and it's every bit as unpleasant as A Good Day to Die Hard and Max Payne.
A rote but engaging historical drama about the eternal debate between truth and mythology.
Tallulah tackles so many big themes and is so stuffed with characters and ideas that it all could use more breathing room... Still, there are worse sins than being too ambitious.

The unacknowledged irony is that [Halt and Catch Fire] didn't really find its voice until it moved away from the Compaq story in its second season, but Silicon Cowboys tells the true story very well indeed.

Crunchiness aside, Racing to Zero is an interesting look at one aspect of the city's infrastructure with plenty of pleasant eyenoise in the footage of the trash-processing plants, even if it's sometimes marred by unneeded on-screen text.
movie_title: Racing to Zero, in Pursuit of Zero Waste (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Setting aside its generic and misleading title, Marcin Wrona's Demon is a very eerie tale of possession, and a testament to what can be done without special effects.
If they have the right to engage in intellectual dishonesty, then you have the right to not pay to see Author: The JT LeRoy Story, or to buy any of their books. Fair is fair.
Justin Tipping's Kicks is a promising, if sometimes overly arty, debut.
Hopefully, Shannon's performance in Other People will be an inspiration to other actors.
Adam traces his tumultuous personal relationship with his father along with his father's tumultuous career, showing how Spock's becoming a cultural icon impacted each.

The plodding, maudlin Max Rose's best moments rely heavily on the audience's familiarity with Jerry's persona, and while it's great to see him busting out some of his old schtick... it doesn't fit the character at all.

It's not that there isn't the germ of an interesting history lesson in Fields' life, and its swell that he's still alive to tell his stories, but the 104-minute Danny Says feels like it lasts a lifetime.
In addition to being a meditation on the way media falsehoods agreed upon can impact real life, The Witness is also straight-up research porn.
In the end, the experiment feels more like a hollow thrill than anything else.
Truman's resolution to its title arc is unexpected and the only way that makes emotional sense.
In an age in which anything can be shown onscreen, sometimes all you need is one person reckoning with the infinite.

[The] picture isn't as much of a study of masculinity as its domestic release title The Measure of a Man would suggest; the original French title, La Loi du Marché, translates as The Law of the Market, which is far more appropriate on multiple levels.
movie_title: The Measure of a Man (La loi du marché) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The real selling point is the fighting, and if you're a fan of fighting with knives, The Final Master has got you covered.

The American Side never quite adds up to a satisfying experience, but that's made up for by the cavalcade of familiar faces in small parts, including Matthew Broderick, Harris Yulin, Robert Forster -- and, most excitingly, Janeane Garofalo.
Ido Haar's documentary Presenting Princess Shaw is joyous and uplifting, but also blurs the line between documentary and docudrama a great deal.
Even knowing that Ma Ma is intended to be a woman's-weepie in the vein of Douglas Sirk's 1950s melodramas, nearly every storytelling and stylistic choice is baffling.
It scores extra points for the line "I will not retract my panda statement!", which is as funny out-of-context as in.
Not every directorial choice lands, but the tearjerking Honeyglue's heart is in the right place.
It's fun enough to be appreciated by audiences who aren't already fans of the series. But it also feels rote, and almost safe, in a way that a Wright and Pegg movie shouldn't.
While Léonetti's film is never less than ridiculous, it forgets to also be fun.
Souls still feels very inside-baseball, trusting the audience to follow along.
Anna Rose Holmer's The Fits is the best portrait of female teenage alienation since Eliza Hittman's It Felt Like Love.
The picture is less about its story than creating a sense of place. It's aided by one of the most immersive soundscapes since The Revenant, and Golden Kingdom's world is only slightly less dangerous.
While resonant of past survivor stories like Crash and Fearless, to compare Tikkun to other films is not to take away from its own haunting, unnerving brilliance.
The film is less about the hardcore spiritual stuff than the nuts and bolts of daily life and some talking heads about what brought them there, or how the outside world reacts to their life choices.
In the end, Right Now, Wrong Then is a two-piece puzzle that's less than the sum of its parts.
Benson Lee's Seoul Searching is a funny and often poignant meditation on both ethnic identity and drinking games.
Trisha Shattuck doesn't represent all middle-aged transgender women by any stretch, but From This Day Forward is still a reminder of a forgotten generation.
What seems to be a fairly straightforward story of a hustler and closet case (cf. Boulevard) serves up some interesting twists.
Jeremy Sims' Last Cab to Darwin is a formulaic but still heart-tugging road movie.
The free-associative Cosmos is either pure nonsense, or it contains all the sense in the universe. Your mileage may vary.
Nuts! is very entertaining, but it turns out the definitive XERA documentary has yet to be made. Get on it, Ken Burns.
Breaking a Monster is simultaneously uplifting and depressing, and if it lacks a third act, it's only because Unlocking the Truth's story is still playing in the real world.
Zero Days doesn't offer any answers, or even hope -- how could it? -- but at least it shines a light on a major, and majorly terrifying, issue.
Frank Zappa has always been an acquired taste, and Thorsten Schütte's otherwise terrific documentary Eat That Question: Frank Zappa in His Own Words may not be the best place for a neophyte to start.
movie_title: Eat That Question: Frank Zappa in His Own Words (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Wedding Doll ultimately lives and dies on Rosenblatt's open, vulnerable performance in a tricky role, and she makes you feel Hagit's every joy and pain as she navigates a world that proves to be far less sunny and welcoming than her smile.

Three makes great cinematic use of its claustrophobic single location, and it's at its best when To ratchets up the tension, particularly as Tong and rather patriarchal Chan grow increasingly frustrated by their inability to outwit the Lecter-clever Shun

The key is the proudly silly script, which packs in every pun it can - and a few it probably shouldn't have - while indulging in wordplay such as "I want you the way you were before I wanted you to be the way I wanted."
movie_title: Therapy for a Vampire (Der Vampir auf der Couch) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Sheila Vand steals Jimmy Vestvood: Amerikan Hero as the vivacious Leila. After the smoldering, dark-eyed performance as the chador-wearing vampire in A Girl Walks Home Alone at Night, it turns out a girl also has fantastic comedic chops.
If Only God Forgives evoked Twin Peaks: Fire Walk With Me, then this is Refn's Mulholland Drive, and the best film to play in theaters so far this year.
In addition to being a necessary portrait of the plight of women in post-World War II that can stand alongside Christian Petzold's Phoenix, director Fontaine's The Innocents is refreshingly poignant.
Though Pollak's direction in his first narrative feature is solid, The Late Bloomer is mostly an excuse for predictable sex jokes and ample toplessness.
Coming out as queer is always a difficult process, as is making an interesting movie about coming out in 2016, but Andrew Ahn's meditative Spa Night pulls it off.
What hampers The Lennon Report are its austere budget -- we're told that 1980 is an especially violent year in New York, yet the hospital is all but deserted -- and its occasionally sub-par acting.
A picture as gleefully sleazy as The Lure should be a lot more fun than it actually is.
[Examines] modern masculinity, Mexican stereotypes and especially the privilege of beauty.
movie_title: You're Killing Me Susana (Me estás matando Susana) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The young Fessender has his own voice, and develops a strong enough sense of place and tone that even the many walking scenes don't feel like padding.
Unquestionably moving.
Budgetary considerations no doubt play a part, but director Asghar Farhadi has a way of making domestic dramas that play out in apartments endlessly compelling.

Raoul Peck's powerful documentary I Am Not Your Negro is not a straight-up biography of writer and civil rights icon James Baldwin, nor does it claim to be -- but that makes a certain omission no less frustrating.
My Life as a Zucchini is an unfortunate title for a movie that braves such dark emotional territory.
movie_title: My Life as a Zucchini (Ma vie de courgette) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Speed Sisters is as much about sexism in a Palestinian institution that arguably hasn't existed long enough to develop institutionalized sexism as it is about life under the occupation.

Though not a canonical Ghibli picture, the fact that their last two features The Tale of the Princess Kaguya and When Marnie Was There centered on well-conceived female characters makes the gender politics here doubly disappointing.
What it lacks in scope and budget, the intentionally claustrophobic Tenemos La Carne makes up for with a wonderfully spooky sound design, and the best use of a tympani since 1963's Blood Feast.
movie_title: We Are the Flesh (Tenemos la carne) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Zbigniew Herbert's poetic prophecy of a rat becoming a unit of currency plays out in Colin M. Day's documentary Saving Banksy, which considers the tensions between street artists and their wealthy collectors.
The movie's most impressive trick is that while Winfried's stated philosophy is "Don't lose the humor," his disguises never descend into a Patch Adams-type aggressive whimsy.
Rosemary Myers' wonderful Girl Asleep is a modern fairy tale -- if a story set in the 1970s can qualify as "modern."
Neruda is ultimately about as historically accurate as Miles Ahead, but like that film, it's also more satisfying and poetically truthful than had it just related events as they happened.
The... character-driven and satisfying Paris 05:59 is a tight 90 minutes, mostly in very long takes with largely unobtrusive editing.
movie_title: Paris 05:59: Théo & Hugo (Théo et Hugo dans le même bateau) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Soapy but affecting.

Punching Henry features a fantastic supporting cast of comedians... and Phillips' low-key yet undeniable charisma keeps it from landing squarely in the Sad Bastard genre it otherwise circles, as does the fact that it's genuinely funny.
[A] gripping story of young POWs forced to remove the millions of landmines along the coast of Denmark after World War II.

Storywise, The Void evokes Carpenter's Assault on Precinct 13 and his terminally underrated Prince of Darkness; that not a bad thing, because it's a sturdy framework that Carpenter himself adopted from Howard Hawks.
Your Name is the most beautiful anime since Patema Inverted, with which it shares themes about the difficulties of personal connections as represented by inexplicable cosmic phenomena.
intergenerational conflict is very much in the Ozu domain, but this is not to say that Kore-Eda doesn't have his own authorial stamp.
movie_title: After the Storm (Umi yori mo mada fukaku) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: For Here or to Go? follows the rom-com template a little too closely at times ... but makes up for it both for the issues it raises, and an ending that defies expectations in a very satisfying way.

In Search of Israeli Cuisine could well be a pilot for a Food Channel series, and the personable Solomonov is like Anthony Bourdain without the self-conscious machismo, which makes Solomonov a far more appetizing guide.

American Anarchist makes the interesting choice of saving Powell's difficult childhood for the end, and while it was tragic, most people with difficult childhoods didn't go on to write books about how to make bombs.

You'll be hard-pressed to find a documentary more aesthetically and emotionally satisfying this year than Ceyda Torun's KEDi, about the hundreds of thousands of cats that make the streets of Istanbul their home.
[Ozon] seems to enjoy playing with the color and the timeline without having to be strictly beholden to reality. And that's not a bad thing.

Simon Aboud's whimsical yet slight This Beautiful Fantastic is the latest in the English Garden subgenre, in the vein of The Lady in the Van or A Man Called Ove (which is Swedish but still qualifies).

Strephon Taylor's San Francisco Cable Cars is a loving and very entertaining history of that most iconic of local conveyances, while also tracing the rise and fall of above-ground mass transit in this country.
Granted, the only other film in the KCU thus far is Josh and Jacob's 2001 Haiku Tunnel, but that's still batting a thousand.
In spite of its stuffy outward appearance, The Ottoman Lieutenant retains its director's B-movie sensibilities, and is all the better for it.

The picture's timeline is a bit wonky ... and especially frustrating is a second-act twist that reveals the story about how he got into dance, presented as truth in the first act, was entirely made up for no good reason.
movie_title: Mr. Gaga: A True Story of Love and Dance (2017)

movie_review_blurb: [Staying Vertical lacks Stranger by the Lake's] urgency and economy, but makes up for it by making its countryside feel almost as ominous as that film's lake.
Nobody's ever really themselves on camera, but when Palmer zooms in on Cohen's tear-streaked face, Bird on a Wire feels like an honest portrait of a man just barely hanging on.
It's a character study in which little is revealed about the character being studied.
Hafen's performance rises above the material, eliciting more sympathy for Jenny than the movie believes she deserves.
Videofilia doesn't add up to much, and is just begging to be remixed down into a tight video-art collage -- which may even be the point.
movie_title: Videofilia (and Other Viral Syndromes) (Videofilia: y otros síndromes virales) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Miles Doleac's The Hollow is a fun little genre potboiler that gets it right.
Miss Hokusai is a lovely biopic, even if it never quite picks up and focuses on a single thread. (Then again, neither does life.)
Nothing in Hannes Holm's tearjerking comedy A Man Called Ove is likely to come as a surprise, but that doesn't make the picture any less entertaining.
movie_title: A Man Called Ove (En man som heter Ove) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Sleep well, America!
There's one good thing that comes from the occasional American Godzilla film: They get Toho to dust off the property and do it right.
Of a piece with Love and Demons, but never quite as emotionally satisfying as that film, reVISIONS also functions as an east-of-Twin-Peaks travelogue of San Francisco.
In addition to being a terrific portrait of crippling social anxieties, Christine is a portrait of a bygone era that in many ways looks the same as ours.
Ultimately, it comes across more like a bonus disc than a feature film.

While The Handmaiden is an empirically gorgeous movie no matter what's happening on screen, it also has no business being two-and-a-half hours long. It loses its momentum in the third act -- but lordy, those first two acts.
One of the more entertaining boom-nostalgia docs of late.

The picture is boisterous and shouty and frequently grotesque, and it features a preponderance of scantily clad, large-breasted women, including Straw Hat pirate Nami, whose barely-there bikini top helpfully has the word "sexy" printed on it.
Between The Incident and now The Similars (Los Parecidos), Isaac Ezban is proving himself to be one of the best directors of brainy sci-fi.
Fire at Sea meditates on how life can go on even with a front-row seat to unspeakable misery and injustice. After all, someone still has to make the pasta and take listener requests.

The film does work as an interesting formalistic experiment... I Am Not Madame Bovary doesn't attempt to prettify the smoggy, overcrowded landscape, making the already-small frame feel that much more claustrophobic.
It's refreshing that Pierre plays in a band, and is uninvolved in drag culture. Who knew that not all boys who defy gender expectations dream of lip-syncing Cher?
movie_title: Don't Call Me Son (Mãe Só Há Uma) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: In addition to being as close to a you-are-there document of an incident that the NRA would probably rather we forgot, Tower also works as a study of both survivor guilt and guilt-guilt.
The result is more of a hang-out film than the first three, which is not necessarily a bad thing, and Everfree can't be accused of treading the same old ground.
movie_title: My Little Pony Equestria Girls: Legend of Everfree (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Rémi Chayé's Long Way North is a lovely, traditionally animated film that falls a little short in the story department.
movie_title: Long Way North (Tout en haut du monde) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: In addition to being a character study of a tragic figure, Off the Rails is an indictment of a justice system that hasn't been on the rails for a long time, if ever.
The film has lost none of its silly charm in the ensuing decades.
[Kiki] has been compared to early Almodóvar for good reason.
movie_title: Kiki, Love to Love (Kiki, el amor se hace) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Rogue One may be more intense than fun, but it's the best Star Wars prequel film by a long shot.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The Brand New Testament may well be the purest fantasy film of the year. It's certainly one of the most satisfying.
movie_title: The Brand New Testament (Le tout nouveau testament) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Eden may especially resonate with those who've struggled and put their all into their art, only to see their colleagues succeed and pull up the ladder behind them. Plus, it has a good beat and you can dance to it.
Fitfully interesting.
Evolution never quite gives up its secrets, and it's not a coincidence that the opening shots are deep underwater, since the picture submerges the viewer in its world and keeps them there.
The real-life theater location gives the picture more production value than is often found in the Jaglomography, and Ovation! is one of his more accessible works overall.
The dialect-heavy picture makes few concessions to mainstream storytelling and is all the stronger for it.

Glover is always pleasant to hang out with, Rudolph gets to show off her considerable dramatic chops, while Joel Murray makes a blink-and-you'll-miss-it cameo. And if you don't think you can feel sorry for a pig, wait for those last few minutes.
Sophia Takal's unnerving Always Shine is the most overtly (and awesomely) feminist horror movie since last year's Felt.

As to be expected from the directors of Winged Migration, the meditative Seasons is a sparsely narrated collection of often-stunning footage of animals going on about their business, sometimes in spite of humanity's best efforts.
A worthy addition to the director-and-their-muse documentary subgenre that includes films like Liv & Ingmar or Werner Herzog's My Best Fiend.
The visual spectacle, special effects and action should impress lovers of the fantasy genre.
Red Planet delivers a tight, taut story, but at times disappoints, dragging when the action should fly.
A delight, with tickles that reach from pre-k to grown-up.
Action fans will find Bait, the latest power-packed, special-effects extravaganza starring Jamie Foxx, irresistible.
So sloppy with sentimental goop, unsuspecting audiences should be warned not to sit too close to the screen.
This little horror film offers spooky sound effects and a few bona-fide chills sure to delight young audiences.
The violence in the movie is so cartoonish, at times viewers can only imagine that a large anvil will fall from the sky, squashing a very perturbed coyote.
Dazzles with an array of high-powered star appearances.
Lost Souls is wretched.
The over-the-top bigness of Cage and the understated honesty of Leoni refresh this well-worn story.
Rarely has the time-tested battle between cats and dogs felt so good.
Much like my stereotype of fashion models, Head Over Heels is pretty to look at, but, after a while, it doesn't hold interest.
Draws genuine laughs through not only the plot but through character development.
Engaging and dynamic.
Despite a litany of inanities, the film scores a big hit because it's just plain funny watching goofy Arquette twist his rubbery face as he stumbles into disaster.
A turgid adventure tale caught somewhere between family comedy and spy spoof.
Fans of farce comedy and sight gags should love Just Visiting despite its uneven story.
While the message of the story sings loud and clear, the drama plays out at a whisper.
Agent Cody Banks 2: Destination London is pure fun.
Across landscapes from sunny South Florida to snowy Detroit, George Clooney and Jennifer Lopez deliver a sizzling, palpable heat in Out of Sight.
Look elsewhere for reality or good drama. Look here, however, if you're in the mood for a good heaping of fantasy and some fun.
A brilliant grassroots take on the humble beginnings and eventual demise of a musical movement that ultimately had far more impact than it would have ever imagined.
Anything heartbreaking or somber is touched upon with the barest of brushes or converted into a comic Band-Aid, leaving you stuck on the cusp of the last stage of grief.
The overarching sentiment of Ways to Live Forever is curiosity. Does dying hurt? How does someone live forever?
Herblock and his mighty graphite were there for Watergate, McCarthyism, the civil rights movement, the Vietnam War, the anti-tobacco campaign, and the post-Columbine push for gun control ...

The fact that Jolie isn't very likable would be less of a problem if this film were actually funny, but his selfish disregard for those around him only ends up making us feel bad for the people who care about him.
Though it largely sides with the protesters, the film does not find them faultless.
movie_title: 99%: The Occupy Wall Street Collaborative Film (2013)

movie_review_blurb: It's shock value (drugs, sex, bodily fluids, and a lot of yelling) over any semblance of cleverness.
The grief we see among those who loved him is brief yet palpable. But the emotion we're left with is more uplifting ...
Jeremiah Chechick's The Right Kind of Wrong has more wrong than right and plays like an ode to testicle jokes.
Any potential for an in-depth examination of the adolescent psyche pushed to its limits goes unmet, though not for lack of trying.
There are some great moments sprinkled throughout. But overall, these elements never seem to come together in the same harmonious way that this family does with each other.
Never really excels in any given area, and re-watch factor is a zero.
Enough already with these uninspiring jaunts - especially if no effort is going to be made to stimulate our curiosity and imagination in a way that would truly honour Verne's enchanting writings.
It's an interesting film, even if it's never clear what Erdem is getting at.
Rich, heady filmmaking that employs small strokes on a huge canvas.
Gerwig's done enough good work to allow us to chalk this one up as a glossy blip.
A fascinating reminder of why the humble video camera can be used as a weapon against political oppression.
Preaching to the choir, but that's no bad thing.
movie_title: Something from Nothing: The Art of Rap (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The film is as much about Reich as income inequality, a topic he has written and talked about for decades. You'll learn why he's 4 feet 10.5 inches tall and why he became active in social politics.
The film ends with more questions than answers - perhaps that's the point.
movie_title: Money for Nothing: Inside the Federal Reserve (2013)

movie_review_blurb: There is nothing new here.

If you accept that there won't be a semblance of sense in the screenplay, and that the... film is essentially a showreel for Khan to show off his sculpted body, action moves and dance steps, then perhaps you can enjoy the madness that is Jai Ho.
As the second half wears on, the proceedings become monotonous.
You name it and they are all there, larding up this film to the 160-minute mark.
Haider starts off promisingly. It's too bad that the promise never delivers.
Avoid at all costs.
If you don't mind a bit of shallow romance, and pretty people falling in love, this might be the film for you.
Ghosh builds up his thriller beautifully, and the atmospherics throughout the film are pitch perfect, lending a note of authenticity to a screenplay that doesn't always make sense.

As Madaari draws to its predictable conclusion, the only thing you are left wondering is how on earth did the nameless man get enough network coverage for him to watch videos unbuffered and upload them in the middle of nowhere?
The two timelines and the characters seem worlds apart, and the tenuous thread that holds them together seems to snap much before the 137-minute narrative ends.
Thanks to the vagaries of the Indian film market and the mystery that is the Bollywood movie watcher, we are faced with Housefull 3, a film that should never have been made.
Like the snow-covered mountains that form a backdrop to much of Shivaay, the film may have been meant to inspire awe, but the end result leaves you stone cold.
2 States doesn't know where to stop. It takes a good idea and stretches it to a point where it becomes tedious and uninteresting.
The trimmings in this love story like the music and choreography are the best bits but Mehra and Gulzar fail to give us a sense of the real conflicts in the film.
The verdict, in this case, isn't in Jolly's favour.
For a film that starts off so well, M S Dhoni: The Untold Story is unable to achieve what its subject has made an art out of -- finishing off in style.

What works for the film is that the pace doesn't falter -- Yash and KK are always chasing the bad guy and hunting for the next clue, which makes it easier to ignore the gaping holes in the plot and focus on John Abraham's action moves.
Dear Zindagi might not be a love letter to life it was intended to be, but Bhatt and Khan make this one worth watching.
The Ghazi Attack is stylishly shot and employs technology on screen better than many other Bollywood films, but its story-telling is reminiscent of patriotic films from the 60s and 70s.
Kaabil is a surprisingly easy-to-watch film that keeps its eye on the ball.
Gowariker's film feels average, and no amount of songs by A R Rahman or Hrithik Roshan's acting prowess can change that.
On the face of it, this is another one of those films that requires you to suspend all belief and watch it for Salman Khan. On another level, this is a film that angered me no end.

The sequences are wonderfully shot and choreographed, so much so that it is difficult to believe the actors aren't full-time wrestlers. And at the centre of it all is Aamir Khan. He plays Mahavir with practiced authority and impeccable timing.
Dastur walks away with more lines and more screen space than the leading man, but doesn't make much use of it, giving an insipid performance that is in keeping with the film's tone.
Shirin Farhad Ki Toh Nikal Padi could have been a sweet romance, but turns out to be an entirely forgettable film that you would be best advised to avoid.
movie_title: Shirin Farhad Ki Toh Nikal Padi (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Matru Ki Bijlee Ka Mandola is a disappointing film, one that could have been so much more.
Whether intentional or not, Phullu seems liked a half-made film, one that started off right but was abandoned midway and left to fend for itself.
Bumpy's action comedy is a shining example of what can go awry not just during a robbery but in making a film about one.
The film is a rehash of the many reincarnation stories that have populated the Bollywood romance genre over the years and has nothing new to say.
The romance in this romantic comedy is non-existent, but thankfully the wit and sparkle in the humour make it a fun watch.
There is nothing that can be salvaged in this project. It doesn't work as a love story or a crime caper, and is as unpalatable as five-day-old biryani.
A Death in the Gunj is wonderfully observed, stunningly shot and thanks to Massey's breakout performance, a must-watch in theatres.
On watching Naam Shabana, you realise that not all stories need two hours of run time. Sometimes, a well-executed five-minute scene is more than enough.
Trapped is one of those films taken to another level only on the strength of a powerhouse performance, and Rajkummar Rao will be remembered for this one for a long, long time.
You might be better off standing in a never-ending queue at a bank or ATM rather than watching this out-of-tune film.
Baar Baar Dekho, for the most part doesn't slow down its pace, and is peppered with expensive sets and lovely locations. It's easy on the eyes and that makes it easier to watch.
The only thing this film has going for it are some interesting bit characters.
Ae Dil Hai Mushkil has neither gravitas nor the charm to be worth remembering.
This is one of those movies you can catch on television when nothing else is playing. Otherwise, Table No. 21 is safe to avoid.
The film is tailor-made for Shroff and he doesn't disappoint -- he executes a kick with the same fluidity and grace as a dancer and makes the toughest of sequences looks scarily easy.
Despite having a lot of things going for it, Te3n doesn't pass the first test of a thriller -- it doesn't keep you on the edge of your seat.
The comedy just gets more tedious and unfunny as the film progresses. Except for a couple of jokes, nothing, and I mean nothing, is salvageable in this disaster of a film.
Mukherji doesn't seem to be able to tie together the twin themes of partition and the exploitation of women.
Chopra, the maker of one of Bollywood's most enduring love stories, wanted to move with the times, but he didn't quite get a hold of the Dharam-Shyra generation as he did the Raj-Simran generation.
When the ending comes, it is more than effective, giving you a better sense of the two characters and their pain than the film has managed to until that point.
Much like its title character, who often flares up for no reason, Saala Khadoos is a lot of hot air and not much else.

Seema Pahwa [gives] the standout performance in the film. Maya Sarao as Bauji's daughter; Namit Das as the daughter's boyfriend; and Kapoor as Bauji's younger brother, all add to what is a terrific ensemble cast.

There are plenty of simplistic solutions to problems; long, rambling speeches; and lingering shots of kids living in poverty -- which leads to the film often over-stating its point. But thanks to the two main leads, you might forgive these flaws.
Naseeruddin Shah, as the romantic fool who isn't past manipulating his own nephew for his own ends, reminds you why he is one of India's best actors.
For a man who gave us Kabhi Kabhie and Silsila, Jab Tak Hai Jaan is certainly not a fitting swansong, but it is a reminder of why his brand of romance always worked.
The performances are hampered by some predictable writing and a director who seems to treat her characters and setting as a tourist rather than someone with an insider's point of view.

Kangana Ranaut walks away with the entire film, playing both Tanu and Kusum with panache, in what is probably the defining female performance of 2015 (in a year already filled with many). Yet, even she cannot salvage this film in the end.
Bajpayee and the rest of the cast plough on, regardless of the meaninglessness of the script.
Krrish 3 could have been salvaged if the story had been a little less convoluted, but there are too many unnecessary complications and sub-plots.
Thankfully, the director doesn't over-dramatize events. He uses a restrained, subtle narrative to tell the audiences Shahid's story, rarely judging his motives or intentions.
There are some movies that are worth your time and money and the effort of writing about them. And then there are movies like Boss.
Unless you like the feeling of being hit on the head repeatedly with a hammer, avoid this one.
Nitpicking aside, The Lunchbox is a thoroughly charming film, brought alive by some great writing.
Phata Poster Nikhla Hero could have been funnier, but director Santoshi drags it too long and loses the viewer mid-way.
This is a film that will require a bit of patience as it trundles towards its conclusion, but spare some time and you will be rewarded with a fresh take on love that you haven't seen in a long time.
The only saving grace is Naseeruddin Shah, who as usual is excellent in his role despite being saddled with a rather hackneyed script.
Apoorva Lakhia's attempt at retelling one of Bollywood's best films is an example of how the film industry got it wrong. Six-pack abs and item songs do not a great story make.

R...Rajkumar is the latest in the series of "masala entertainers" that Bollywood seems to churn out with alarming regularity. Watching one is like watching another, and reviewing one is like writing about all of them.
Even Varma's staunchest supporters would find it difficult to defend his latest atrocity of a film.
A film that, like its protagonist, is a mere shadow of its earlier avatars.
Thankfully, director Sayed keeps it short, resisting the temptation to segue into melodrama. He sticks to a few montage scenes between Vidya and her daughter.
If the aim of the film was to evoke nostalgia, it works in the sense that you yearn for the time when Bollywood knew how to make a love story, and romance didn't have to be this laboured.
Baahubali 2: The Conclusion is a worthy conclusion to this epic series. It may not up the ante from the last film, but it doesn't let up on the pace either.

As a tribute to a demigod of cinema, "Kabali" doesn't need anything but Rajinikanth on screen for it to work. As a film though, it falls short on many levels, and no amount of hero worship can cloak that fact.
The bad guys may be missing, but Sultan has everything else that makes for a satisfying Bollywood film.
Just like his set, Puri's film also focuses on the theatrics, the frills, the melodrama, and not on the actual story, which makes for a very tedious watch.
Shorgul is too busy splashing fake blood on its characters to give you any real insight.
Despite the heartfelt performances, especially by Revathy (who plays Laila's feisty mother), the film strikes many a false note.
Fan ends up as a disappointment for its unwillingness to explore the complicated, at times unfathomable relationship between an actor and his fans, and for reducing it to an average thriller.
Like its subject, the tone of Luthria's movie is slightly over-the top and tends to caricaturize certain characters, but the lead performance is so all-encompassing that you don't mind these flaws.
The film careens from one fake crisis to the other.
Ram Leela is not a realistic film, nor does it play out as well as it should. But you cannot take your eyes off the screen.
Rajput immerses himself as Bakshy and comes out on top, but the film itself never manages to soar, despite threatening to do so many times.

This is perhaps the weakest of Hirani's films. His trademark humour is sparse; and inspite of Anushka Sharma's spirited portrayal of a reporter who helps PK, and Khan's over-earnest performance as the protagonist, the film is a tedious watch.
Happy Bhag Jayegi is a mildly funny comedy that doesn't try too hard to push the boundaries, but does enough to entertain you.
Other than a few smart lines, UnIndian doesn't have too much going for it.
The naivety in the beginning gradual gives way to sheer ridiculousness as the 123-minute movie spirals into a whorl of bad acting and even worse accents.

Under the flimsy cover of a sports film, Freaky Ali is just another Bollywood 'good guy versus bad guy' movie. Every character is a caricature and every plot point already seen in a thousand other films.
For a story that is replete with so many layers, Desai handles the narrative with all the finesse of a bull in a china shop.
Sunaina Bhatnagar's coming-of-age drama doesn't look too promising at first, but is one of those films that grow on you.
There is something to be said for a film that takes a tired romantic trope and turns it into a tale that will bring a smile to your face.
On the surface, Badrinath ki Dulhaniya is funny and smart, but when you get to the heart of it, the film doesn't quite hold up.
The only redeeming quality of this film is Varun Dhawan and his comic timing that lightens the mood and makes some lines funnier than they would have been otherwise.
There is a thin line between making a film about a serial killer and glorifying his actions. With Raman Raghav 2.0, Anurag Kashyap seems to be unsure which side of the line he's standing on.
While Pari and Chotu do have their moments, for the most part Dhanak comes across as forced and superficial rather than a heartfelt story of two siblings.
In spite of some soppy dialogue and a jingoistic end, the film is an easy, breezy watch, which you might enjoy even if you are not a die-hard Salman Khan fan.
The performances are superb and everyone plays their parts well.
For all its positives, Talvar fails to keep that distance, and therefore compromises its ability to be an impartial, unbiased chronicle of what is India's most sensational murder case.
Court is a rare film that creates drama out of the humdrum lives of ordinary people, whose limited world view and biases affect the lives of others in more ways than they can imagine.

For all the controversy surrounding this film... the main talking point about Udta Punjab should be that it is, by far, one of the best-acted Bollywood films in the past few years. That alone is worth the price of your ticket.
It is to Tiger Shroff's credit that he pulls it off. His action sequences are fluid, and his dance moves are even better.
Piku is a lovely film, which tells a compelling story created out of everyday lives. This doesn't happen too often, so don't miss this one.
Pink is largely a triumph -- a Bollywood film that talks about a burning topic and finds an entertaining way to do it.
The film, produced by Karan Johar and Anil Thadani, is an adrenaline rush, a spectacle of the kind we haven't seen from an Indian film-maker before and hopefully it is a sign of good things to come.

This is a movie that is so bad, it's good. It is horrifying and hilarious at the same time. So what do you get out of it? Three hours of disbelief plastered on your face that you cannot wipe off, no matter how hard you try.

Mary Kom is a travesty of a movie because it misses an opportunity to tell a great story, and dumbs it down to such an extent that every nuance, every bit of context and every bit of truth is obliterated.
It is Ranaut's ownership of the character, as well as director Bahl's conscious attempt at a subtle, screwball comedy that makes Queen soar.
[Banjo] looks and feels like a film that has crossed its sell-by date.
Not every film needs to have meaning, or a larger message, but it does need a story. Student of the Year is all about the clothes, the brawn and the glamour, but not much else.
Sadh has a perpetual scowl on his face, and Pannu's attempt at playing the gregarious Punjabi girl falls flat. This "shaadi" should have never happened.
Hasee Toh Phasee is an unusual romantic comedy, but for some powerhouse performances and genuinely good humour, this film is worth it.
Ghaywan doesn't overstate his points, and even though the resolution he finds for his characters is predictable, their journey is interesting enough to make up for a cliched ending.
Hunterrr has some good humour, but for a sex comedy, it is surprisingly banal.
The two hour-long murder mystery is taut; and even though it is packed with all the familiar tropes, the atmospherics ensure that the story never sags, keeping the audience engaged throughout.
Gabbar is Back is a dated film, both in look and feel, and the cast seems to know it too.
In the end, you only wish Warsi would get better roles and better films that do justice to his talent, rather than this hackneyed mess of a film.
Sandilya's attempt at giving us a glimpse into the unseen pressures of urban life is commendable, but the story has neither meat nor heft to keep the audience interested.

The film belongs to Akshay Kumar. He is in almost every scene and this is an author-backed role that he obviously relishes. Even if you aren't the patriotic sort, his performance is reason enough to watch the film.
Nishikant Kamat's Rocky Handsome stars John Abraham as a hulking man-robot who seems capable of the most complicated stunts and ruthless killings, but is unable to muster up basic emotions.
If only the director had got his main leads right, perhaps this would have been a different film.

There is so much to be said about changing roles in today's India, and films would do well to reflect on this great churn. But R. Balki, like most of Bollywood, would rather not look outside and learn.
This is misogyny and regression masquerading as comedy, and Sharma seems to be too busy trying to morph into a Hindi film hero to employ his famous comic timing to good effect.
Mastizaade is another example of Bollywood's belief that even if you sink to the depths of mediocrity, there is someone out there who will still come and watch your film.
Shetty's story doesn't have the emotional heft or enough jokes to entertain us for 151 minutes - the film's runtime.
The Hindi Chef is as one-toned and as predictable as the original. For a film that purports to be about food, there is little more than a passing interest demonstrated.
Chicken Khurana isn't perfectly cooked, nor is it one of those beautiful dishes you see in cookery shows or in magazines, but it does have the warmth of a home-made dish. Give it a chance.
There is a host of ensemble actors who add nothing to the film's humour quotient, and saunter in and out of the screen with no purpose.

For those of us who are election junkies, Newton is a welcome peek into the fascinating world of an Indian general election and the processes and ideologies that govern it. But even if you don't care about elections, Newton works on so many other levels.
Haseena Parkar is a film that is more concerned with making money than it is about telling the true story of that rare woman who made it to the top in the underworld.
movie_title: Haseena (Haseena: The Queen Of Mumbai)(haseena Parkar) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: As revenge-dramas go, this one is middling, with neither emotions nor actions quite hitting the mark.
Scratch the surface, and [Daddy] is yet another film that romanticizes a gangster and attempts to redeem him.
By the time we come to yet another sanctimonious speech from Sunny Deol about the true meaning of masculinity, you will want to bolt for the door even before the credits have rolled.
Baadshaho is a yawn-fest.
The problem with Secret Superstar is that it starts out with a good idea, but the film unravels because it wants to say too many things at once.
This could have been an attempt to get under the skin of a famous psychopathic criminal, but it falls flat because the film-makers choose style over substance.
With its bad jokes and mediocre dialogue, this pullav - to use another cliché - is unpalatable.
There are some laugh-out-loud moments when the screenplay plummets to the absolute depths of Bollywood inanity. Apart from such moments of hilarity, Hate Story 3 has absolutely nothing going for it
For all its rough edges though, there is an attempt to stay off the beaten path and a few sincere performances to match that effort, so 3 Storeys deserves some credit.

Once Roy strips away the mystery from his characters, Pari loses its way, and it feels like a laboured finish to the end. Even those easily scared (like this reviewer) will find no need to avert their eyes.

The narrative is thin and repetitive, and the film relies mostly on the charms of its two leading men to carry the burden of a middling screenplay. The dialogue lacks spark and the director takes his own sweet time getting to the conclusion.
This is misogyny and regression masquerading as comedy, and Sharma seems to be too busy trying to morph into a Hindi film hero to employ his famous comic timing to good effect.
Don't miss Kai Po Che - it's a warm film that speaks much about friendship in the troubled times we live in.

In spite of the obvious lack of depth, and the rather predictable problems and solutions, Kapoor and Sons is powered by some great performances...Rajat Kapoor and Ratna Pathak Shah are fiery but it is Fawad Khan who steals the show.

For all its flaws, Padman, much like its protagonist, puts in a sincere effort. It takes a subject that most Indians are reluctant to talk about and puts it on the marquee, and that alone is worth the applause.

Khilji is depraved, crazed, perverted and violent, and yet he is the most interesting character in the film. Credit for that goes to Ranveer Singh, who gives in to Khilji's unhinged personality and makes it his own.

My Birthday Song is supposed to be many things - including a psychological thriller and a mid-life crisis drama - but it is mostly a repository of bad acting, the kind that makes you cringe every time someone even tries to attempt an emotional scene.
Sports in India is much more than just the game and Kashyap tries to throw the spotlight on that, but he tries to land too many punches, and in doing so, misses the mark.
If there is ever a third film in the works in this action franchise, then the filmmakers would do well to put Kaif in the spotlight and give Tiger some down time.
This is a dull month for Bollywood, and Fukrey Returns just adds to the gloom.
Great Grand Masti could have turned the tables on the sex comedy genre, but thanks to some watered-down humour and regressive script, this is just another mediocre film that will sink into oblivion.

For all its flaws, this is a welcome break from the other sanitised rape-revenge dramas we've seen this year in the form of Maatr and Mom, and one that doesn't flinch at the brutal nature of its subject.

This is an author-backed role, but Vidya Balan makes it so much more by adding layers of empathy and vulnerability to make Sulu a character that will stay with you long after you have left the theatre.
If only Chandra had focused on her two strongest characters and left out the rest, we'd have a winner on our hands.
Rajkummar Rao tries his best to salvage the situation, humanising Satyendar for the most part; but even he cannot pull off the truly farcical parts of this film.

Rajdhani Express is one of those films which will force you to answer some existential questions. Questions such as "Why am I here?" "What am I doing with my life?" and most importantly, "How did a movie like this get made?"
At the end, you will find it hard to care about the goldfish, the plant, the cranky old woman, or this group of what seem to be the world's most immature and irresponsible people.
There are just a couple of positives that are not enough to keep this ship from sinking.

From 80s movies tropes like mental hospitals to characters that saunter in and out of the frame without any context,"Akira is a great example of a movie with a timely topic that suffers from outdated treatment.
Unfortunately, just like the India's demonetisation drive, proper implementation is what's sorely missing in this endeavour.

Tamanchey is a DOA film - one that doesn't have any chance of redeeming itself or its cast. Thankfully, it also generates so much "so bad, it's good" humour that your two hours in the theatre are not completely wasted.
This is one of those films that works on the strength of good writing and some good ensemble acting.
The mystery itself is not very intriguing and dealt with in an amateurish fashion. You can see the red herrings a mile away.

Director Abhay Chopra seems to have realised what many in Bollywood haven't - when it comes to thrillers and mysteries, it is best to keep it short. Bereft of item songs and irrelevant sub-plots, the film comes out looking good.
[Bareilly] could have used some spicing up.
The leading ladies acted beautifully, and the bonhomie between them seems genuine. For what is being touted as "India's first female buddy film", that is a huge saving grace.
Ali is obviously trying to push his boundaries and it doesn't always work, but when it does, the result is breathtaking. For that alone, the film is worth a watch.
Beyond the dance performances, ABCD 2 is disappointing and lacks cinematic flair or energy.
The hurried manner in which Akhtar and co-writer Reema Kagti wrap up all loose ends is what makes the film unravel.
(Rawal's) performance and the film's willingness to address the biases and narrow-mindedness that many Indians harbour toward their fellow citizens is a good enough reason to watch this film.

NH10 scares, thrills and entertains throughout its 115 minutes. It also suggests that Bollywood finally might have turned a corner this year, and is ready to churn out films that more faithfully reflect the country we inhabit -- the whole country.
This might not be your everyday Bollywood romance, but it is one that should be celebrated, because it is a love story that is rooted in reality.
Nana Patekar seems to realise the futility of this film, and his indifferent acting is ample proof. Perhaps the film-makers should have realised it too.

Raghavan takes one of the most worn-in genres in Bollywood and makes it fresh. Raghavan questions the nature of revenge, he questions whether the revenge justifies the crime, and whether our ideas of good and evil might need a rehaul.
In theory, this could have been a film within a film, but in reality, it ends up being nothing but a long, meandering, and rather pointless story.
Llike a pilot who has no idea where he's going to land his plane, Balki keeps circling round and round, playing out the same conflicts over and over again.
Director Shaad Ali tries to package this unoriginal storyline with some frills, including kitschy dance numbers and smart dialogue, but they can't camouflage the weakness of his script.
The only happy ending here is when you walk out of the theatre, having survived the ordeal that is this film.
While the premise of vigilante justice might be one of honest intentions, D'Silva sullies the cause by refusing to fill up the giant craters in his script.
It is one of those films that take the romance-action-comedy formula and pushes it so many notches higher that you can't hear yourself think over the cacophony on screen.
This is one of those films that manage to surprise you - it is taut, engaging and filled with good performances. May we have more of these.
Ugly is a disturbing film which will make you squirm in your seat. But if you don't mind that, it is worth a watch.
Alone relies on the usual horror movie tricks to scare the audience, but the story is saddled with so many meaningless twists and turns that it's more exhausting than scary toward the end.
Baby is a fast-paced, smartly written and well-acted film that never wavers from its subject. Even if it doesn't always keep you in suspense, it doesn't let you wander too far.
Dolly Ki Doli is a breezy watch, one that is salvaged largely because it knows how to deliver smart lines and, most importantly, knows when to end.
This Tubelight flickers erratically for a long time and then dies out.

If only Kumar were the main plot. When the movie returns to the randy old scarecrows, it feels like an anti-climax and just one more hackneyed, derivative film in a Bollywood library that's already brimming with them.

What could have been an interesting film about the times we live in, turns out to be an insipid romance that neither engages nor entertains. The actors seem unable to rise above their stunted roles and the situations aren't funny enough.

Dhawan and Sanon share an easy chemistry. Pritam's soundtrack is hummable. The only purpose of Dilwale is to chant every known Bollywood mantra for a successful film and cash in on its celebrated lead actors. In that aim, the film is hugely successful.

The narrative is linear and predictable, but the film comes alive when Ranveer Singh and Priyanka Chopra are in the frame. For Singh, it is possibly the role of a lifetime and he plays Bajirao with an ease and confidence that radiates on screen.
Amit Masurkar's story is insular, and thus loses its charm half-way through the film.
The biggest problem with Pyaar Ka Punchnama 2 isn't that it stereotypes women, it doesn't even do it in a way that makes you laugh.

Where Singh is Bliing differs from the tried and tested is that the leading lady is not reduced to a simpering mess waiting for her knight in shining armour to rescue her. Prabhudheva's heroine is the one doing the rescuing for much of the film.
Akshay Kumar is more restrained, playing the role of the toilet messiah in a more laidback manner. But it isn't enough to lift this film from the depths of mediocrity.
Cinematographer Vivek Shah's gloomy frames highlight the mood of the film wonderfully. If only this was enough to redeem the film.
For all its rough edges, Indu Sarkar has a strong message; and to Bhandarkar's credit, he doesn't let that message get lost in the fluff.
Arjun Kapoor displays a singular lack of comic timing, and the female leads are for decorative purposes only.
Shroff is the perfect old-school hero, with screen presence and action skills to match. Now if only someone would give him a good script to play with.
Its intentions are honest, but the narrative strikes a false note at several key points.
This feels like a college skit that mistakenly made it to the big screen.
For all its narrative flaws, Mom does have some plus points, especially cinematographer Anay Goswami's frames.
[Jagga Jasoos] is a rousing musical that pays tribute to Tintin and Feluda, and combines Disney's musical tradition with a whimsical style reminiscent of Wes Anderson's work.
The film's plot is sketchy and misses crucial details. The dialogue -- especially Hydari's lines -- is stilted, with supposedly poignant moments coming across as fake.
This is a film that feels like it was directed on auto-pilot and then left to its own devices.
It is the mind-numbingly inane commentary that is the most grating part of these scenes. The verbal diarrhoea drowns out what is supposed to be the most action-packed part of the film.

Even an actor as accomplished as Nawazuddin Siddiqui seems to have given in to the shrill tone of the film, turning in what is perhaps his weakest performance so far in what should have been a meaty role.
All Is Well should never have been made and no one should have to sit through the travesty that it is. Avoid at all costs.
Khan and co-writer Parveez Shaikh fail to come up with any unexpected twists and turns. Despite their attempts to create suspense, they end up depicting chaos on the screen.
Bahl might have set out to make a quirky, and perhaps an absurdist take on romance, but he simply doesn't have the skills to pull it off.
