Welcome Back is sporadically funny, one that ebbs and flows; but it just about passes the "guilty pleasure" test thanks to Kapoor and Patekar.

Both Pancholi and Shetty seem awkward and self-conscious in front of the camera, and overcompensate for their seeming lack of acting talent by either screeching instead of emoting (Shetty) or adopting a fierce look at all times (Pancholi).
Katti Batti is a film that tries too hard to be "cool" and ends up falling on its face.

The film, co-written by Puneet Krishna, Sumit Purohit and Anshuman, is an incoherent mess, oscillating wildly between insipid humour and all-out mediocrity as it hurtles towards a catastrophic climax.
Prem Ratan Dhan Payo is a spectacle that rings hollow. This is not the Diwali gift you were waiting for.
Perhaps it is time Bollywood discards the candy floss version of the great Indian family and adopts this more real, searing version.
Nocturnal Animals works because it doesn't allow you to breathe.
What the movie lacks in depth, it more than makes up for in solid acting and a compelling (and convincing) love story.

It's an admirably bold vision for Vundla, but I suspect it will leave a lot of local audiences a little bewildered and underwhelmed. That said, it's a boldness that may ultimately lead to a warming up to new ideas.
Baby Driver is a strikingly adventurous and bold action film.
Tom Noonan is great as the sheriff, and his scenes with John Malkovich are the best in the movie.
While watching Bowling for Columbine, the word 'absurd' kept coming to mind.
The pride which the story has for intelligence and the grace of those who try to achieve it is 8 miles away from those who flaunt their ignorance.
Where Sandler's career is going is anybody's guess.
The team of Kaufman and Jonze has made another quality film for the cerebral set. I can't imagine what they will come up with next.
Romantics will be loyal to this movie, but they are after all "romantics."
A powerful political piece that never preaches.
Director/writer Douglas McGrath (Emma) pares the long novel down to a screenplay just over two hours long while keeping it interesting and faithful to the book.
A fairy godmother isn't going to show up at the end and make it all better, but the story keeps you guessing what's next.
The dialogue is very choppy and monosyllabic despite the fact that it is being dubbed.
The action is so engrossing that I didn't notice the actual filmmaking.
The film may be bloody, but it still has depth and honesty.
The movie starts off embarrassingly bad. Ten one-liners go by with not even a smirk from the audience.
Almodovar has said that maybe maturity is what made him write male characters. Whatever it is has worked wonders to make this his most confident work.
The energy caught on the water kept making me tense my legs as if I was going to fall off my surfboard at any moment.
If you need a good cry, can't miss the latest Beatles tribute, or just want to see a humanistic drama sprinkled with funny scenes, go see I Am Sam.
They don't make them like this anymore, and I can't even think of another actor or character that could pull this off right now.
Although this movie won't stir up great debates and isn't something that will change your life, it is beautiful in vision and spirit.
The corny jokes and the tired plot will make any self-respecting adult grimace.
I am proud of those men, and I am grateful to the filmmakers for bringing this story to my attention.
This movie has everything -- swashbucklers, swords fights, masked festivals, hot air balloons, and whips.
The characters are so smug, that nothing they do seems appealing.
Harrison's Flowers' director wisely keeps [Andie] MacDowell quiet for most of the Yugoslavian scenes, leaving [Adrien] Brody to carry the scenes.
Sadly, 'Garth' hasn't progressed as nicely as 'Wayne.'
It isn't the saccharine sweet rags-to-riches type story, and it isn't dumbed down.
This one does a nice job and reminds us that the core of a good film is a good story.
Based on Dave Barry's popular book of the same name, the movie benefits from having a real writer plot out all of the characters' moves and overlapping story.
The sweet, happy ending will satisfy the movie goers.
There are remnants of romantic comedy, but they are obscured by gross-out humor.
I don't care how many times and in how many movies Woody's character can think he has a brain tumor, I still think it's funny.
The acting is much above average for action films and takes advantage of the depth of an experienced actor like Bale.
David Koepp has worked backwards to write the worst movie of his career.
I didn't groan once, and I left with a smile on my face. That's all I can ask.
The picture opens big with 'All that Jazz' and goes out bigger with 'All That I Want' and 'Razzle Dazzle.' This is an all-around crowd pleaser.
The Life of David Gale is gripping and has a good logical payoff. Director Alan Parker has done better but he could've done a lot worse here.
It is great to see Cage go from comedy to sentimentality to drama.
In the category of zombie movies, this is top shelf.
The fanciful flashbacks which are colorful and storybook-like add some magic to the mix.
Duplex's small laughs don't make up for the frustration I have with the story.
This movie also has some of the biggest laughs of a comedy this year.
The film is poetically austere in dialogue but thoughtful. Like a walk on a spring day, Lost in Translation is not momentous but rather pleasantly freeing.
As always [Chan] gets some big laughs.
The most intriguing scenes are of the dealers and their henchmen.
Robert Downey Jr. goes into Johnny Depp territory with a great performance that is at once antic and next turning on the tears with ease.
The ending has a suitable pay off, but overall the movie is derivative of other horror movies.
This is a motion picture that has the stillness of a painting. Watching it is like watching pretty paint dry.
A well written script can give a better slice of life depiction than a whole season of Rich Girls and The Simple Life. Interesting characters make it worthwhile.
The movie is a little underworld and a little romance, but neither story has a lot of impact. It could benefit from playing up the mysticism of Bernie's lack of luck.
The outtakes at the end brought tears to my eyes, they were so funny.
Eastwood's maturity is reflected in the story that doesn't back away from hard subjects and can admit that pain and remorse can mold a man's life.
The ending is so forced that it betrays the movie's potential.
Words can't describe the characters and color that inhabit this film.
It is unabashedly silly and playful. I don't think Atkinson could be mean or offensive if he tried.

An old-fashioned but emotionally stirring adventure tale of the kind they rarely make anymore.

A grand entertainment.
Filtered through the unsparing prism of history, it's a unique and powerful portrait of a marriage.
A sensitively directed, highly humane look at the ties that bind.

An unmoving, cold affair of the heart.

The film is always riveting.
Actually lives up to its title; it's a muted, uninvolving film.
Yet another tiresome coming-of-age movie.
A confused, confusing and too often glib treatise on matters of life and death.
Pointless movie.

Derivative, idiotic thriller that is devoid of any suspense, logic or intelligence.

The climax is worth the ticket money.
Outdated in its approach, and tacky in its handling, Shorgul disappoints on more counts than one.
Qissa is a brutally honest and shocking portrayal of the psyche of individuals who were unsettled during the Partition of 1947.
movie_title: Qissa: The Ghost Is A Lonely Traveller (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Watching this movie is a spiritual and uplifting experience. Don't miss it, for your sake.
Life is too short to waste almost three hours on this film.
Judwaa 2 keeps you entertained. Sajid-Farhad, master writers in the silly dialogue department, come up with numerous chuckle-worthy gags.
This is not a review of Sholay. This is to reiterate the greatness of the epic film.
Is it entertaining? Oh yes. Is it funny? The first half is, though the energy dips in the second half.
Shaandaar chooses to kill us with clichés [rather] than charm us with its idiosyncrasies.
Dear Dad is a one-line story that has been stretched to 100 minutes and beyond, as if to test the audience's patience.
A story with great potential, it could have been better. But watch it anyway because its simplicity is beautiful.
It is Deepika and Ranvir's sizzling chemistry that does full justice to Bhansali's passionate story.

It might have worked better if one, there was no incessant, absolutely irrelevant background music assaulting the senses, and two, if the lead actors were asked to relax a bit and some humour was infused into the storyline.
The film is fun but shallow, nevertheless. A pity, because with a subject of this kind, the possibilities were immense.

Watch this film for the fuzzy, heart-melting feeling that it will give you through the two-odd hour duration. But also watch it for the hidden charm, the stoic way the protagonists face the problem with their own brand of positivity and optimism.
The film with its tongue firmly in its cheek content, gives a timely, strong message of how blind faith and mob mentality can be easily manipulated by anybody in this country.
Watch it if brazen in your face is enough to titillate you. If not, let's wait for a more mature film dealing with sex.
A film with the right intention and its heart in the right place shouldn't be missed. Watch this one.
Poor dialogues and amateurish execution makes the characters look more caricaturish than believable.
It is to Hooda's credit that he gives a convincing performance even in this mish-mash of mush.
Don't miss this film. It is one of those precious little watches that's capable of giving a quick bout of spring cleaning to your heart.
This painfully long film is peppered with unnecessary songs after every two minutes.

It's a fun, one-time watch. And to its credit, it is straight, simple and clear about its intentions, unlike a few 'modern' ones that begin on a woman-friendly note, but actually end up belittling them.

Surkhaab is perhaps one of the finest examples of those small budget films which start with a good intention of dealing with a relevant issue, but then fall into the trap of making it 'safe' to ensure a box office hit.
We all know Arshad Warsi is a competent actor and his talent shows in a particularly hilarious scene which includes a Indo-Pak cricket match.
If this film looks like an entertaining, escapist film at the outset, it is, but it is also much deeper than that.
This film is a disappointment.
The film grips you right from the beginning and doesn't let you get away even for a second.
Second Hand Husband is definitely not a classic, but it manages to make you laugh out loud at some points.
Don't miss this one.
Arshad Warsi puts in a decent effort, but he's saddled with a role where he's grossly miscast.
Be warned. While watching Baahubali, you might have to periodically pick up your jaw off the floor.
If you think you have to leave your brains at home for a Salman Khan film, be surprised.
A fairly entertaining watch for dance enthusiasts.
Watch this film for Ajay and Tabu's performances and of course, that one-in-a-million story. Content, after all, is the key.
Fairly intelligent and relevant.
A good one time watch, especially if you are a fight junkie.
It's sad to see director Umesh Shukla coming out with this, after the delightful OMG.
Nawazuddin is brilliant as Manjhi. The film is carried solely on his frail but extremely capable shoulders.
The good thing is that this film. like its original, is totally unabashed and unpretentious about its silliness and randomness.
Sooraj Pancholi is good in parts, but then again he is limited by his one dimensional role.
Vijay makes for a good hero figure, but is handicapped by the absence of anything substantial to do.
Fast paced and guaranteed to keep you hooked for most part.
Neeraj Ghaywan in his debut film offers a realistic portrayal of the hypocritical society that we live in.
Watch this movie for the important story it tells - women standing up against racism and sexism in different and complex ways.
What should have been a late summer treat is soured by extremely lazy writing and a forgettable plot.
[Death Note] whitewashes a cast that's originally entirely Japanese. The result, as you'd expect, is soulless and nonsensical.
The moral of the story, children, is that the world, of superheroes and mere mortals alike, is all the more better when there are more women around.
It's absolutely brilliant to watch Marvel take the risk and put out something as zany, wacky and completely irreverent as Guardians.
Marvel proves yet again that it's not just running on a streak of luck: These guys have enough superhero tricks up their sleeve to keep us coming back for the foreseeable future.

Crushed under the weight of creating a Marvel-esque DC franchise, Batman v Superman fails to ever truly tap into the potential that a clash between two of the most revered superheroes of all time should technically provide.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Too many characters and too little context give the tragedy little scale and even less emotion.
Rogue One: A Star Wars Story sets the benchmark of how a good standalone film can be made without ruining a tight story with unnecessary sequels.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Lego Batman Movie is the fun, exhilarating and irreverent Batman movie we all deserve and need, and there are more than a million reasons why.
Warcraft is a welcome change from all the superheroes in spandex and capes that we've been inundated with since the beginning of the year.
Justin Lin's take on J.J. Abrams' reboot of the franchise, while taking it back to basics, fails to do little else but give you the faint promise of excitement, but never fully delivering.
All in all, Apocalypse feels like the rise of a new generation of X-Men characters that could easily take the franchise to new heights of glory.

Sally Hawkins delivers a performance of a lifetime...A visually stunning adventure that's part monster film, part romantic fable, and part Cold War thriller, The Shape of Water is a playground for some of Del Toro's favourite themes.
Part-horror, part-thriller and part-morality play, the justice system in the world of Killing of a Sacred Deer terrifyingly holds a mirror to our own.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: While the film may not punch you in the gut the way Williams' Jumanji did, the sequel offers much in the way of laughs and shallow entertainment.
The actors just couldn't make it work in Morten Tyldum's disastrous Passengers.
It's the kind of art that's aggressively theatrical, but not even for a moment does it feel performative.

Beyond the Clouds is a story about love, family and finding the two in unexpected places. That Majidi manages to tell this story in a country unlike his own - and tell it well - is a testament to its universal strength.
Pixar returns stronger than ever with a magical and visual treat that will tug at your heartstrings.
To summarise, treat yourself this week with a trip to 2049. You may return with more questions than before you went in, but at least it'll make you think.
If the original Kingsman movie asked you to suspend your disbelief, Kingsman: The Golden Circle wants its viewers to take it and shoot it all the way to hell.
The Last Jedi is not a film for the faint of heart. But courage, a sense of wonder, a resounding faith in the strength of love, and a healthy dose of hope will take you far.

Full of magic and fantasy with an interesting mix of eccentric and complex characters.
On the whole it's a fun film that is pretty much guaranteed as much success as the novel enjoyed.
An exhilarating and emotional musical drama which once again pushes the limits of modern film-making.
Except for heartfelt performances by Sophia Loren and Pete Postlethwaite as her wheelchair-bound husband, Between Strangers is an awful cheat.
There are many scenes of belly dancing, pure pleasure to watch.
Attal pushes too hard to make this a comedy or serious drama. He seems to want both, but succeeds in making neither.
Director Jay Russell stomps in hobnail boots over Natalie Babbitt's gentle, endearing 1975 children's novel.
Excellent bits of sound workmanship are that of camera and mike following Page and the heavy along the dance floor to pick up their conversation as they glide.
The British comic is still the consummate pantomimist, unquestionably one of the greatest the stage or screen has ever known.
There not being so much of Clara Bow in the picture, or a straining for her to turn on that 'it' personality, she gives an all around corking performance.
The main problem with the movie is the by now shopworn nature of its setting.
An A-for-effort novelty that, by the end, barely musters a passing grade.
A studied, original portrait of sexuality and its role in human relationships.

The tone of the movie...saves it from its preposterous plot.
A small film that packs a big wallop.

movie_review_blurb: Despite its admirable qualities, Canvas fizzles and falls into cliche.
It's sillier but funnier than Knocked Up, the summer's other notable comedy.

An important, timeless and sometimes troublesome classic has been filmed successfully and at long last.

movie_review_blurb: An irresistible Irish comedy, lovingly told, beautifully acted and graced with the perfect balance of chuckles and bittersweet heartache.
movie_title: The Boys and Girl from County Clare (2004)

Quality material for wee ones.

[I]ll-defined, creepy and not credible even within the parameters of comedy. The problem is that the story is not funny at all.
This story probably looked good on paper (and the film boasts its original elements), yet is ultimately not gripping onscreen.
Well-layered film about a disenfranchised young man fleeing a disintegrating family life and seeking refuge in the home of his putative girlfriend.
A cinematically impressive documentary about a treasure-hunting oddball who is regrettably not fascinating enough to justify 90 minutes of film time.
A complicated portrait of a dictatorial father whose "radical" ideology becomes a vehicle for abuse in an idiosyncratic family.
Inspired by The Searchers, Les Cowboys tells the story of a French father in pursuit of his daughter who has run off with her Muslim boyfriend. It's a compelling update.
Inscrutable and not especially compelling.
Riveting, morally complex film about an aging Holocaust survivor attempting to track down the Nazi guard who destroyed his family in Auschwitz.
Unnecessary reworking of Body Heat, this time featuring a very young lead who is involved with an unhappily married woman.
Lacks credibility and humor.
For viewers who are not into genre trappings, The Curse of Sleeping Beauty [...] is dull and silly beyond belief.
A predictable, flat-footed film.
Highly original dark comedy about brain-dead performance artists and the lasting effect they've had on their adult children.
A thoughtful and impressively performed Israeli film about a cheerful but mentally challenged young woman whose professional and personal ambitions are out of reach.
The autobiographical doc about a disturbed mother-daughter relationship and its resolution is not without interest, yet its exhibitionistic elements are a bit unsettling.
A well-crafted script, deft direction and an excellent cast [...] keep this from being just another romantic weeper. It's a weeper, alright, but a darn good one.
Unexpected is a well-acted and produced film [...] but [it] cannot compensate for its movie-of-the-week material.
Delightful, fast-moving animated feature that boasts entertaining characters, lovely visuals and fun tunes.
A vivid and compelling portrait of a much-snickered-at subculture that few Americans have give much thought to short of feeling superior.
"[Peter] Capaldi is a BAFTA Award-winning actor ... and if he were sending up a 'conceptual performance,' it would be brilliant. But this is not a mockumentary."
Though it's a bit pat, Isn't it Delicious is nevertheless a lyrical, touching comedy-drama about seizing the day.
Engaging overview of the women's movement launched in mid-century America.
Familiar and not fully plausible, but features top-notch acting, compelling imagery and interesting film technique.
The Only Real Game is refreshingly devoid of sentimentality, yet despite itself oddly affirmative.
[The Invisible Front's] sharp storytelling, editing and fast-paced direction make it riveting and immediate.
Al Pacino's superb performance as an aging, psychologically unraveling actor cannot save this pretentious and flat-footed film.
Whether the film will generate action is arguable, though Wolf has done a fine job in painting a disturbing portrait of refugee life with no end in sight.
A film with many shortcomings, yet notable for its ensemble cast and fine acting.
It is indeed uncomfortable to admit that a Holocaust documentary feels a tad generic, and while the film runs only 85 minutes, it seems much longer.
The Dog is a funny, bizarre and wholly entertaining account of John Wojtowicz's strange life.
For those who are familiar with this universe, Standbys is a worthwhile refresher course; for those who aren't, it's an eye-opener.
Nicely acted coming-of-age story feels oddly dated and lacks resonance.
Thought-provoking snippets and moments of suspense surface, but for the most part the film is generic.
In the end, Listen Up Philip is an idiosyncratic comedy-drama that is inexplicably seductive, despite its off-putting elements.
Predictable and just plain dull.
[Old Fashioned] raises some interesting questions, but in the end it's not credible.
Farewell to Hollywood is unbearably sad, at moments horrifying, and relentlessly compelling. It is a profoundly disturbing documentary on many levels.
An auspicious directorial debut for Forbes, who can tell a story, keep its momentum building, and has most impressively pulled together a fine ensemble.
The 11th Hour will be virtually meaningless-in fact, downright ludicrous-to any woman who has never had a burning desire to have a child.
Though Gooding tries hard to look sincere and troubled, often he appears slightly embarrassed. It's no surprise. Too bad so much talent is wasted here.
'I Believe in Unicorns' has its shortcomings. But it also lingers long after the final credits have rolled and bodes well for [writer-director Leah] Meyerhoff's future.
Visually striking but pretentious.
Good Kill is a fascinating character study set in a vividly evoked dystopian universe. [...] But as successful as [it] is on many fronts, it's also a tad disingenuous.
Queen and Country is a truly entertaining flick forged by a master storyteller and the acting is polished, even in the smaller roles.
It is still hard to fathom why an actor of [Richard] Dreyfuss' stature would find himself in a thin, predictable and wholly contrived indie like Cas & Dylan.
For the most part Anita B. is well done and engaging.
Racial diversity and girl power are dandy, but they cannot compensate for uninspired material.
Lyrical, memorable and beautifully conceived film about a woman charging after an elusive dream misfires in its final moments.
Kidnapping Mr. Heineken has elements of an exciting crime caper and at moments scores, but in the end misses its mark.
Edmands [...] has pulled together an impressive acting ensemble that brings to life three-dimensional characters and the frozen, claustrophobic world from which they emerge.
Mixed-bag documentary packs an emotional wallop despite its failure to achieve its goals.
A suspenseful and compelling film that's all the more powerful because it doesn't shy away from contemporary anti-Semitism in France.
Despite potential pitfalls, Is That You? is a delightful and nostalgic road-trip romance that explores the road not taken.
Though not groundbreaking, Joan Kron's documentary on plastic surgery is enjoyable.
None of it really makes much sense, nor is it cohesive stylistically-it has a low-rent feel.
A flawed yet ultimately lovely film centering on a mature romance and starring two icons.
This sincere drama about a young woman afflicted with schizophrenia is tedious to watch.
Uninteresting romantic comedy starring Glens Close, Patrick Stewart and John Malkovich along with a huge cast of supporting characters who are hard to keep track of.
An exceptional character study of an outlier who lives a Jekyll and Hyde existence in a universe almost devoid of causality.
Despite its flaws, this drama marks an auspicious debut for writer-director Ryan Frost.
So-called inspirational film about a mature woman who abandons her husband to run off and "find herself" on a Cape Cod beach. Absurd and dishonest in equal measure.
Terrific film about a dysfunctional artistic family that is at once funny, sad and totally credible.
An evocative but not fully fleshed-out documentary about a theatrical tradition that's lasted for half a century and may be coming to an end in a Tuscany village.
One of the most charming, delightful and hilarious comedies this reviewer has seen in a long, long time.
Set in Franco's Spain, this self-referential film-within-a-film is painfully dated and unfunny, and its mishmash of genres is even more off-putting.
movie_title: The Queen of Spain (La reina de España) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Thoroughly unentertaining.
movie_title: The Nut Job 2: Nutty by Nature (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Entertaining and original low-key family drama with comic elements.
Cliché-ridden redemption story about an unscrupulous corporate go-getter who changes when his son is dying of cancer.
Cliché-ridden melodrama about a Southern woman out for revenge against the man she believes was responsible for her son's suicide seven years earlier.
Neither amusing nor interesting comedy about three couples starring in a documentary centered on marital discord.
Fascinating yet somewhat schematic character study.
A totally implausible film[, ...] Swing Away is also a harmless entertainment with girl power themes for the pre-teen set.
Maya Dardel is cruel and unusual punishment-I thought that was unconstitutional.
Familiar and predictable family drama with several fine performances that regrettably cannot save the dreary material.
A potentially fascinating character study gets lost in a diffuse, minimalist film about the tedious lives of German construction workers laboring in Bulgaria.
Unfunny comedy rehashing the ways in which men and women are different.
An annoying rehash of anti-Israeli sentiment in connection with the occupied territories.
Its earnest tone is a major flaw.
Innocuous, dated father-son comedy that manages against all odds to be mildly appealing.
The story is simple [...] and the acting is brilliant, but the pace and style of The Bachelors may be too depressing to appeal to the Instagram set.
Flawed yet interesting exploration of contemporary Jewish identity.
An uncompromising view of a disintegrating marriage in a morally bankrupt Russian world, its truthfulness not easy to watch but compelling throughout.
The elements do not meld organically, feeling self-conscious and calculated instead.
An original, nuanced portrait of a Holocaust survivor who runs a tailor shop in an otherwise abandoned Kansas City mall and serves as a motivational speaker.
Holy Air is flawed, but on balance it's a winner.
Despite its limitations, Destination Unknown should find an audience among Holocaust fetishists, and it's a terrific teaching tool in the classroom.
Visually striking thriller about a blind woman who regains her sight and then loses it again quickly becomes predictable.
Somewhat generic but mostly agreeable.
A feel-good, well-acted, visually evocative foreign-language biopic about a master fencing teacher in Soviet-controlled 1950s Estonia who changed the lives of his students.
Lively and informative documentary about a brilliant sleight-of-hand magician who has a black belt in karate-and is blind.
Nice performances by Kevin Kline and Mary Steenburgen in an otherwise uninspired movie that explores a father and son's disparate expressions of grief when wife/mom dies.
Marking her debut as a documentary filmmaker, Kristi Zea-an Oscar-nominated production designer-forges a vivid portrait of a unique talent and personality.
An engaging documentary about an unlikely Israeli basketball team beating the odds.
A fast-moving, fun movie exploring the nasty machinations of a female lobbyist (Jessica Chastain) who is at once intriguing and a trifle grating.
Despite excellent performances, the movie lacks cohesion and focus.
Though fundamentally absurd, with a hodgepodge of genres to boot, Elle is an engaging and thought-provoking film.
This visually striking documentary about impassioned Dutch gardeners is meditative but at moments a tad monotonous.
movie_title: Portrait of a Garden (Portret van een tuin) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Awash in unrealized potential.
This silly romantic comedy may find an audience among the 30-something crowd but will make little sense to anybody else.
A two-dimensional reworking of Philip Roth's novel that reduces a complex story to a Lifetime movie.

'Christine' never morphs into a reenactment of psychopathology, thanks to Antonio Campos' skillful direction, Craig Shilowich's sensitive script, and Rebecca Hall's rounded interpretation of an intelligent young woman who is unable to navigate the world.
The Great Gilly Hopkins is a surprisingly well-written, directed and acted family film. Darn it, it's actually engaging.
An oppressively earnest family flick that teaches a lesson about living in the moment, change and growth.
Despite its self-conscious quirkiness and wink-wink moments, in the end this comedy has unexpected charm, appeal, even depth,
Provocative, if a tad disingenuous, documentary about Lifta, a Palestinian village that was abandoned in the wake of the 1948 Arab-Israeli war and now lies in ruins.
A thin and not fully believable courtroom procedural that nonetheless holds your interest.
Swing State generally scores, and if it's any indication, Sheldon's next film should prove winning.
There's a place for low-budget quirky, zany comedies, though they require a lightness of touch and appealing characters-regrettably in short supply in My Dead Boyfriend
Dull, slow-moving film about a young man in Florence trying to find himself.
A fascinating documentary about Gertrude Bell, frequently dubbed "the female Lawrence of Arabia," that could have been even better with more exposition and historical context.
A riveting character study that draws you in even as it turns you off.
Unfunny, cloying and implausible.
An original and subtle comedy of remarriage, with top-notch performances by Debra Winger and Tracy Letts.
A "new normal" family grapples with a gender-transitioning teenager. Not dull, but not really credible either.
Visually striking film about blindness and sight that lacks focus and purpose.
Trite and cutesy coming-of-age tale about a super-intelligent young woman who learns a life lesson through taking chances. Purgatory.
An unintentionally hilarious thriller about a demented woman seeking revenge on her ex-hubby and his new love.
Up until its absurd ending, Wolves is a familiar but engaging film about a teenage athlete in a troubled family attempting to navigate life's bumpy road to maturity.
An utterly charming, good-humored peek into the warring factions within one small, closely knit Israeli Orthodox congregation.
Awash in clichés and predictability.
A potentially interesting story, but ultimately a tedious and pretentious film.
This sci-fi action-adventure-romance has fine performances and real comic potential but is laden down with excess.
A wit-free comedy that defies classification (and not in a good way).
You don't have to be a foodie to find Roger Sherman's documentary In Search of Israeli Cuisine unexpectedly interesting.
No strand of Excuse Me for Living's frantic, unfunny, and pseudo-thoughtful narrative is well conceived.
[It] has many flaws, the foremost among these is the inability to indicate whether we're supposed to consider the savage behavior brought on by its crises as ambiguous or unassailably good.
Affair of the Heart's focus is so vaguely sketched out that it ultimately could be about any grateful artist who enjoys a modicum of celebrity years after his initial success.
A film in which any authority figure who can't magically sober up and play surrogate daddy for a spell is treated as either a meddler or a well-meaning, do-nothing skeptic.
Seeing "the years [slip] out of [Bill's] head" in this 71-minute compendium is nothing short of revelatory.
Dredd is proudly degenerate-and it never feels compelled to slow down and explain itself.
It's ... frustrating to watch Parker only talk about whatever she immediately thinks to say.
James Murphy never says that his music will sound different after LCD Soundsystem disbands, so why fearfully anticipate a change that we don't even know is coming?
movie_title: Shut Up and Play the Hits (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Knowlton never delves far enough into her subjects' stories for Somewhere Between to feel more nuanced than, say, a good commercial for international child-adoption services.
An unbearable 90-minute trip with a trio of loud, needy egotists-one whose updated scenario never feels like it needs the extra 75 minutes.
Jones and Streep give likable enough performances as a humane monster and a human victim. But their characters never become more than that.
The film's protests of censorship ring hollow given its selective version of the truth.
Something like a trippy grindhouse homage whose familiar images are refracted through a prism of blacklight posters, Jodorowsky films, and even Rob Zombie's grungy psychotropic sensibility.
Deconstructing Dad might be a messy biography, but it is a fascinating primer on Scott's work.
movie_title: Deconstructing Dad: The Music, Machines and Mystery of Raymond Scott (2012)

movie_review_blurb: This modest crime drama is infused with the joy and expectation that only comes from young filmmakers instinctively awed by their urban surroundings.
Flying Swords might not live up to the promise of Detective Dee, Hark's recent comeback, but it does deliver frequently and always when it counts most.
movie_title: The Flying Swords of Dragon Gate (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Ham-fisted dialogue and clichéd characterizations trump genuine chemistry in The Other Son, a contrived Franco-Israeli drama about two 18-year-olds, an Israeli and a Palestinian, accidentally switched at birth.
What most interests the creators of Race 2? Action-figure posturing.
As far as agitprop goes, The Return of Lencho is not totally generic, but its subject is mostly undistinguished.
The many shortcomings of 'Journey 2,' including its lack of chutzpah and sense of fun, are all secondary after its lack of anything truly spectacular, or even just exciting to look at.
The clunky action mostly revolves around uninspired wire-fu choreography: Monks fly around while flailing their arms as hordes of CGI creatures gather around and then do nothing.
movie_title: Bai she chuan shuo (The Sorcerer and the White Snake) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: It's thrilling to watch Nambiar futz around with tone and style for the sake of establishing a thematic progression.

An essentially conventional loose-cannon cop story made occasionally exciting thanks to some unexpectedly lurid narrative flourishes, Mumbai Mirror feels weirdly exciting and novel despite its pompous and clichéd scenario.
A well-measured docu-character study ...
Save for a couple of visually engaging dance numbers, mostly shot with hand-held digital cameras, MKBKM is dishearteningly banal.
A banal World War II thriller dependent on contrived role reversals.

Too many Wiki-worthy info dumps and not enough character-enriching detail stops Shady Lady, a docudrama about a team of World War II Australian bombardiers, from cohering into a compelling fiction-doc hybrid.
Without its topical pretext and overzealous patriotism, Allegiance would be just another generic action film.
The film feels flimsy rather than delicate, lacking strong performances or psychological nuance.
Deadfall just isn't manic enough to be memorable.
So trite that it's unwittingly insensitive.
Kapoor naturally exudes a kittenish charm that not even a violet, skintight, leopard-print dress and equally purple dialogue can entirely diminish.

There are few romantic dramas more frustrating than the kind that studiously avoid clichéd characterizations while gracelessly begging viewers to alternately coo and tsk-tsk the behavior of their adult protagonists.
The callow behavior that characterizes Ex-Girlfriends' lead would be less maddening had writer/director/star Alexander Poe firmly decided how to portray the bedroom follies of youth.
Ciancimino and director Kevin Patrick Connors's lone gag pays off. Too bad the joke is only funny in retrospect.
Mostly likable thanks to its creators' preference for lighthearted mugging over self-serious teeth-gnashing.
More exciting in theory than it is in practice.
Cleaner and probably more rewatchable than Red Cliff 2.
It's telling that the most satisfying segment in V/H/S was directed by a group called Radio Silence.

The world of difference in tone and content between actor-turned-director Jiang Wen's Let the Bullets Fly and his masterful Devils on the Doorstep can be seen in the former film's deceptively happy ending.
If Neon Flesh is any indication, writer-director Paco Cabezas is a deeply confused Guy Ritchie rip-off artist.
If you like your films like you like your airport fiction, then Puncture should be right up your alley.
So batshit that calling it director Tsui Hark's comeback is an aptly ridiculous claim.
movie_title: Detective Dee and the Mystery of the Phantom Flame (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The Good Doctor isn't a ponderous bore because Blake isn't a strictly good or bad character: It sucks because he isn't even a compelling character.
Claudio Cupellini's A Quiet Life works best if you think of it as a divergent alternative scenario for Toni Servillo's character in The Consequences of Love.
A consummately clear-headed documentary that honors the allure of its subject by being personal but never intimately so.
Pot comedies may not be rocket science but a few more script revisions would have probably gone a long way here.
Submitting Surviving the Game for the White Elephant blogathon is like giving an unwieldy lump of coal to a child on Christmas day: As malicious gestures go, it's a doozy.
As dated as it is, The Keep (1983), Michael Mann's second theatrical release after Thief (1981), remains an intriguing mess of historical provocation.
That kind of nonstop self-seriousness should wear thin after a while but director Robert Harmon makes the screenplay's unabashed cruelty more potent than churlish.
A toxically quirky black comedy starring a morbidly obese albino who dreams of traveling to Switzerland.
Red Cliff 2 is a bit more uniform in its languid presentation of the various sub-plots that branch out from the film's central conflict.
A cliché-riddled kid's film whose sole inventive hook is its hand-painted, Cray-Pas-by-way-of-water-colors animation style.
movie_title: Mia et le Migou (Mia and the Migoo) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The brutality of Tyrannosaur, actor Paddy Considine's kitchen-sink directorial debut, isn't so over-the-top as to make Considine's sympathy for his flawed characters look like a sham.
Thor continues the trend of weakly jumpstarting a franchise based on a Marvel comic with an instantly forgettable origin story.
Of the authorial trifecta that created Despair, director Rainer Werner Fassbinder's voice is the most pronounced.

In spite of his adorable CG fish-eating accessories, Popper is just another lazy, family-friendly stock patriarch in a long line of clueless but basically well-meaning fathers that Carrey has played over the years.
The film is by and large too concerned with not offending its audience too much for it to ever even be that shocking.
He may sing, "All I want is your pity," in "All I Want," but that sentiment is not what LCD Soundsystem deserves to be remembered for.
movie_title: Shut Up and Play the Hits (2012)

movie_review_blurb: In Coscarelli's reprehensibly lazy adaptation, much of which is copied note-for-note from Pargin's book, shit happens at a furious pace, and almost none of it is adequately explained.
If only there was more to The Surrogate than ephemeral beauty.
Mary Elizabeth Winstead and Aaron Paul only serve to highlight everything that the rest of James Ponsoldt's film sorely lacks.
It's a rousing drama and certainly Spike Lee's most hopeful since 9/11.
Weirdly enough, Robot and Frank's biggest problems don't stem from our not being able to take Frank's robot seriously, but from the depictions of the man relating to his family.
There's no essential truthfulness to Majo's emotional journey.
A beautiful fairy tale about survivor's guilt that's about as good as the festival hype would have you believe.
Celeste and Jesse Forever is a big missed opportunity.
It champions an incoherently hackneyed kind of morality where filial piety matters more than treating your fellow man well.
While the ending to any shaggy-dog story is supposed to be irrelevant, The Catechism Cataclysm's capper is particularly enervating.
The most striking thing about Carnage, Roman Polanski's adaptation of Yazmin Reza's stiff but satisfying stage play God of Carnage, is how much funnier it is than its source material.
Shark Night 3D sets itself apart from Ellis's other films in its sincere attempt to humanize its heedless pretty young things.
Love Exposure is, in a sense, Shion Sono's equivalent of the Great Russian novel.
Fassbinder, who also co-adapted the film's screenplay, usually makes a point of undermining the affectation of his melodramas with jarring intrusions of camp.
Zookeeper is essentially a surreally awful Happy Madison Productions version of Mad Libs.

Tim and Eric are vomiting their ids, replete with jokes about being covered in various different fluids (from rancid yogurt to semen), onto the screen. And that's sometimes pretty funny. But their kind comedy works better in short sketches.
movie_title: Tim and Eric's Billion Dollar Movie (2012)

movie_review_blurb: What sets Special 26 apart is its insistence that cops and robbers operate based on similarly intractable assumptions about each other.
It only looks like Tautou does a lot with a little in her performance because much of her character's inner life is implied through pensive scenes of her frowning and deferring her gaze.
The film's writers left no cliché unused, and no major plot point undeveloped.
It's a lived-in, unsentimental comedy about a community of smug but sympathetic intellectuals that, by film's end, becomes a little better-integrated.

While it's not much worse than its predecessor, Friend 2: The Legacy has none of the bromantic charm that made Friend, South Korean writer-director Kyung-Taek Kwak's 2001 gangster drama, the highest-grossing film in Korean history.
"Khumba" is essentially cut-and-paste cinema. The film's creators borrow a lot from the "Madagascar" and "Ice Age" films, and while that doesn't sound that bad, "Khumba" is disastrously uninspired.
When Commitment isn't a perfectly forgettable action film, it's either an oil-thin melodrama or a charbroiled treat for meatheads.
The film reduces Mandela's ideas to impassioned sloganeering, and the repercussions of his ideas to unmoving montage sequences.
While it is definitely Fellini-esque, it's also a crystallization of Sorrentino's own distinctive style.
The plot - Robert Davi's stoic detective and Claudia Christian's pushy psychologist hunt an undead lawman (Robert Z'Dar) - is pretty dull, but the film handily coasts on sleazy charm.
Many of the assumptions that Devries's arguments are based on are left unexamined, like his mostly unqualified comparison of the treatment of animals at family-run farms and factory-controlled farms.
There's just enough tension and humor in "Thor: The Dark World" to make the film's otherwise listless proceedings worth watching, but only just.
An emotionally generous and expansively detailed romantic fantasy.
"Aftermath" is toothless, and that's inexcusable for a civics lesson that's supposed to jolt us out of complacency.
The movie version of Orson Scott Card's "Ender's Game" is way too kind, and the drama suffers greatly for it.
It's gratifying to see Divine praised for being outrageous ...
"Haunter" has a solid setup, but the further Natali and King coax you into their labyrinth, the harder it becomes to appreciate what initially made their film so promising.
Smart and scary horror films about faith, and loneliness are rare, and for the most part, "I Will Follow You Into the Dark" is pretty exciting.
movie_title: I Will Follow You Into The Dark (2013)

movie_review_blurb: In spite of its enjoyable, easy-to-exploit aspects, "47 Ronin" is a big budget spectacle hamstrung by its need to be at once flippant and respectful of its honor-driven source material.
Thankfully, Milius is not just a hagiographic portrait of the artist as a crotchety, marginalized dynamo.
Based on the popular Bengali novel of the same name, Chander Pahar is an unfocused adventure-cum-travelogue.
The subject certainly isn't dated, but the film's dull post-John Hughes, sub-Judd Apatow style of comedy is like a just-buried time capsule full of accumulated clichés.
"As It Is in Heaven" ultimately doesn't go anywhere unexpected, but it does foster a potent, unexpected bond between its subjects and its audience.
Little more than an ugly collection of tropes stolen from "The Exorcist" and "Seven."

Imagine a film that makes A Modest Proposal-style satire out of Dracula's gothic horror tropes in the spaghetti western milieu of The Great Silence. It's a pitch-black comedy about Manifest Destiny and cannibal frontiersmen.
"Witching and Bitching" is accordingly overlong, and conceptually thin. But like most of de la Iglesia's films, it's also freakishly energetic, and often hysterical.
While "Ping Pong Summer" does aggressively pander to viewers' nostalgia (dig that Nike track suit, and Run-D.M.C. cassette tape!), it's also warmer and funnier than its worst jokes.
Writer-director Richie Mehta's characters aren't especially thoughtful. Like their creator, they make massive leaps in logic before they do anything.
"Cold in July," a pulpy, Texas-set thriller based on hard-boiled horror/thriller author Joe Lansdale's novel, fails to capture the discomfiting qualities that make it a Joe Lansdale story.
On paper, "Bad Milo!" sounds loosey-goosey-crazy-go-nuts. But in practice, it's understated, if only in relation to its bonkers premise.
There's just enough right in "Days of Future Past" to off-set what's wrong.
There's nothing lovable about a musical that leaves poor Meat Loaf to grasp lustily at low-hanging fruit.
"Blood Glacier" is too sleepy to do anything with its guano-stirring premise.
One can't really fault Bekhor and Math for trying to entertain rather than educate viewers. But their carnival barker callousness is really disturbing ...
That Demon Within often feels like a berserk plot-vending machine.
"Afflicted" is as emotionally involving as a really accomplished special-effects sizzle reel.
Mistaken for Strangers doesn't reveal anything about Tom but his own insecurity.
More horror remakes should be as thoughtful as "Patrick: Evil Awakens," an atypically clever riff on the 1978 Australian thriller "Patrick."
"Wolf Creek 2" isn't much different than "Wolf Creek," but it is markedly worse.
It's hard to appreciate an intentionally blurry portrait of a family that's so impressionistic that all you can see of its already-withdrawn characters are their shadows.
The movie's inability to showcase its greatest asset, the grace and control of its dancers, is its most conspicuous failing.
This is a David-vs.-Goliath movie, but David's aim is so spotty that Goliath has nothing to fear.
This sequel is sluggish and rote where its predecessor was aggressively perky and desperate to please.
Mud is as unmoving as it is because it doesn't aspire to be anything other than a competent anti-fairy tale in which the paint-by-number morals are enforced by equally obvious main protagonists.
Instead of retreating into his manic, hyper-allusive style of psychedelic, grindhouse-friendly pastiche, Zombie tested his considerable skills and made something different.
A fitting final act for noir master Jean-Pierre Melville ...

This is probably Rob Zombie's best film, though it does often prove that the cinephile writer/director is a gifted tyro. At the same time, as his most formally mannered and tonally tempered film, Zombie's latest also proves his versatility.
Some good laughs and a passable air of bonhomie do nothing to cover up the fact that The Angels' Share is totally lightweight and distractingly underdone.
Simultaneously dopey and irrepressibly charming.
Wailing amateur actors are thrust into viewers' face so often that Holla II looks like it was shot in someone's dirty rear-view mirror.
A relentless and largely unrewarding descent into an ostensibly personal hell.
An over-stuffed, hyper-pulpy, and mostly trite trifurcated drama about family, crime, and moral ambiguity.
Violeta Went to Heaven's creators do a disservice to Chilean singer and multi-hyphenate artist Violeta Parra's legacy by making her suicide the logical climax to her working life.
The film's creators exploit the group's natural, thoughtless enthusiasm.
movie_title: Mindless Behavior: All Around The World (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Korine's latest is a characteristically serious film about inherently ridiculous characters, but it's too montonous to be really thoughtful or funny.
When the creators of The Last Exorcism Part II swapped pseudo-verité realism for psychological realism, they made it a lot harder to take their franchise seriously ...
An exploitative docudrama that mercilessly begs viewers to wallow in an exhausting, stilted re-enactment of the 2008 Mumbai terrorist attacks.
It's pretty apparent that inmates were allowed to take over the asylum.
A romance, a thriller, and a science-fiction drama, "Upstream Color" tantalizes viewers with an open-ended narrative about overcoming personal loss.
Zheng errs on the side of improvisatory and lazily assembled Apatow-esque narrative episodes; many of those scenes are amiably goofy, but it all holds together based on his cast's charm and energy.
Arthur Newman an intentionally listless story about a boring everyman.
Shootout at Wadala is a true-crime gangster epic about an ostensibly charismatic outlaw who's really just a preening monster-something the filmmakers seem to miss.
Insidious: Chapter 2 is a puzzle movie with too many unnecessary pieces and not enough essential ones, but it's superior to its predecessor in a few basic ways.
Adore is a proudly feminist film, with both its pedigree and its themes allowing additional opportunities for women.
It soon becomes apparent that the filmmakers, many of whom worked together on "The State" and "Reno 911!", aren't committed to their film's main conceit.
"You're Next" is a simultaneously nihilistic and grossly incompetent horror homage.
The kind of American independent quirkfest that needs to be quarantined and examined, not valorized.
movie_title: Some Days Are Better Than Others (2011)

movie_review_blurb: "The Mortal Instruments: City of Bones" will make you yearn for more "Twilight" movies.
movie_title: The Mortal Instruments: City of Bones (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Therese Desqueyroux,...is not the nuanced period drama it should be but is rather more like a banal, pseudo-thoughtful and monotonous episode of Masterpiece Theater.
As ambitious and vibrant as it is ugly and scattershot, "Pain & Gain" is the most charming Michael Bay movie in a long while.
The demure, self-effacing Struzan undermines Sharkey's strategy by insisting his art is only the product of a mundane creative process.
movie_title: Drew: The Man Behind The Poster (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Reluctant parents: you don't need to tell your kids that you won't love them if they like "The Smurfs 2." Instead, you can silently judge them until either you and/or they simply can't bear the thought of talking to each other.
While it takes a while to come to a full boil, Drug War is an atypically grim gangster film from the typically inspired Hong Kong filmmaker Johnnie To.
Watching "The Conjuring" is like getting a tour of a haunted house attraction from someone that pushes, and pulls you through every room.
As shrill as it often is, the film's situational peril makes otherwise unlikable characters sympathetic, or maybe just sympathetic enough.
When Drugs is firing on all cylinders, it feels as if you're in a room with these people, just listening to one crazy story after another.
movie_title: How To Make Money Selling Drugs (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Instead of being a creepy B-movie about the necessity of suppressing one's animalistic urges, "The Purge" is just a product of uninspired filmmaking.
The creators ... only vaguely know what kind of story they want to tell-and not at all how to tell it.
Stands as a prime example of Meyer's infantile and sometimes disarmingly protean perversity.
Can't we allow ourselves to blamelessly dehumanize one group of real-life boogeymen without the fear of some would-be humanist insisting that these monsters, like us, have souls?
As ungainly and unkempt as its teen protagonist.

Though it looks like a highly polished, quasi-avant-garde bit of speculative fiction, contemporary French sci-fi flick Eden Log is really a far-flung descendant of the Heavy Metal comics of the '70s and '80s.
With Big Fan, screenwriter Robert Siegel's directorial debut, the schmaltz-meister that wrote The Wrestler shows us that he's grown leaps and bounds as an artist in the span of just one year.
Robert Rodriguez's Shorts may have a more complex narrative than Spy Kids but it's otherwise just as bland.
movie_title: Shorts: The Adventures of the Wishing Rock (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Pálfi's skill at making something as churlishly repulsive as a scene of self-mummification completely mesmerizing is a testament to his unparalleled dedication to imaginary grotesques.
There's a pervasive and unintentional Raimian sensibility to Grace, writer-director Paul Solet's feature debut, that thoroughly undermines its Polanskian underpinnings.
Writer-director Li Ying should be commended for the complexity he's given a subject as controversial as the Yasukuni shrine.
As a film about the underground resistance movement in Denmark during the Nazi occupation, Flame & Citron's spies are the historical equivalent of superheroes.
movie_title: Flammen & Citronen (Flame & Citron) (The Flame and the Lemon) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The Collector signals much of what's wrong with torture porn.
Co-writer/director Duncan Jones' debut feature Moon is a modest but nonetheless exciting bit of (derivative) speculative fiction.
The most a muckraking film like this can hope to do is frighten the viewer out of their complacence so much that they feel like, if only for a moment, they need to do something.
It's one thing to poke fun of stereotypical Greek behavior, but it's another to bitch about the tourists who clog the already varicose-thin Athenian streets.
With any luck, it will develop the cult it deserves because while its urgency makes it an easy target, Pontypool's new ideas are commendably gripping.
There's something fundamentally disappointing about watching Raimi use his considerable resources to just make more wonderful scat.
An overlong, sap-happy crowd-pleaser.

Up-and-coming filmmaking duo Luke Meyer and Andrew Neel's latest doc, New World Order, admirably humanizes the "9/11 truthers," a seemingly impossible task they accomplish handily by never condescending to or patronizing their less-than-credible subjects.
Events unfold at an unfathomably cool pace, making Horten a comfortably numb cipher.
The Final Destination is a mean little film with little brains on its side.
Before seeing Sorority Row, I couldn't imagine that any slasher film released this year could possibly be more misogynistic than either the Friday the 13th reboot or Donkey Punch.
Essentially a condensed version of the first few episodes of the series with a few elements from later episodes tossed in to make the show's climax appear more grounded.
movie_title: Evangerion shin gekijôban: Jo (Evangelion: 1.0 You Are (Not) Alone) (Neon Gensis: Evangelion 1.01 You Are (Not) Alone) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Stanley Tucci has such a disdain for subtlety that he doesn't even allow the viewer to suss out for themselves what made-up identities Don and Janna have assumed in each encounter.
Slaps, screams, and airborne fire extinguishers thoroughly destroy the film's air of mopey sincerity to bits.
Impatient as they may be, the filmmakers never lose sight of what's important, namely keeping Dutton's rag-tag group of survivors sympathetic and perpetually in peril.
About as personal and memorable as a seasonal card your significant other snatches up from a local Duane Reade at the last minute.
Raffaeli and Belle still lack the charm that would make their tight-lipped line deliveries memorable, but they still run, kick and hop around like nobody's business.
Preposterous by the end, but Green provides enough formal polish to the film to make it at least partially engaging.
Amiel commits the cardinal sin of biopics and confuses unenlightening biographical speculation with cutting insight into how a work of such complexity and sheer intelligence was created.
Considering the best thing here is a joke about Billy Crystal letting his freak flag fly, it's painfully apparent there's just no rehabilitating this stinker.
This is not a story about lamenting the inevitability of time but rather of living in denial.

Daybreakers was unceremoniously dumped into theaters by unadventurous studio heads in the first week of January, [but] one shouldn't take their cluelessness seriously: Daybreakers is so much better than they would have you believe.

Roland Emmerich provides the next entry in the "Apocalyptically Disastrous" subgenre of mega-blockbuster cinema, following up Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen with an equally soulless depiction of life at the end of the world.
Osunsanmi knows that everybody secretly wants to believe and when it comes to giving the people what they want, he does not disappoint.
There's a good reason why it's taken Duffy this long to secure funds for a sequel to his D.O.A. meal-ticket: It was never funny in the first place.
movie_title: The Boondock Saints II: All Saints Day (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Ong Bak 2 is infused with an urgency and relentlessness that few contemporary action films have.

Filipino filmmaker Raya Martin confuses broad scope with great depth in his alternate-history fable.

To give resonance to that pedantic, half-baked conceit, director Miguel Sapochnik apes the severe gravitas of Children of Men.

[Director Rian] Johnson presents an intolerably glossy and emotionless exercise in style; he's so in thrall with his skill at blank pastiche that he only half-heartedly tries to make us care about the film's characters.
[Chow's] hamminess doesn't make Dragonball Evolution make more sense, but it's a great way to cope with an otherwise inexplicable kitschfest.
Apart from the new ground Ahsoka breaks as the first female Jedi, The Clone Wars is a pointless experiment in computer-generated (CG) animation.

Screenwriters Alfred Gough and Miles Millar stuff Dragon Emperor with the same kind of disjointed details that almost ruined the jubilantly preposterous atmosphere of the conspiracy theory hokum in David Koepp's Crystal Skull screenplay.

All the clues make sense when pieced together -- but only on the surface.
movie_title: Ne le Dis à Personne (Tell No One) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Yawn-worthy.

Since it's a sweet, funny and relatively quiet film, the lack of Big Thoughts is easily overlooked. [Director] Meadows has given himself a much-needed break, and it's a very satisfying one at that.

The film's cerebral affectations unravel because neither one is ultimately able to carry the film's disjointed plot.

movie_review_blurb: An impressive document of devotion that miraculously stems from still-festering pain.

movie_title: Dealing and Wheeling in Small Arms (2006)

movie_title: The Good, the Bad, the Weird (Joheun-nom, Nabbeun-nom, Isanghan-nom) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The narrative is as complex as a piece of dry white toast.

A surprisingly poignant and enduring film.

movie_title: Legend of the Fist: The Return of Chen Zhen (2011)

movie_review_blurb: There are myriad reasons why the term "torture porn" never made sense and one of the most important is the irrevocable impact Herschell Gordon Lewis's schlocky gore cinema had on American movies.

movie_review_blurb: There's nothing inherently wrong with the fact that Top Floor, Left Wing makes light of a hostage situation involving Muslim terrorists.

movie_review_blurb: It may be impossible to turn off your brain while watching "The Wailing," but that makes the film's visceral charms that much more admirably vexing.
Panoramic wide-angle photography makes even the most claustrophobic side-street-set brawls look inviting, while crystal-clear extreme close-ups drive intimate parries and thrusts home.
If you like action films, you need to see "Kill Zone 2."

If you watch this film knowing that it is Steven-Seagal-wearing-a-du-rag-and-glowering-impassively-at-attractive-young-women bad, you will get what you pay for. That's both an endorsement and a warning.
Violence in "Dragon Inn" is exciting not just because it's choreographed exceptionally well, but because there's a genuine sense of danger and excitement in each fight scenes.
You can fully enjoy Belladonna of Sadness if you either overlook or participate in the objectification of a gorgeous victim.
"Holidays" is frustrating because its creators all have something good going for them, but almost consistently have no ideas of what to do.
I laughed a lot at My Big Night and can't recommend it highly enough.
"Green Room" may be too schematic to fully capture the essence of its characters' groddy milieu, but it's also economically paced, and gorgeous.
Skolimowski ties these characters' stories so close together that you're never really sure who they are. And that's OK.
"Hardcore Henry" is like a good roller-coaster in that it does not require a complex reason to be: it's there, it's fun, you ride it, and that's about it.
The film ... makes Marinoni sound generically obsessive and maddeningly inaccessible.
movie_title: Marinoni: The Fire in the Frame (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The makers of the grim, film-school-sloppy horror-thriller The Girl in the Photographs never flesh out their provocative thesis: that photography is a predatory act that allows photographers to control their subjects.
You can see flashes of bawdy comedic brilliance sprinkled throughout Parched, an otherwise grim Indian drama about four women living in a male-dominated village.
The film rarely comes to life because Rollins, the only compelling actor in the otherwise amateurish cast, is underutilized, and virtually everything else underdeveloped.
"The Neon Demon" is often productively brash, even if it is ultimately more preposterous than it is satisfying.
To trusts his actors, and uses them so well that you often forget that we don't know much about them beyond the worried look in their eyes, the smirk on their lips and the arch of their brows.
By emphasizing the uglier aspects of his most complex character, Lee turns an otherwise down-to-earth slice-of-life drama into an unconvincing morality play.
Demon ranks up there with The Witch and The Babadook as one of the best recent horror films.
A classic, albeit unsolvable, brainteaser.
It's very easy to be turned off by Perez's feature debut, but if you can get on its wavelength, you'll find yourself drawn in by one of the year's most original horror films.
If the creators of South Park had made it, Yoga Hosers might have been hysterical.
Summer of 8 may be as sincere as a Hughes movie, but it's as shallow as a kiddy pool.

Action hero Jackie Chan rises above uninspired sex jokes and a weak co-star in martial arts/road movie hybrid Skiptrace, a Midnight Run-style buddy comedy that shackles Chan to Jackass star Johnny Knoxville.
You can only coast so far on a novel idea's fumes, and Operation Avalanche doesn't go far enough.
The arbitrary value of life in I Am Not a Serial Killer makes its nature as an ostensibly character-driven mystery that much harder to swallow.
movie_title: I Am Not a Serial Killer (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A trio of naturally compelling working-class success stories is inadvertently diluted by inferior talking-head interview footage in sake documentary Kampai! For the Love of Sake.
movie_title: Kampai! For the Love of Sake (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The Mind's Eye is the kind of childish genre movie that gives genre movies a bad reputation.
Come for the abidingly mysterious plot, stay for Hagan's bewitching performance.
Let's Be Evil's vision of the future is ... tantalizing but shortsighted.
There's something here, but it's darker, and more elusive, than perhaps Fox even knows.
Japanese melodrama Our Little Sister is the rare film that captures the everyday pleasures and anguishes of family life.
A fetid slice of US exploitation cinema that chides audience members while ineffectively whipping them into a frenzy.
Italian drama Mia Madre is an either/or film, a humorous and poignant character study that frequently becomes an ensemble piece.
A gonzo idea in search of better execution.
A buddy film about overcompensating characters that seems to have also been made by overcompensating comedians.
People live, people die, monsters creep out of the shadows, but it's all a little too formulaic, cynical, and ... well, boring.

But the mood is ruined by sloppy direction and an offbeat rhythm. You can't help but feel like you're watching a parody rather than a sincere tribute to female-led blaxploitation films like Foxy Brown, Cleopatra Jones or Coffy.

Political head-butting and crabby bon mots energize a series of wide-ranging conversations about the nature of secular Judaism in the consistently entertaining documentary My Coffee With Jewish Friends.
This one is almost good.
Exceptionally good comfort food cinema.
A lot of things transpire in any given scene, but none of them will make you care what happens next.
It will probably break your heart in all the wrong ways.

Brody and co-stars John Malkovich and Rory Culkin laboriously establish their dull stock characters through tenuously related flashbacks about closely guarded truffles, deadbeat dads and stolen goldfish.
Every potential source for good popcorn entertainment is thrice warmed-over, and poorly executed.
The kind of bad movie that sounds amazing on paper, but is excruciating to watch, even at a brisk 82 minutes.
Bates and Reed's homoerotic sparring would be sexy and shocking in any context. But Women in Love's talkier scenes are more exciting than any screen nudity could be.
On the Beach at Night Alone" exemplifies all of the worst tendencies of Hong's films without many of his better qualities.
movie_title: On the Beach at Night Alone (Bamui haebyun-eoseo honja) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Even Angelica's most juvenile gags are a perfect synthesis of gross-out silliness and atmospheric scares.
The experience of watching this anti-climactic three-hour drama is unproductively depressing, and upsetting.
movie_title: A Bride for Rip Van Winkle (Rippu van winkuru no hanayome) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: An irresponsible and potentially dangerous postmortem of the still-unsolved 1994 pub shooting in Northern Ireland that left six Loughinisland residents dead.
Most Beautiful Island may take a while to get going, but once it does, you'll be eager to see what Asensio does next.
The kind of lame, unimaginative comedy that constantly takes cheap shots at elderly characters, and then turns on a dime and begs you to see the humanity in them.
Veiel's refreshingly open-ended approach invites you to find your own answers.
I'm sure you think you already know how you're going to feel about Mom and Dad. But it's better than that, and in ways that you really must experience for yourself.
The maddeningly unfocused Israeli documentary West of the Jordan River doesn't reveal anything insightful about Gaza settlers' reasons for either supporting or rejecting a two-state solution.
[The Forgiven] only succeeds as an ugly, empty-headed provocation.
Claire's Camera is, like many of Hong's best comedies before it, amusing without necessarily being laugh-out-loud funny.
Think of Itzhak as a revealing scrapbook of Perlman's favorite stories.
Chan seems to do everything he can think of to ingratiate himself with viewers.
movie_title: Police Story (Ging chaat goo si) (Police Force) (1985)

movie_review_blurb: Just relax, and let Yuasa take you wherever the hell he wants.
Has the same political urgency as Wes Craven's now-classic, but rough-around-the-edges early films, like Last House on the Left and The Hills Have Eyes.
The Lodgers disappoints on a number of levels, many of which have more to do with the limitations of its creators' imagination than the apparently minuscule budget.
Come for the gory swordplay, stay for the half-serious melodrama.
movie_title: Blade of the Immortal (Mugen no jûnin) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Cooke crams in so much persuasively appalling information ... that it's easy to forgive him for seemingly trying to push all viewers' proverbial buttons at once.
The most disappointing kind of bad horror movie: the kind that's too smart to be this dumb.

An unsettling, and sometimes high-concept doodle, but it's awfully hard to resist a film that marries Atomic Age paranoia and optimism with Kurosawa's signature post-modern, atmosphere-intensive style.
What Winchester lacks in originality its creators amply make up for in execution.
"Padmaavat" is a rare work of pop art that is both powerful and repugnant.
Legends of the Mountain's narrative fuse may be long, but Hu knows exactly when to light it and when to snuff it out.
The stylistic quirks that define the bitterly funny Chinese animated neo-noir Have a Nice Day are thrillingly original.
movie_title: Have a Nice Day (Hao Ji Le) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: A very dumb, and very satisfying throwback to a simpler time when American action films were as predictable as they were formulaic.
Monster Hunt 2 is equally charming, sweet, slight, and unmemorable.
It's fun to watch. I just don't think it's the kind of fun the filmmakers' planned.
Sadly, the makers of Leatherface didn't put enough thought into a sleepy story that could easily be titled 'I Was a Teenage Leatherface.'
Chan may still be figuring out what he can and can't do in his old age. But dreck like The Foreigner should be swiftly crossed off his bucket list, and never revisited.
The worst kind of science-fiction film: the kind that coasts on a central gimmick instead of delivering either visceral or intellectual thrills.
If you treat Harmonium like a mood piece, and respond to it on that level, you'll find yourself thinking about it long after you watch it.
None of this makes sense.
You will walk away from Matsumoto's film with a newfound appreciation of what movies can be.
A spectacularly miscalculated historical epic.
Sofia Coppola has made a modern feminist horror film about the dangers of not allowing your social conditioning to talk louder than your personal feelings.
Deepsea Challenge has too little interest in anything that's not Cameron's personal experience.
Worth seeing, even if its basic plot repeatedly stalls. It is a thoughtful movie, but not necessarily a fulfilling one.
A blackly comic performance by Colin Farrell provides the emotional anchor for Yorgos Lanthimos's film.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: We may be wrong to look for scapegoats for the 2008 global financial criss, but by normalizing Madoff's behavior, The Wizard of Lies thoughtlessly asks us to sympathize with a devil we don't want to know.
An ugly film whose ambitions are never matched by its creators' limited abilities.
An obnoxious story about revenge and self-destruction that throws together a bunch of hackneyed observations about humanity.
The action choreography is exciting, the operatic plot is compelling, and there's a genuine sense of optimism that undercuts the gouts of blood and thunderous sound effects.
The film doesn't offer anything new, and doesn't stop pushing 'Family' until even the cutest animal seems to be lecturing you to listen to your parents.
The film's charms are substantial, but what makes Slack Bay so original and enticing is also what makes it fairly alienating.
Unfortunately, the film's commendably atypical focus on characters, mood, and psychological realism does not make Schwarzenegger's latest necessarily good.
It feels lived-in despite its glaringly mannered dialogue and charmingly eccentric characterizations.
"Baskin" is a perfectly imbalanced mix of chilly atmosphere, heavy-handed symbolism, and familiar horror-movie tropes.
A surprisingly affecting call to arms.
Kuso may often feel unproductively loud, and monotonous, but it is a head-scratcher worth contending with.
A grade-A piece of meathead cinema.
Starts out as one kind of unpleasant, then switches gears to a higher level of unearned nastiness.
Don't Sleep could have been a great horror movie. Too bad a great topic does not necessarily make a great film.

American Made sells a toxic, shallow, anti-American Dream bill of goods for anybody looking to shake their head about exceptionalism without seriously considering what conditions enable that mentality.
Adequate as comfort food, but fails as anything else.
A maddening experience, watching a film with a great kernel of an idea fail to grow into something equally impressive.
There is no monster at the end of this story, only boundless regret, and tedium.

Endless Poetry feels like the product of a revitalized old master. There's a generosity of spirit, and clarity of intent that gives shape to the the film's rambling narrative, and broad-brushstrokes characterizations.
There's a lot of cool knives on display here, but the people doing the stabbing don't really matter.
Song's performance makes me wish the rest of A Taxi Driver was as thoughtful.
You may not think that a movie that asks you to understand terrorists is for you, but if you give Bonello 130 minutes of your time, he'll make you a believer.
Wolf Warrior 2 lectures you, pummels you, and then expects you to cheer.
While Battleship Island is sometimes unpleasant to watch, it is a consistently involving, atypically thoughtful crowd-pleaser.

Theron's commanding performance is remarkable because she gives to her character, through her take-no-bull body language and calculating stare, an intelligence that proves she's the right person for the job.
Noisy, silly, and sometimes rather fun. I just wish it weren't such a hot mess.
Once the novelty of the film's non-linear plot wears off, Killing Ground is mercilessly rote.
A sleepy globe-trotting adventure.
"My Golden Days" exists simultaneously within and outside of its characters' headspace, a testament to Deplechin's powers of imaginative sensitivity.
movie_title: My Golden Days (Trois Souvenirs De Ma Jeunesse) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Even the movie's refreshingly atypical focus on character-driven neuroses over pat post-Poltergeist-style jump-scares can't save Another Evil from its creators' lack of ideas.

Shirai doesn't answer a major question that viewers of his impressionistic slice of work-life doc The Birth of Saké are bound to wonder: Why does the Tedorigawa Brewery's arduous, old-fashioned fermentation process make its sake superior?
Business as usual for the irrepressibly cheerful, pineapple-dwelling sea-creature.
movie_title: The SpongeBob Movie: Sponge Out of Water (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The film never devolves into finger-wagging hysterics thanks to Ronit and brother/co-director Shlomi Elkabetz's keen attention to their actors' performances, especially Ronit's star turn.
movie_title: GETT: The Trial of Viviane Amsalem (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Jeff Bridges's abysmally campy performance may be the worst thing about disposable sword-and-sorcery fantasy Seventh Son, but it's also the only memorable thing.
Ugly, unfocused photography makes it impossible to enjoy the film beyond its theoretical novelty.
The Loft's boorish leads aren't sensible enough to be worth caring about, making the film's character-driven conclusion feel like a self-defeating cop-out.
Beautiful and thoughtful.
An interesting story, but unfortunately, rather uninterestingly told.
Even if you like bizarre movies, you'll probably like "R100," then hate it, then go back to liking it, then wonder what you're looking at. And then the movie will end.
Amateurishly realized sensationalism trumps character-driven drama throughout Killers, so Nomura and Bayu become generically morbid sociopaths with way too much time, and blood, on their hands.
Flawed but genuinely creepy ghost story The Woman in Black 2: Angel of Death is disappointing, but only because it comes close to greatness.
movie_title: The Woman in Black 2 Angel of Death (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Proves disarmingly entertaining thanks to a Tsui specialty: spectacular fight scenes.
Visually splendid, but generically flat-footed, "Song of the Sea" is an animated fantasy that comes close to greatness, but is rarely as clever as it is comforting.
Based on Pulitzer Prize-winning poet C.K. Williams's autobiographical work, "The Color of Time" is about poetry, though it has none to speak of.
Borowczyk's cruel attempts at social commentary are mollified significantly by his probing fascination with the female body.

We Are the Giant tries so hard to get viewers to cheer on the recent Arab Spring uprising that it distressingly ignores the individual factors that led Libyans, Syrians, and Bahrainis into the streets in the first place.
"What We Do in the Shadows" is an irrepressibly charming B-movie that never over-stays its welcome, and is both conceptually clever and admirably well-executed.
movie_title: What We Do In The Shadows (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Here's hoping Green's next film is just 90 minutes of Ray Wise talking to an imaginary friend.
Writer-director Liv Corfixen works harder to coddle Drive director Refn, her husband and subject, than she does to get inside his head.
movie_title: My Life Directed By Nicolas Winding Refn (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Without compelling characters, worthwhile performances, or superficially arresting aesthetic pleasures, the only thing of interest in "Out of the Dark" is its thematic concern with suppressed third-world citizens.
For a while, it's exciting enough to feel brand-new.
Schwarzenegger may be Maggie's main attraction, but he's so inessential to the film's drama that he could easily be replaced by a grimacing, monosyllabic pull-string doll.
